This has to be in my top 5 games of all time. I absolutely loved the Original Persona 3, and I feel Atlus did a great job adapting the game to modern audiences. I also love that there is more interaction between all the characters, they genuinely feel like your friends at the end of the game.

There's a lot of emotions going on right now as I'm writing this, since i did just finish the game. If you are ever considering picking up this game, it's a must have for any JRPG enjoyer. If you loved Persona 5, you will quickly convert into a Persona 3 fan with this game.

A fantastic remake, and an amazing game in it's own right. In my opinion, this is the best modern Persona game. I still recommend people play Persona 3 FES and Portable to fully experience what the P3 universe has to offer, as it is by far the best against 4 and 5. I doubted the price tag initially, but after completing this game, it is without a doubt worth the admission. I'm excited to see what Persona 6 and future Megaten games have to offer after this.. I believe the future is bright for Atlus games'.

The game is a good remake but there is one massive issue with it: Party AI doesn't work.
I will change this review when/if there is any improvement on this issue, or at least a proper workaround.

It starts off with small things that you notice:
-Junpei won't use fire attacks when it's clearly the critical weakness of enemies, opting to use physical attacks instead...

But fine, one offs can happen. However, gradually the more glaring issues become noticable:

-Shift: Party members cannot use shift or rather, will not use shift in battle. Why? This was possible in Persona 5 when the AI would somehow make a decision based on equipped Personas, adding a great flow of battle. This is unacceptable.

So what does this mean? It means that a party member will often just fire the same attack over and over until his or her turn is over with.

-Theurgy: Love this added component of battle, a nice added alternative of the combo attacks from Persona 4 and Persona 5... Fatal flaw? The party AI will rarely if ever use it when available. I have seen it used, however it's very rare. Currently I have a party where all 4 members have maxed the theurgy bar but just will not use it, even if they've run out of SP.... What is the point of this?

Basically if you play with party AI on, you are forced to switch to manual control to force them to use theurgy skills. A big step down from Persona 4 and 5 when these attacks would happen randomly.

If these features have been built in, then the AI should be designed to use them properly.

Apart from the awful Party AI, the game has other annoying issues:

-Dying and reloading: If you die, you are forced to go through the usual dreary ending screen. THEN you are not given an option to reload, but only to restart from when you first entered Tartarus. Likely, you probably regularly saved each time you went back to the entrance and therefore have a save that is more recent than that.... So when you die, you're forced to either go back to the main menu or to your first entry, and manually reload that save. It's 2024 Atlus! How can you bring in a save system as bad as almost 20 years ago?

-I am getting performance issues, occasional skipping on PC. But not that often and not that major.


Sorry, this is not good enough, especially for a P3 fan who spent 100 euros on the full edition.. 

Polish your game, and above ALL. fix your party AI, Atlus.

I've played OG Persona 3 multiple times years ago, but this still feels good to play today. This is a great first Persona game if you've never had the chance to try one. If you're coming from P5R, this game will feel a little more barebones. Still, the gameplay loop is tight and fun.

Game runs kinda iffy on Steam Deck though, especially considering the verified tag. Some sections of the game (velvet room, dorms, some parts of tartarus) have some pretty egregious framedrops, maybe due to lighting? Regardless, the game looks great maxed out on a decent PC.

All in all, I recommend this game and I absolutely love it. However, I'm not sure if it's worth the $70 price tag. At the end of the day, this is an 18-year-old game with a really, really nice-looking coat of paint. The re-recorded music is top notch, the UI is amazing, the visuals are stunning, but the story is basically still the same old persona 3-- actually a bit worse in some ways because, although plenty of new content was added, some major content from the original is missing (no FeMC/FES ending). If you don't know what I'm talking about, then this game is definitely worth it. If you've had experience with this game before, I'd ask myself if I'm willing to spend $70 to replay a beautified and re-hauled 18-year-old game.

Edit: Steam Deck framedrops have been fixed. Game runs well and if frame caps are used, good battery life is achievable.

Persona 3 Reload is Atlus's move to modernize P3 for a current audience. One that is familiar with Persona 5, and while it doesn't render any of the previous versions obsolete, it modernizes it wonderfully. Even if it might not go above and beyond or reach the same heights as P5R. 

One of the biggest contentions about Persona 3 as a whole was the story. While it was a story that was amazing on paper. Many thought that it had a lot of pacing issues, especially with its cut scenes. Regardless of how you feel about the original, Reload makes a lot of attempts to remedy this and to good measure. A lot of characters are alluded to early on to give them enough screen time but also not alienate the player. Sure some parts can go on for a while, but considering the story being told, I think its worth it. 

One of the new selling points of P3R is the amount of voice acting used in the game, this is the first game in the series to have fully voiced dialogue. I think this is a great move for the series as it helps keep confidants engaging and some of these moments are made that much funnier as well. Speaking of, the English dub sees a mostly new cast. Now I got the privilege to meet the members of SEES at a convention, (where they all signed my PS5) and I can tell a lot of them are really happy to be apart of this project. Some of the new voices I think are leaps and bounds better such as Aigis and Junpei. Though others not so much, like Akihiko and Ken. Overall I am happy with the voice cast and I don't mind the recast, especially considering a lot of the original cast got cameo roles ala the Mario Movie which is really cool to see! Obviously this is not a thing with the JP cast where most of them reprise their roles with a couple of exceptions. 

Gameplay is very similar to the original though with some new improvements such as balancing, menu navigation, world exploration and mechanics such as shifting or theurgy attacks that are based off of Persona 5. While it might feel a little derivative, its also important to know that if it ain't broke, don't fix it so I don't mind this. One important change made was being able to control your party members, which also changes both the dynamic and balancing of battles since now you have a lot more strategies to down enemies and take them out instead of having an AI decide based on your options. It goes a long way to keeping the flow of battles up while still feeling like enough of a challenge (at least for me). 

Music is good as well, rapper Lotus juice from the original and he does not mess around, especially with the new verse of Mass Destruction or Its Going Down Now. Although the vocalist can be very hit or miss. New songs like Color Your Night work well for her, and even some old ones such as the credits or Master of Tartarus, but then you have When Moon's Reaching Out where she just sounds like a peanuts character simply put. However overall I like a lot of the remixes and the new songs so its a net win, even if there are some stinkers. 

One point of contention among Persona fans is the lack of The Answer or Femc from FES or Portable. While it is indeed a missed opportunity, it doesn't weigh down the package overall so its loss doesn't feel as noticeable as some might make it seem. With that said, there are rumors about the Answer being a DLC campaign and Portable is on Steam and other platforms so there are still options. Personally I think this does enough to stand on its own, maybe even surpass both versions. 

I had a really good time with this game, Its no secret that I am a big Persona fan, but this is the kind of game I will recommend to everyone. Although I think Persona 5 is still the better starting point. While I got my moneys worth at $70, when P5R is $60 (and goes on sale a lot physically and digitally) plus is just a newer game all around, I think that works better overall. But still if you like Persona in general or RPGs such as Like a Dragon, you honestly have no reason to skip this one.
Still not Persona 4, but it's as close as close can be.

The long desired sequel to Persona 2: Innocent Sin and Persona 2: Eternal Punishment has certainly lived up to the hype spawned from its predecessors, despite taking the series in a drastically different direction.

God bless you all for taking your time to read this. I recently found my son playing a video game called "Persona 3." I was doing house chores while he was playing it in the living room. It seemed like a child friendly and educational game at first. The characters were at a school and learning math. The next thing I know, they were shooting themselves in the head! The characters had what looked like guns and they'd put them up to their heads and shoot. I got worried, so I did some research on the game. The guns are actually "evokers" used to call upon a "persona." I'm worried that my son will one day find a gun and try this out, or try to evoke evil spirits in other ways. I learned that there is a sequel called Persona 4 where the teenagers call a "persona" by using tarot cards. This goes against the Lord. As I kept doing research, I learned that these games are a part of a bigger series called "Shin Megami Tensei." What I learned about this series is horrifying. There are games called "Devil Children," "Devil Survivor," "Devil Summoner," and "Digital Devil Saga" that are part of this series! This got me really worried about what my son was playing. In these games you summon and fight "demons." These demons look really similar to what my son was summoning as "personas." What can I do? I'm scared that if I take away the games, he might try preforming these things in real life and rebel. But if I don't take them away, he'll be felling into the hands of the devil! Please pray for my son!

A wonderful remaster and rejuvenation of a great game. The emotional highs and lows still strike a chord all these years later, and the characters shine through. Combat is engaging while also challenging at times, even in the Peaceful mode. Relationships are worth exploring in this tightly spun narrative of hope in the face of death and loss. Brilliant job by Atlus in reviving a great game and giving it the tender love and care it needed to bring it up to date. While it suffers from occasional frustrations from any game in the Persona (sometimes I want to save before in between the long series of important cut scenes and lore dumps), it's still a worthwhile venture into Tartarus and the Velvet Room.

It's P3 with all the QOL improvements we got from future installments and more. Only thing missing is The Answer but if it's coming, PLEASE make it DLC and not a rerelease like P5 Royal. Otherwise, thanks Atlus!

Fantastic experience so far. For context, I've never played P3 before, but have completed P4G and P5R.

The UI in this remake is magnificent; reminiscent of P5's for sure but crisp, responsive, fluid, and BLUE. Voice acting is stellar. Gameplay also reminds me a lot of P5R -- albeit a bit simplified, which isn't a bad thing on its own. I'm not too deep into the story just yet, but what I've experienced is incredibly immersive and tantalizing, just like any other Persona entry.

I'd recommend this game to anyone! UNLESS they haven't played P5 or P5R yet, then check that out first. Another massive W for SEGA after Infinite Wealth.

Around 2 years ago, I finished a PS2 game that changed my life. It was the second game from that series that I played and, while enjoying my time with that first title and still hold it in high regard, this one hit very different. It was a less refined title to be sure, with game play that was flawed and clunky at points, side-characters that were rougher around the edges, a tone far edgier than what came later and pacing that was fairly questionable in the middle stages. Those weren't issues for me...

The story of that game genuinely changed how I viewed the world. Death is a terrifying thing. It matters not who you are, death will come for you no matter how hard you try to avoid it, a certainty that everyone will desperately try and avoid. After the rocky two years prior, I genuinely was horrified at the thought and had this sinking dread upon thinking about it, my heart consuming itself in the void of its own making. 

Yet, after playing around 100 hours of a single game, I don't mind it as much anymore. The presence is real, but the pain is gone. Living life to the fullest, building bonds and enjoying simple goals, even taking care of someone for a short span of time in the history of the Universe... that's what life is about, why its worth living.

Two years later I got to re-experience this game in a remake. I can gladly say that while Persona 3 Reload has its own drawbacks in its own right, I cannot help but recommend this game. Its confidently my favourite work of art I've experienced, its theme so integral to my existence that I genuinely don't know if I would be where I am without it. I don't think there are enough words for me to aptly describe how I feel about this game, and goodness knows I've tried.

Persona 3 Reload is a perfect reimagining of the PS2 classic.

The original game's story is loving recreated with more modern quality of life updates. Additional social scenes with SEES members really help to flesh out the cast and improve one of the Persona series' core pillars. The new voice cast successfully captures the personality of the characters and in some ways deliver superior performances compared to their counterparts,

The gameplay is also a massive step up from the original, including many gameplay and combat improvements making P3 more in line with the gameplay of Persona 5. However the general gameplay loop from the original is intact mainly how Tartarus and the Full Moon Shadows work, in fact most guides from the original game will work nearly 100%. The social mechanics are mostly intact however the social links are now much easier streamlining the games dated system and bringing closer to P5's confidant system. The exclusion of P3 Fes' The Answer epilogue and P3 Portable's are notable however I feel their absence is negligible. 

At the end of the day I think that Persona 3 Reload is everything that P3 did well while bringing the less well aged mechanics and bringing them up to 2024's standards.

My first Persona game was Persona 5 Royal, so I can't avoid comparing them.  After reading so many people say Persona 3 has a much better story than Persona 5 (even life-changing for many), I do feel pretty let down. Overall P3R is definitely a very well-made game with mostly well-written characters and a satisfying gameplay loop, but it is undermined by real flaws.  NOTE: All spoilers are in footnotes.

Gameplay

From what I can tell, P3R makes a lot of significant improvements over P3 FES and P3P's gameplay, with more stuff to do in the real world and with more variety in Tartarus.  Combat is also much better balanced, bringing in some ideas from P5 without making it a clone of that game.  On the pro side, for example, theurgy attacks are a much better version of Showtime from P5R, giving you more control over choosing which one to use, how they charge up, and how they reflect the characters.  I still wish you could skip the cutscene... but still a significant improvement.  On the con side, Tartarus is really dull compared to Persona 5's palaces.  There's almost no environmental storytelling in Tartarus, no clues as to why one level looks different from another (and why one specific section, as all my party members EXPLICITLY ACKNOWLEDGED, is physically painful to look at, so the devs knew what they were inflicting on me).  The only motive to explore it for much of the game is simply because the leader said so, and because you need to grind so you can face the monthly bosses.  I also really question the decision to add variety floors that actually make Tartarus more of a pain, such as the greedy shadows that steal all the loot and you have to guess which directions they run in to catch them, most of the time without any clues.  Later on they give you an SP costing skill that just skips that whole minigame, so I can't understand why they put that in there to begin with.  Finally, enemy variety is severely lacking compared to Persona 5.  Even the bosses you fight in Tartarus are just mixed up versions of regular enemies with no truly unique mechanics.  Thankfully combat is generally fun (and quick) and the loot flows nicely through Shuffletime, so Tartarus really isn't a terrible experience over all; it's just incredibly uninspired from a level and enemy-design standpoint.  It also gets very easy, even on hard mode, where I simply used melee focused characters, healed them with Yukari's ridiculously cheap healing, and never had to use SP items again past the midpoint of the game.  Again, it's reasonably fun because I genuinely like these characters, but I can't escape the feeling that it could be so much better.

Music

More hit or miss for me than Persona 5, but I do love jazz much more than rap (the dorm song started setting my teeth on edge after a while), so it's going to come down to personal taste for a lot of people.  A lot of the songs for running around school and town are great, though I do wonder why they didn't go harder on other aspects of the ambiance like the weather.  Rainy days would make so much sense in this game.

Side Stories

The social links are pretty hit or miss for me, like the music.  Some are great and thought-provoking, a couple are genuinely funny and made me laugh, but several of them seem pretty pointless or undermine themselves in the rank 10 conversation.*  Biggest disappointment for me with these links is that the main character is so undercharacterized it's not at all clear why talking to him is this amazing, life changing experience for all these people.  Even if you give people terrible, life-destroying advice, they discover themselves regardless and credit you as their dearest friend and savior.  Joker, in Persona 5, has much better dialogue options, IMO, and also helps turn people's lives around in concrete ways with his unique abilities.

Story

You'll hear a lot of people say this game has the best Persona story.  In fact, that seems to be a pretty overwhelming consensus on social media, from what I have seen.  It definitely is good, and much better than I have found in most video game franchises, but it's really strange to me that it's considered so clearly better than Persona 5 because there are some pretty obvious flaws.  Not fatal flaws, mind you; I still enjoyed it quite a bit, but I found Persona 5 a lot more compelling from start to finish, and I'm not even going to talk about the differences in pacing.

First off, people praise the characters in this game.  Regarding your companions, I think that's definitely deserved.  I like nearly every companion in this game better than their most similar equivalent in P5R.  They feel more down to earth, less trope-y, and they have better defined and consistent development that is interwoven well with the main story, with one exception.**

Regarding the villains (who are, after all, supposed to be characters too), this is definitely not deserved.  Without delving into spoilers in the main body here, I will just say there are a lot of inconsistencies in the motives and actions of the villains in this game.***  E.g., sometimes they use overwhelming force and sometimes they hold back for no clear reason.****  

The plot and worldbuilding also don't feel as developed as Persona 5, but I have heard some of my questions in this area will be answered with DLC.

* Maiko's story was really touching, and I felt for her, but asking to marry you just made the whole thing leave a sour taste in my mouth.  It would have felt much more natural if she said she was thankful for you because you're like the older brother she never had.  The epilogue scene for this social link is also bizarre, because the father opens his heart to you like you're a close friend then turns on a dime and starts screaming at you to stay away from his daughter.  I've known IRL bi-polar people who don't flip that fast.

** Aigis is weird and creepy as a concept, and as trope-y as it is possible for a character to be.  I will never get over the idea that a scientist for the Kirijo Group decided to make a "weapon" that looks like a 16-year-old girl.  The Chairman actively highlights this problem with how he introduces her, telling the group to look for a weapon so SEES starts looking for a tank or something.  And when we met her, I literally thought, "Please don't tell me they're going to have the android learn what it means to be human by discovering emotions..."  It's the laziest version of that trope, too, like the difference between Avatar and District 9: both movies get you to sympathize with aliens, but one takes the easy road of making them attractive and perfect; the other makes them hideous and STILL gets you to sympathize, which takes much cleverer writing.  Aigis is obviously the former, not the latter.  She stands out all the worse against the other SEES members, who are actually interesting, flawed people.

*** The Chairman was a huge missed opportunity.  He could have had so many interesting connections to Yukari's and Mitsuru's fathers.  He could have given an alternative, more nihilistic philosophy compared to the main themes of the game.  But instead the sum of his motives is he believed a prophecy (no clue who gave this prophecy or how) that someone would become a king (over a bunch of dead people?) if Nyx came back.  For that he was willing to live a double life for years and crucify you all, murdering Mitsuru's father.  I mean, COME ON you've got to give me more than that.

**** Takaya has a revolver that he always gets perfect killshots with when he uses it, but he only uses it when the plot demands somebody die.  Supposedly he is desperate to stop us from ending the Dark Hour, but his strategy is to... shoot one of us at a time, with several months in between...  And when he fights you as a boss, for some reason he does it totally honorably without even trying the gun, even though that gun was unblockable by a couple of the most powerful persona users in this game.

What an absolute masterpiece of an RPG this game is. 

A proper blend of random dungeon crawling at night with the daily grind of a school life,
Stories within the Social links are all mostly the same in quality, but it is clear that some would hit harder to some people than other Social Links. Exactly how life is with socializing, you will meet people you might not click with, while you can find those who you instantly relate to with their stories as you spend time together.

While the questioning of the content that was taken away will always be discussed, I would personally like to say this is the best version of Persona 3 as a whole. Significantly more polished in its mechanics and tone, lack of a severe and sometimes blatantly unfair punishments from the original are gone. It made the experience much more enjoyable throughout the whole game. If they do add the Answers DLC or the Female MC story, it would only serve to enhance an already masterful product. And I will look forward to that day if it arrives.

This is one of the games I will absolutely give a 10/10 mark in all aspects. Gameplay that requires proper strategy, a story that will immerse you with its profound way of dealing with its darker themes, all neatly tied with a wonderful OST all across it.

I love these games so damn much, man. Even though Persona 3 Reload is still bogged down by the missteps of early persona, the game is still a must-play for anyone with even a passing interest in jrpgs. These games just make you feel good, and even though this one is ten times more depressing than the other two put together, watching the credits roll is like saying goodbye to a close friend.

Even though I love P5 and the story of P4, I never got around to playing 3 as bearing witness to THE worst turn-based rpg gameplay I'd ever touched with 4 killed any and all desire to go even further back in the timeline to a game that was sure to be even more clunky, ugly, tedious and frustrating. When the remake was announced, it became the only game I have truly looked forward to since Elden Ring, and I'm extremely happy that my hopes paid off, even with a company as shitty as Atlas.

The gameplay of P3R runs counter to P4 in every way, in that the gameplay is some of the best turn-based combat I've ever played. It's so stylish, so flashy, so fun and satisfying, and it flows like an absolute dream. While tartarus is still an endless labyrinth of the same 3 rooms copied and pasted over and over and over for [spoiler] 264 [/spoiler] floors, and is still a tedious slog to get through as a result, I'm more than happy with keeping the game as faithful to the source material as possible for the longtime fans rather than the transient tourists. While some battles do still reek of that obnoxious early persona, eg. comical health pools, constant statuses and insta-kill attack spam, the vast majority are still fun and tactical. Anything is better than the sticky, clunky, ugly, stock sfx laden hell that is P4's combat. (Missing all your attacks for 4 rounds straight is fun, right?)

It should be outright criminal to have a game series with music THIS good. No words I have can do justice to the absolute euphoria that is this game's soundtrack, so I won't even try. There is not a single piece of music in this game that I hate from start to finish, every single one is just a transcendental banger. You know you have something special when you find yourself getting your groove on while just wandering around the overworld.

The story is probably the weakest of the 3 persona games though. While it isn't bad by any means, it is extremely clich√©d and doesn't really progress for about 75% of the game's runtime.

[spoiler] 

"Where monster!?" 
"There monster!"
"Kill monster!" 
"Wait for next monster..." 
[/spoiler]

sums up a large majority of the game's runtime, and the game doesn't really do much with its interesting premise. On top of that, the party members themselves don't get as much time to shine as they should. In the other two games, each new member of your group is the focus of an entire arc of the story before joining up. In P3 though, they just kinda show up, wave, and then that's it, they're part of the party now. On top of that though, I was also baffled to discover that none of the male party members have social links. Apparently it's a holdover from the original game having a male and female protag, and there aren't enough tarot cards (or time) to add them all, but like, I can become best friends with a fat guy who nearly shits himself in front of me on multiple occasions but I can't get closer with the guys I'm risking my life alongside? So to compensate each of the guys have a sort of truncated, pseudo-social link system that just randomly pops up whenever it feels like. It's not ideal, but it's better than nothing. (I guess). Be prepared though, as even though the overarching narrative isn't the best in the series, the game makes up for it by being much more emotionally charged than the other two. Every social link, every party member, every story beat is just downright depressing at times, and even though there's still plenty of that persona levity mixed in, this is a very dark game. Even though I had been spoiled on the ending and knew what was going to happen for 70 hours, I still wasn't ready when it finally arrived.


And to round things up, the game is drop dead gorgeous with stylized graphics and a buttery framerate. This is what the PS4 was keeping us from all this time, and I'm so glad these games have a home that doesn't chain them to 30 fps gameplay anymore. (Although am I the only one who thinks that the school looks... off? The place is so white and textureless that it looks like it was cobbled together out of spare assets.)

So to summarise: I love this game. It's everything I love about jrpgs, and I hope that Persona 6 can keep the flame going when it releases in 2035 after Persona 5: Dancing in Tactical Strikers 2's 3rd dlc.

Persona 3 specifically is a very memorable game to me. I first played the Portable version on PSP and, even with a lot of downgrades of the original (and some QoL from Persona 4), it managed to affect me in a very emotional and thoughtful way of many different aspects of my life.
Because of it, I followed this franchise from that point on and played many other Persona and SMT games, most of them were indeed a great time/experience, but not a single one managed to hit me like 3 did.
But even with my personal bias and attachment to it, I will try to give at least an honest to good review about positive and negative aspects of this "Remake". Please take all of it with a grain of salt.
Pros:
-The models are amazing. They really did polish everyone, not only Soejima's Art style improved, but his anatomy as well. If you compare to Persona 5 models, the new ones are less uncanny than the previous game.
- The Soundtrack is top notch. Atsushi Kitajoh managed to create not only beautiful arranges from the originals made by Shoji Meguro, but  with the return of the legendary Lotus Juice on the rhymes, they managed to outclass Mass Destruction. It's going Down is perfect in a way that hits you with a dopamine rush when you hit shadow advantage and, if you time it correctly, hit an all out attack at the peak of the song. Color your night still gives you a "Persona 5" vibe, but you can still "feel" it belongs to Persona 3. The entire soundtrack likes to work on small leitmotifs here and there to make you feel attached to the atmosphere of the game, and when you hit the final part + the credits song you get a kind like "nostalgia" punch on your gut together with the really emotional ending.
- The Battle system is even more balanced and comfortable than the previous Persona games. The party members skills got buffed, the addition of Kouga and Eiga spells balanced the Light/Dark elements. The Navigator system AND Baton pass equivalents got balanced/nerfed to improve the all in all experience of the game, not to mention since you're fighting shadows, you can't have a spoiler of their weaknesses from the Velvet Room fusion/Recruiting them on ambush.
- Tartarus got a INCREDIBLE revamp. The original and portable versions made Tartarus only looks the same thing with different color schemes each Name Floors, but on Reload each one has it's own vibe/environment/random seeds to make the Immersion and experience way better
- The addition of Link episodes with party members and, even with some story relevant characters made the experience even better for newcomers and P3 Veterans. They even added some special situations that were exclusive for certain Versions of the game (one from P3FES and another from P3Portable FemMC route only)
- The addition of Theurgy Skills made the gameplay even more interesting, putting the Fusion Spells the protagonist had on Theurgies (and not requiring you to have the Personas on the party all times) not only balanced the use of it, but also made it even more interesting to complete the Compendium
- You can now choose to date a female Social Link or not. Compared to the original, you were obligated to
date the girls and even had the risk of getting a reverse arcana if you got caught cheating or ignored them for a long time
- Reverse Arcanas now are way harder to get, In my entire gameplay, I didn't get a single one, so I think the only way now is purposely choosing a rude/stupid option on the Social Link interactions, which brings me to the next topic
- Voiced Social Links improved the Visual Novel part of the game, making you feel more attached to them.
- Better HUD/Aesthetic design than the previous games.

Now with the Cons:
- The game feels way more easy than compared with the original and other Persona games, sure, it takes more time to "break" than Persona 5, but the few cases I got a game over were on two specific battles and against the Reaper because a friend on Discord kept insisting for me to beat it on level 35~50. Even with all the QoL and balance on some mechanics, Theurgies really help to mitigate or even brute force some bosses/challenge battles. 
- You can't change Tartarus Theme like the FES/Portable Version, which is a shame because after a while it gets really boring to hear the same arranged for more than 200 floors.
- The game does gives you more options, but you still have the same time limit from the previous games, so, unless you follow a guide or is a veteran, you can pretty much fail to get all Social Links on the first play through(Veteran's Advice: focus on the School Social Links since you can't do them on weeks before exams, exams and school vacation+near the ending)
- The Social Links are a hit or miss for the community. Either you hate them, or you love it. So I highly avoid discussing about that online.
- Some Link episodes are miss able and even unlocks some specific Personas to fuse, so if you don't make them or lose one, you're pretty much screwed.
- Not having the "Answer" and "female MC" route makes the fan base debate if this could really be the definitive edition of Persona 3, but they already confirmed on making a future DLC for The Answer Episode, so, only time will tell.
- Tartarus has few Designs for each Floor Section and some are either extremely short, or stupidly big with a big NOTHING on them, so after a few times, you just ignored them and just look to the HUD on the left side.
- The Artbook and OST DLC's are a scam. You cannot access them unless booting up the game SPECIFICALLY for each one, meanwhile Steam has a built in MP3 player for games with Soundtrack for years already. This is probably a terrible decision from Atlus/Sega to avoid people from pirating it or spreading on the internet.

I highly recommend this game for both Veterans and newcomers, and I can assure that this game was a test/base for the future Persona games (possibly 6 or another 4 Remaster)

[h2]intro[/h2]
Persona 3 Reload is a remake of probably one of my favorite RPGs of all time, and it nailed it spectacularly in my eyes. The story is mostly unchanged, with a new feature called Linked Episodes and all new character casting. The gameplay has been vastly revamped to function as a mix of P3 and P5 while Tartarus was reworked. The soundtrack has been redone by the team featuring a new vocalist and more Lotus Juice. The graphics and artstyle of the game is upgraded to a level near P5, featuring a mix of CG and animated cutscenes for important scenes. Reload didn't really reinvent the wheel for me, but it was more Persona 3 which I enjoyed. Some sections below will probably bleed into the other ones by how they're affected.

[h2]Story/Casting[/h2]
Persona 3's story being unchanged means it still has a very slow beginning and doesn't really pick up for the first few months. The Linked Episodes are days where party members/[spoiler]Ryoji[/spoiler] will ask you to hang out. These are absolutely fantastic, they add more exposition/character thoughts about their situations. They have story arcs, new CG art, and allow you to fuse a new Persona at the end. They bleed into gameplay however, since most of them take place during the already limited daytime. The character casting is wonderful in Reload, with the old cast voicing side characters and the new cast getting better throughout the story. Social Links are 100% voiced in Reload and it's amazing (referenced below).

[h2]Gameplay[/h2]
[h3]Tartarus[/h3]
The gameplay of Persona 3 Reload is a mix of very different and very similar. Tartarus is still a whopping 264 floors and is still the majority of your playtime. But the blocks visually look and navigate differently (just wish they played different themes), with many new features sprinkled throughout. The Tired system has been removed. Monad passages on floors have a strong enemy inside and reward you with items and the map of the floor and the floor above. Block breakpoints contain boss gauntlet versions that are excellent one-time rewards. F.uuka is a much better navigator in Reload, being able to buff the party before fights, make you invisible/distress enemies, and fully map the floor. Some floors are "Dark Zones" where Twilight Fragments spawn in abundance (a new currency used for some treasure chests and the clock in Reload), but spawn the Reaper after around 1 minute. The Reaper doesn't show up until 62F, but once unlocked can spawn on any floor and even chases you up floors.

[h3]Battle System[/h3]
The battle system was reworked to be a mix of P3 and P5, with the 3 Physical skill/6 elements system. Less enemies have instakills at a lower level, and Kouha/Eiha (Light/Dark non instakill) type skills were added to Personas and Shadows. Like Portable you have direct party control, and the original Tactics system just isn't very good in Reload (doesn't make use of Shift or have original options). Shift is a new feature similar to P5's Baton Pass where hitting a 1 More lets you swap turns to another character. (doesn't buff you inherently, requiring Shift Boost/Amp) Missing/blocking/repelling an enemy with an attack no longer invalidates your extra turn/downs you. Party members have different skill lists from the original games and some perform much better and some kind of diminished at first. (but everyone has a good list by lategame) At nighttime in the dorm characters will have voiced hangouts, and doing enough of 1 type grants them a Characteristic which passively buffs a part of their kit. All party members have extremely powerful abilities called Theurgies which charge up passively depending on their personality (think Limit Breaks in FF!), The protagonist's Theurgies are the Fusion Spells from the original games but they only need the Personas in their Compendium.

[h3]Fusion/Shuffle Time[/h3]
The Fusion system is heavily upgraded and works like Soul Hackers 2/SMTV, with a Fusion Search option that shows you a complete list of what combinations make what from the Personas you have. Filling out the Compendium grants the protagonist a very strong Characteristic so it feels rewarding. Skill Cards are dupable daily at the Shrine, making it extremely easy to build something powerful. Shuffle Time is no longer a minigame and you can just pick your reward/s with no consequence of cursed cards. Major Arcanas are a new card type that serve various effects, and once you hit Arcana Burst (cap) it buffs all rewards for the rest of the expedition. Finishing an enemy with an All-Out-Attack or Theurgy greatly increases the Shuffle Time chance.

[h3]Difficulty[/h3]
Now with all these changes you're probably wondering if the game is still hard. Yes at early game where resources are scarce, but it's very easy to overlevel just casually playing since floor subbosses give a lot more XP now. Rare Shadows don't run away near instantly and grant a boatload of XP in Shuffle Time. Easily dupable Skill Cards from Shuffle Time and Compendium prices allow great access to builds. Full moon bosses have new/reworked mechanics and are still pretty interesting. Merciless isn't weird like P5 and actually makes the game harder. Basically having direct control+Shift turns the game on its head, where you can bring the same group of party members for every encounter and shift back to protag as needed.

[h3]Social Sim[/h3]
The social sim aspects of the game are mostly the same with some nice additions. Linked Episodes, nighttime voiced hangouts, exploring the strip mall at night, and using the dorm computer. The Episodes, hangouts, and fully voiced Social Links are my favorites! You feel a lot more connected with the characters having it all voiced and it's an absolute treat from start to finish. Time is limited and with only 2 Social Links occuring at night, you spend the daytime progressing Links/Episodes and night time progressing Social Stats. School answers are changed, and sleeping in class gives Courage. Romances are no longer forced at rank 8 like the original, and social link reversals are even rarer.

[h2]Soundtrack[/h2]
The soundtrack has been redone by the team with a new vocalist in tow. I'm partial to this change, I believed several songs from the original were done worse in Reload namely Mass Destruction, Master of Tartarus, and the final month themes. When the new vocalist does get to shine in the new songs though she is absolutely wonderful! I didn't let these bring the game down too much for me, but I do wish we had a toggle option like many other remasters/remakes allow for soundtrack. Additionally the soundtrack included with the deluxe edition is truly awful (I left a review there) but yeah.

[h2]Graphics/Artstyle[/h2]
Persona 3 had a clean artstyle for the time, and Reload raised it up to P5's quality. Some areas of the game especially Iwatodai Dorm look too bright however, but I believe you can color correct it to look like the original. I have a very weak rig and yet I could play on the highest settings with no frame dropping (probably because this game still runs on xbox 1/ps4) so performance is good as usual for Atlus games. Most of the major scenes were done in CG instead of anime, but certain scenes not animated before were animated in Reload. Going into Reload at first I did not think this was a grand idea. (coming off Portable's PC launch and expecting FES/movie scenes) I was pleasantly surprised by how everything looked and having a closer view on the scene really adds to it. 

[h2]Fin[/h2]
Persona 3 Reload is a remake that does Persona 3 justice. It doesn't completely morph the game into something unrecognizable, it just adds more Persona 3 throughout and makes it look neat and proper for modern-day. Despite small gripes about certain decisions by Atlus (like this game being $70) I fully believe it was worth the price. If I had to give it a number rating, I would put it around 9/10. Enjoyment is subjective though!

P3 Reload all but completely erases the flaws I encountered in other Persona titles. The graphics and UI are gorgeous, the cast is very interesting and varied, the gameplay is addictive, the soundtrack is full of bangers and earworms, and the story was engaging and had plenty of wonderful takeaways and heavy-hitting emotional moments. The story in particular is a very high note, and surprisingly mature in spite of the high school anime aesthetic.

P3 Reload goes above and beyond what is expected of remasters, making for a lot of wonderful new systems and options and soulful revisions to improve quality of life and overall game experience. $70 for a remake had me leery at first, but it's genuinely worth every dollar. There isn't a single area that I can truly naysay this game in, and the most I could offer in terms of ideas for improvement is to have settings for xp and money rate adjustments to alleviate some of the grind that I did to hit some optional milestones at certain points.

All in all, I have never had a game that aced every single area there is to judge before. 
I see why older fans were so into P3. P3 Reload has become my favorite game of all time over 20 years of gaming. If you enjoy JRPGs, i'm positive you will enjoy this one, too.

One of the best games I've ever played. The gameplay is highly addictive and most importantly fun. The turn-base system isn't something I typically enjoy, but this whole series is the exception for me. It's fun and really thought-provoking at times. I enjoyed the flair that the combat had, a slick type of design compared to P5R. The social link system is also really fun, learning about a bunch of new characters and having it connect to the combat of the game is really smart. The story is where the game shines tho. The characters are really well-developed and have some sort of underlying theme with them. The plot is also good with a bunch of plot twists and reveals. The message of death being unavoidable and learning how to live your life with the time you have is done so well here. The ending is perfect ;(. Music all bang, I honestly think there is not a song here that isn't good. Full Moon Full Life, Memories of You, Mass Destruction, It's Going Down Now are all highlights in the game. Voice acting too is actually perfect, only cast member I thought was a bit below everyone was Yukari but that was for some scenes. My only complaint is that there isn't much to do at night. 

10/10

After having played the game for this long I can safely say it's great. It is undeniably a good experience and a good entry point to the Persona series just like Persona 5 before it. Although, being a huge fan of the original, it's my personal opinion that there are some real flaws with this remake.

Most of the unique features from the original Persona 3 have been discarded in favor of the more modern iteration of the Persona gameplay such as the removal of the protagonist being able to wield every kind of weapon, which added immensely to the customization and strategy of the game. They also brought back direct party control which is a nice feature just like it was back in Persona 3 Portable, however, just like in that game, the AI control has been pushed to the side and is unable to actually be properly viable in any situation. The AI control was a key component to the original vision of the game, not something to be fixed. It was deliberate and it, along with many other things, truly added to the idea that these people in your party are people entirely seperate from you who live their own lives as well as to the difficulty of the game, needing to plan way ahead and thinking things through a lot more than with direct control. I do recognize though that not a lot of people actually enjoyed how Persona 3 went about its gameplay so I can excuse direct control being at the forefront of it. However, what I can't turn away from is the presentation.

The game itself is beautiful and almost every area is wonderfully recreated and given new life but most of the original gloom is gone. The game is far too bright in some places and it HEAVILY leans into the green color scheme present during the dark hour which would be fine if not being used in places where the original clearly was going for an entirely different atmosphere. The atmosphere in the final boss is effectively ruined, where the original had dark clouds surrounding the arena and everything was very gloomy and dark along with a slight unsaturated green tint, the remake splatters bright green all over the place with it looking no different than any other place in the dark hour. Another aspect to the worse presentation are the cutscenes. The animations are beautiful no matter if it's in engine or animated but they are all worse. The direction in all of them is very weak and nowhere near what the original had, such as the first time the protagonist summons his persona which takes away most of the tension and "coolness" of the original. The game also goes for a more watered down normal anime look to the 2D cutscenes which is not a bad thing but it does fit way less and is not as unique as the original style of the cutscenes. This change in art style is also seen with the sprites for the characters when they are talking and these are more important than they may seem thanks to them being present the entire game. The original Persona 3 had incredibly expressive and unique looking game sprites, every character having a wide range of emotions as well as poses. The remake completely throws that away for incredibly basic sprites that virtually all look the same minus a simple smile or frown and the position of the head for some cases. It's mind boggling to me how some sprites simply weren't even remade and the times they were used in the original, others are used in the place of them that simply do not fit at all. I don't understand this change whatsoever if not to keep it more in line with the ones in Persona 5 but even then there are some sprites in that game that are far more expressive. The art style of the sprites themselves is completely fine, I have no issues with them whatsoever even if they are less unique and I completely understand the change when it comes to that. 

In terms of story it is pretty much the same with some new added things here and there. These additions are by far my favorite, such as the new interactions with Strega and the events that pop up sometimes with characters that do not have social links. These are amazing and give glimpses into these characters you wouldn't get otherwise unless you played as FEMC in P3P and even then, as far as I could tell, all the events are entirely new. These should be kept going forward for characters that don't have any social links in the future Persona games. The ending of the game is also amazing, it is given justice and it has aspects from different adaptations of the game from what I could tell. Truly, in terms of story I have nothing to complain about.

The english voice acting, the one I played with, is not bad at all. I think every voice actor does a phenomenal job though some characters could have been closer to the originals because as it is you have some who sound exactly or near the same and some who sound completely different. Beyond that I think it's just as good as the original and the new voice acting in social links especially adds to that.

The music is, in my opinion, amazing. I love every track without exceptions after having heard them all for quite a while. Yes, some are weaker than the originals but I don't think there's any song that is outright terrible or anything of the sort. It would have been great to have the option to play the originals instead which I still prefer over the new ones but no, you're stuck with them. I am fine with that especially given that the battle them is far better to me. It's Going Down Now is my favorite battle theme in Persona hands down even though mass destruction fits a lot more and is a way more iconic.

Circling back to the battle gameplay, it also has some flaws of its own. Firstly, the addition of shifting is actually pretty nifty but the AI cannot use it which makes no sense because the ones in 5 could. This adds even less reason to use the AI tactics and makes that feature dead on arrival. Then there's theurgy which is just not fun whatsoever with the exception of the ones that raise your attack or orgia mode but you could already do that without the need for an entire new mechanic. Theurgy attacks make the game too easy and they require barely any planning whatsoever for an incredible amount of damage and sometimes even more so if you strike the enemy's weakness with them. The idea to make the fusion skills theurgies is pretty cool and sure, so is giving every party member a special attack, but it is pretty much just broken from my experience. I have killed bosses simply by maxing out my theurgy skills prior and then using all of them, which yes was entirely my choice but the fact that it even is one is kind of stupid to me. Beyond this though, I like the other additions made to the gameplay such as the new Tartarus which is beautiful, the new major arcana cards and the monad doors scattered around which offer quite a bit of a challenge (given you don't just spam theurgies).

Do not let all this deter you from getting the game though! Like I said at the start, it is undeniably a great game! Most of my criticism revolves around me having played the original and prefering how it was handled far more as well as simply the fact that many of these new features and changes go against what the original creators had in mind for the game which really only annoys those who wanted a pure 100% true to form remake which was never going to happen so I am happy with what we got. All and all I recommend this game even if you're new to Persona.

As an avid Persona fan, I believe the new features that were added to this reboot of the game not only brought a refreshing redesign to the old gameplay we all know and love, but also revitalized a very integral game in the persona series. At first, I thought the changes would be jarring and overall feel like a wave of nostalgia was lost but I was wrong. Atlus really did a great job with the execution of this game and I highly recommend it, especially for someone who is just getting into the Persona series or just recently played Persona 5 royal.

To preface this I am marking this a negative review simply because steam doesn't allow for a mixed option. Overall this game is a 5/10. A major positive is OST, the original game has always been known for its phenomenal soundtrack and this is no exception. However since this is in all seriousness the only real positive for this game then you should just really listen to it separately. 

Now onto the negatives:
The first negative is Tartarus, which has to be the most boring dungeon out of any rpg I have played. There is nothing of note that happens during this part of the game and is exclusively used for grinding. Also the music for every area in Tartarus is extremely repetitive and makes drudging through every floor a slog. If this dungeon was entirely optional then it would not be so bad but it is required to beat the game and you will have to run through all 264 floors for the ending. It also makes personal progression not really mean anything since it feels endless. 

The second negative aspect of this game is the story or the lack of a story. Nothing happens until the last 3 months of the game as there is not really any interesting plot thread to keep you invested until then. The main villains of the game do not have a clear motivation for what they are doing as they flip on dime. Interactions with them are sparse and the main characters do not have any reason to really fight them except one specific scene on the date 10/4 (Spoilers obviously). Speaking of characters all of them are stereotypes or plot devices and have little screen time with each other. The best example of this is Ken, he just shows up in the story, is only plot relevant for a month, and then just ceases to exist in the any type of scene relevant to the main story. The inverse of this is Misturu, her entire character is exposition. She willingly withholds important details from the party or just forgets to tell you (Again, this pertains to the scene during 10/4). Junpei is your basic best friend that chases after women and has character arc during the game that doesn't really mean anything due to a one note character being at the center of his development. It would be so much better if we knew anything about this character that Junpei interacts with but the game just doesn't elaborate on anything. Aigis shoves the message of Memento Mori into every single discussion involving her that it becomes bland. Fuuka doesn't really do anything besides exist. While Yukari has least trauma out of every character in the game except for Akihiko. Koromaru is the best party in the game just because he is a dog (I know this isn't actually criticism, I am just biased). Alongside nothing actually happening in the plot it only describes events that happened in the past. You do not actually progress through the plot itself as most the interesting things have already happened and you are an observer until the final 3 months of the game.

I don't really recommend this game to anybody unless you really need to know what happens in it. I believe the best thing you can do to experience what little plot there is is to just watch a lets play on youtube.

I am also glad that fans of persona 3 portable will finally and forever shut the hell up about their butchered ass version of the game.

This is definitely not a perfect remake by any means, but it is a more approachable version of the game with some nice new additions and QoL features. The original Persona 3 is by far my favorite of the modern Persona games, so I was really looking forward to this version of the game. It does unfortunately feel like a very sanded-down/sanitized experience compared to the original. The combat is so much easier that it's just kinda boring at times, and I don't particularly like the inclusion of elements from Persona 5 Royal (I wasn't a fan of baton pass or 'showtime' attacks in that game either tbf). The eerie, brooding atmosphere of the original is entirely absent. The new rendition of the soundtrack doesn't feel like it accurately captures the tone of the original game. I do like the new tracks in this though. The general art direction is much weaker overall, though I do like the new menus a lot. With all of that being said, I still like P3 Reload quite a bit. I don't see this game as a clear improvement, but Reload is a nice supplement to the original game. I'd recommend playing Reload as its own experience, but I think Persona 3 FES is just as great and absolutely still worth playing.

I do appreciate that there's much more voice acting now, and that there's the option to switch between English and Japanese voices. I'm a big fan of the original PS2 English dub, but I've been really enjoying experiencing the game with the Japanese voices this time around. The new hangout mechanic is also a great addition. This certainly isn't the worst way to play Persona 3 if you've never played it before or if you're looking to revisit it, but I'd strongly recommend playing the original FES as well. Persona 3 is one of the best role-playing games ever made, so you'll have a great time regardless of whatever version you choose to play.

There are some remakes that are made to fill pockets, and there are some remakes made from a place of love. This is the latter. Reload remains faithful to the original Persona 3 for better and sometimes for worse, which is respectable. ATLUS took some cues from P5's stylish design, while keeping it distinct enough to where P3R is not just P3 with a P5 skin. As you would expect from a Persona game, the music goes just as hard as ever. Despite not having Portable or FES content (yet), P3R still stands on it's own two legs as a solid re-imagining of the original P3, standing alongside P3P and P3FES as a part of the Persona 3 family.

Almost everything I could have asked for in a Persona 3 Remake. It‚Äôs actually shocking how faithful they were able to keep it to the original while making it still feel like a fresh experience. Like they really didn‚Äôt add any new businesses or locations but the way they repurposed the old places to work with modern Persona mechanics like gardening or working part time was pretty seamless. Because of this, the game is way less daunting than something like Persona 4 Golden and especially Persona 5 Royal for newcomers. At the same time, I didn‚Äôt ever get the same issue I had in P3 FES where I had long stretches of time where I had absolutely nothing to do in my night time slot and it started to get monotonous. The game strikes a very good balance between not having enough to do and not having so much to do that it‚Äôs overwhelming.

I feel basically the same way about the story as I did in the original. It starts off a little meh and the pacing can be a bit awkward with how long you have to wait for major events which don‚Äôt always feel like they were all that meaningful, but once it gets going, it‚Äôs genuinely a very gripping story. It helps that more effort is put into expanding on characters like Shinji and Ken who I previously didn‚Äôt feel much for because of how little they got to do in the original game (note that I haven‚Äôt played portable so I can‚Äôt comment on the FEMC route in that game).

I do have a few gripes though. One, the game leans a little bit too much on the easy side for my liking. I‚Äôm no expert at Persona games but even I was having no issue zooming through Tartarus in single time slots. The game simply gives the player too many options to destroy everything in their path. Theurgy is absolutely busted. If it were up to me, I probably would have limited it far more. Maybe one Theurgy use per battle so that you have to be more strategic about when to use it and who to use it on. Sylphid Aura also made it so that if I ever felt unprepared for a battle, I could use a negligible amount of SP from Fuuka to instantly have a massive advantage. 

Admittedly, I was playing on Hard mode and not Merciless, but that brings me to my next criticism. New Game plus was absolutely ruined in this game. I wanted to try Merciless out to see if it would up the challenge enough, but for some god forsaken reason, they made it so that if you start NG+ with merciless, you only carry over cosmetic items. This means you no longer have all the social stats you spent the first playthrough building up which makes it way harder to max out all social links (which is pretty much the only reason I play NG+ in persona games). So I decided to bite the bullet and just play hard again. But for some reason they made player level carry over on any difficulty setting aside from Merciless which completely unbalances the game and removes any challenge entirely. And yes, I know that previous games‚Äô NG+ gave you access to the compendium you‚Äôd built up on your first playthrough which made any challenge completely non existent, the difference is that you had a choice whether or not to use the busted personas way earlier on. You don‚Äôt have a choice what level your character is at so you have no choice but to make it ridiculously easy or reset all of your progress from the first playthrough. As someone who used NG+ to try out harder difficulties once I got used to the game while simultaneously using them to max out everything, this is really disappointing and there‚Äôs absolutely no reason they had to do it this way. I can only hope they fix this in an update but I‚Äôm not crossing my fingers.

Over all, this was an amazing remake and the complaints I had were pretty minor at the end of the day. It‚Äôs a great game to get someone into the Persona franchise and returning Persona fans will love it too.

If this is your first time playing Persona 3, you'd better download the PS2 emulator and play superior FES version then Reload. 

-Visual: Art direction of the original game is gone. 3d model take getting use to. 

-Music: New tracks are amazing and very memorable. Old tracks are very bad. In gameplay instrumental track are not noticeable, but vocal tracks catch your ear straight away. The changed vocal actress to Azumi Takahashi and producer to Atsushi Kitajoh. They can't give the same feeling of the old tracks and when compared to old ones they are straight downgrade

-Graphics: New P5 style graphics are good. Menus are stylish, but personally don't like overstilization of P5. Lighting in some areas are horrendous and flat, like in dorms. 

-Gameplay: Shift, Theurgy and combat menu's are amazing. But making MC's fusion spells and Aigis Orgia Mode theurgy is a stupid decision. Out of 18 fusion spells they "imported" only 7. Game is much easier even on merciless. Fuuka was remade and its decent Navigator now. She has okay spells that can be used outside of the combat. Her Oracle now only give you good things and don't affect enemies, personally don't like this change. For some reason, the removed talking with teammates and instead apt for P5 style of dungeon conversations.

-Tartarus: They changed it a lot. Each block is distinct and with different layout. Visually only first 2-3 blocks are decent, after they overcomplicate them. New catch up companion lvls are good addition. Arcanas are good and make grind less tedious. Monad doors are fine.

-Social Links: They are still strict, but game gives you new methods of gaining points. Now you can friendzone female SL and don't get others SL reversed, what a innovation. Male S.E.E.S members, Ryoji and Takaya got link episodes. Basically SL, but always progresses and available after story moments.

-Voice Acting: New voices are good and I don't have complain for them. Except for Koromaru. Its a guy making dog noises. Its fucking bad. Now every SL rank is voiced.

-Price and DLC: Those fuckers again cut content from the game and sell it as DLC. Price of 70 dollar is too much for this game

-Modernization: Game become much safer, as safe game about suicide and death can be. Violence scenes been change to be black screens or camera angle change. They added subtle modern political messages. Student dialogs about bad and "questionable"  things were cut

Amazing remake! Great additions to story, characters are more fleshed out, and introduces great new mechanics like theurgys and linked episodes. Makes the cast actually unique and usable in battle, unlike the original where you were kind of a one-man army relying on gacha spells from the side cast. So thankful they removed the tiredness mechanic during tartarus exploration, and thank god they kept the original ending to the story. Also so glad they kept all the crazy stuff in the game to keep with the theme of death like [spoiler] suicide, self-sacrifice, self-harm, and mental health issues [/spoiler] which i originally feared they would remove due to censorship.

I am really picky when it comes to remaking some of my most favourite games and as a SMT/Persona fan, I first started at Persona 3 FES so it holds a special place in my heart. I feel Atlus did an amazing job but I kinda wish they did more with it since it is a remake. The QoL implementation is great but unfortunately was lacking on some parts. 

Namely the persona fusing; having to buy personas from the compendium to see what they could be fused was a problem that was fixed in Soul Hackers 2, but not in this game? Genuinely confuses me on why they didn't carry over SH2 fusing. 

The addition of the great clock boosting two party members to your main character level is okay for what we got but why was it even a thing in the first place. We have shared EXP in Persona 5 Royal (a game that came out 4 years ago) that would've just been a better fix. But instead of levelling up your whole party, its only two. You can't skip Theurgies like you could with P5R Showdown and the auto-rush mode is not at all fast. I also played on Merciless difficulty and it is by far the most easiest game so far. 

The new additions to the Tartarus dungeon being Monad doors, are a genuine disappointment when it could've been something interesting to spice up the mundane dungeon crawl of Tartarus. I understand if the intent is to keep the authentic and original experience intact, which is why they didn't change the procedural generated floors but it is incredibly outdated now. I would've prefer a much more grander and unique dungeon for each block of Tartarus.

The lighting and some of the environments outside of Tartarus, aesthetically looks like something you see in the PS2 days, just with better texture. It's feels uninspired and dull but you can remedy the situation by changing the brightness settings by 3-4 notches down. The default settings really do not do the game justice in terms of tone and atmosphere, something that Persona 3 has over any of the other persona games. As for the music, I thought I was going to hate the newly "remastered" tracks but everything except Mass Destruction eventually grew on me but I guess you have the DLC for that (or your own music player)

Even if the review is mostly viewed as negative, it still is the same Persona 3 game that I grew up and known to love. The story is told the same and still has a deep cut on my adolescent years and even so to this day. And the new Linked Episodes is by far the best addition they ever added to the game. More content and screen time with all the characters that you know and love and it doesn't have anything to do with their Social Links. This is something that I want more of for the next game and more to come. As a long-time fan, the biggest positive that I can give to this particular game's version of P3 is the Linked Episode and the fully voiced Social Links event. Both JP and EN dub killed it, but if I had to choose, I would pick JP as it was a lot more closer to what I had imagine the NPCs sounding like. 

If you had played the original and still deciding if it is worth it, or even a new-comer. I suggest you start of with this. It's still a masterpiece back during 2006 and it still is in current year. I love Persona 3 to death, so the complaints that I have is something more akin to my precious child that I want it to do well.

The game feels like P5 when you are actually playing it, however the core story line is just the same compare to the original P3. Why would I buy something that feels like a combination of P3 and P5 while I can still play them separately on steam ( they even have FeMC story line for P3P which is something P3R does not have)? If they just release the game as a DLC for P5 it still will be totally reasonable. In that case, ATLUS still chose to spend years to remake the game and release it for 80 USD only for some cooler effects and graphics. Sorry I just don't get it.
I love this game

I'm going to write this from the perspective of someone who started with P5R, and didn't play any other persona game before or after. I haven't reached summer yet, which is when I hear the story picks up, but I figured I can put some simple thoughts here for now.

Pros: 
1. The game is absolutely gorgeous. The UI, water theming, all out attack kill screens, and more are just pure artistry. They even arguably surpass P5's equally insane UI. 

2. To nobody's surprise, the music is fucking amazing. So many songs just go WAY harder than they have to, but I appreciate it for doing so. The only bad thing they did was mess up Mass Destruction, which is the non ambush battle theme. 

3. The 3D models and animation are mindblowingly good, especially compared to P5R. The models all look really good, and all the in battle animations look incredibly fluid. Hitting an enemy's weak spot is one of my favorite looking things in any game ever (you just have to see it).

Cons:

1. Unlike P5R, social links don't give any unique abilities at certain ranks. They now serve only the purpose of increasing Persona exp gain when fusing with the same arcana. This alone in my opinion is a slight turn off in comparison to P5R, unless you enjoy the social links more than the dungeons. My personal complaint with it is that it makes hanging out feel pointless in the context of furthering the dungeon progress, instead wanting to do social stat raising tasks. Again, if you enjoy the actual social links over their respective abilities, then you will probably love this just as much. 

2. Tartarus. Tartarus is basically mementos but arguably a little worse. It has very little sense of progression, and every floor you go up just feels the same as the last. Instead of it feeling like you're actually getting any further, unlike in P5R, where you at least get a mementos map that shows you your rough progress. It also doesn't benefit from one of the features that mementos best benefited from, which is that it exists SEPERATELY from the main story dungeons (for the most part). As a result, the personalized "Palaces", which are one of P5's strongest suites, are completely absent. Of course, this too, is a matter of personal preference. 

TLDR; So far, it feels like the game looks really pretty, with some banger tunes, yet it suffers from some annoying gameplay mechanics.

By far the definitive edition of Persona 3. Some may say that the game is lacking elements of the previous version (Persona 3 Portable) and thus not be as happy with it, but honestly, for those looking for the authentic experience of Persona 3, you can't do any better than this. I had played the FES version before this, and a small bit of the Portable version, and I can say this is more like FES with a whole slew of improvements from Portable, as well as new Persona games, mixed in. 

With modern mechanics such as Skill Cards, Skill Acquisition choice when fusing, and of course the ability to control your entire party, the game feels more like Persona 3 if it were made today while keeping the plot and character development largely untouched (Only really changing mostly distasteful dialogue). The cutscenes are a major step up as well, even if a part of me does miss the old FMV style for certain scenes. The voice acting is, in my opinion, the biggest improvement the game made. Very rarely do I feel like a character has a weird delivery of a line, or a lack of understanding of the emotional weight of a scene. 

My playthrough took me about 80 hours. This was with me fastforwarding certain points simply due to knowing the general gist of the scene and wanting to hurry along to the next part (Skipping things like gossip or social stat upgrades). I didn't even complete every social link (I missed finishing 2), so if I had spent a bit more time, I probably could have gotten more done and played longer. Even so, less than 1 dollar per hour, to me, is well worth the price point if you like narrative JRPGs with dungeon crawling elements. 

Overall, I recommend Persona 3 to anyone willing to take the time to sit and play and experience the game. It's a lot of fun, and if you are like me, it'll leave you wanting even more. 9/10
It was one of the greatest stories in video games 18 years ago and it's still one of the greatest stories today.

Persona 3 was always better than the other games in my opinion. It just needed an overhaul with quality of life adjustments and this game did it pretty well. I do have a lot of issues still. Merciless should be Merciless for a reason and yet I was able to beat the entire game Solo using only Orpheus with no Grinding. If that is doable especially blind then Merciless is not hard enough. The main issue I have with the combat is the AI are not intelligent, occasionally there is a boss once or twice the entire game that acts differently but 99% of them just follow a pattern which makes them extremely easy to exploit and trivialises encounters where I clearly should have been outmatched. I dont understand why they did this as FES never had this problem and neither did Royal mostly. Another issue is locking certain fights hp bars by phases. If I can hit for 800 damage I expect the attack to do 800 damage, not do 70 and halt at the phase transition. Overall though the combat feels pretty smooth and satisfying to play like Royal but kept the core out what P3 was about.

Tartarus was great to explore, except Yabbashah which was confusing to navigate but that's more of a personal issue than a problem with the game itself. Like OG it still had that sense of an eternal climb to the top but managed to make arguably some of the worst looking areas from the original like Arqa into something very good.

The new VAs absolutely killed their roles, even Akihiko who's voice was very different still accurately portrayed his character well they all did an amazing job. The songs were amazing and its hard to pick between which is better, OG or Reload but Megaten games rarely miss when it comes to soundtracks so that's a given.

The story even after having played FES and Portable so many times was amazing and the additional scenes, dialogue and overall revamp of everything kept the game fresh and still got me to tear up. The cast feel like a proper group of actual friends and conversation flows nicely for the most part. P5 always had characters jumping in to say something that someone had just said and it drew out the game and got irritating after a while when Atlus way of trying to keep a character involved was to just make them spout out a random line of dialogue.

Even with all my issues with the game it is undoubtedly going to be my favourite game of 2024, nothing will come close to it. If you have the money to spare since it is pretty pricey definitely consider buying this. It's an amazing, accessible entry to the Persona series. 10/10

i first played p3fes back in summer 2019, and i was pretty ambivalent about it. for every thing i loved, there was some nitpick or strange design decision that held it back in some way. i ultimately came out of it thinking "the story was amazing, but the gameplay was such a slog". kinda the opposite of persona 5 to me where the story is just decent but the gameplay is fun.

welp, now that this remake exists, pretty much everything has been improved, and i can definitely say that this has all i want in a persona game. great story, gameplay is actually fun now, and the presentation is top notch.

my only real issues are the game balance (i played on hard mode, but it was still way too easy at points. theurgies are busted and should have been heavily nerfed), and the quirks from the original that passed down (some social links aren't good, some aspects of the story aren't amazing, strega is still kinda cringe).

characters were rewritten to be more accurate to the original japanese script, but i feel like that made some characters lose some of their spark. i.e. yukari is nicer, akihiko is less geeky and more obsessive with training (probably a result of them sticking to their flanderization), etc. i gotta say tho, i came out liking some characters a lot more in this version like koromaru, ken, and even takaya somehow. my lads junpei and aigis still peak tho !!

[u] [b]Symbolism and Plot  [/b][/u] Persona 3 handled heavy themes of mortality, loss, and the search for meaning in life extremely well. Everything ties back to the main message of the game perfectly. From the way that the characters summon their persona to character development (all of the SEES members had lost their close ones to death) to emphasize the message of the game. 

[u] [b]Color Theory: [/b][/u] The use of color to symbolize different themes and elements adds another layer of depth to the storytelling, providing visual cues that complement the narrative. Blue- mortality (makoto) , Red- past sin (SEES arm band, the glow of shadows) The gradual fading of color toward the end of the game representing the end. 

[u] [b]Character Development [/b][/u] The characters in the game undergo significant development, and their backgrounds are well fleshed-out compared to P5. I got so attached to most of the social link characters. All of them confronts their personal struggles and traumas to show that everyone is struggling, even a kid. This further highlights the message of the game, which is to overcome the fear of death/loss and find meaning in life.
