I kept telling myself this, but I cannot. Besides, Red Dead Redemption 2, the Persona series has brought me not only memories, but tears of joys as well. I first played P4G on PS5, even though I did not get all achievements, but I managed to almost finish the game twice, then I proceeded to play P5R on PS5 as well, and I got all of the achievements, which I am really proud of. Even though I love P5R gameplay and its plot was indeed creative and interesting, the one that really stucks in my mind is P4G's plot.

That's why I had high hope for P3R when it was announced, and I heard it is one of the best story in the series. And I have to admit, it delivered spectacularly. I even managed to get all achievement within 1st playthrough, but I still have not been able to defeat Elizabeth though. While I love the way they setup the final boss of P4G, this apocalypse setup for final battle, the theme, the plot, and the message, all of them are truly remarkable.

If you are a fan of JRPG, especially Persona 4 (Golden) and, especially, Persona 5 (Royal) for its gameplay, you are in for a treat!! It has Persona 3's plotline with P5R's new and optimized gameplay.

Holy shit what a game. So persona 3 is the last game I decided to play in the trilogy because after I finished persona 4 the remake for 3 got announced. This means that hey I don't have to play persona 3 in a remaster, but at the same time, I was afraid that I'll end up losing interest in the game. So for 8 whole months, I had to patiently wait for the game to come out, and on the night of its release, I instantly played it, and holy shit I was instantly captivated by it. Tbh the past few games I've played hadn't been able to have a grasp on me like how Persona 5 and Omori did, but in the first few hours of Persona 3 Reload I knew then and there that this was going to keep me occupied for most of February. Ngl I kind of expected this game to take up all of Febuary but it turns out I no lifed the game even more than I expected. Although there were some days when I wasn't able to play it, the thought of playing the game never left my mind (yes I do sound insane).   


Alright, that's enough yapping time to actually talk about the game. So the graphics were a huge upgrade from both Persona 3 (duh) and Persona 5. Although some of the outside areas, aka when you're on top of the school's roof, looked a bit choppy, but who cares? The new models were absolutely beautiful and I hope they keep this style or improve on it in Persona 6 when it finally comes out in the year 3014 after we get 500 more spin-offs jk. The music was an absolute bop and tbh it's better and more consistent than Persona 4 music, hey who knows maybe one day Atlus will release Persona 4 Goldener and the music will absolutely blow me away, but only time will tell. When it comes to the story Persona 3 is hands down the best in terms of story, which makes me really want to play the 3rd semester, but we'll have to wait for that DLC to come out, which who knows how long that'll take. There were way too many scenes that made me cry and feel depressed, and way too many scenes that gave me hope and happiness. The confidant's storys were really heartwarming, especially the hanged man arcana. Also of course when it comes to Persona games, I don't really care too much for the combat, I mainly care about being able to hang out with the buds and god did the game delivered in that aspect, the fact that all of the characters had little hangout events made the game 10x more enjoyable compared to Persona 5, like bro it's so wholesome to watch Amada learn how to make coffee, and it's even more wholesome brushing Korumaru's fur. Just those little moments, really makes the game perfect and I hope they'll add this in Persona 6. Also even though I said that I didn't care too much for the combat, Persona 3 Reload is the first game where I took the combat and its mechanics seriously, I had a blast creating the most op Johanna that ever existed and one punching all of my enemies and bosses, and then learning how satisfying it is to create a persona out of several other personas.   


Tbh when it comes to criticism, it's really hard to find any. I guess I'm kind of disappointed that they didn't add the 3rd semester to the Reload, like I know that not everyone is a fan of it, but still, I NEED MORE CONTENT PLSSSSSSS!!! When it comes to persona games my number one gripe is that the games always feel too short, even though the game isn't short, but I want more content >:(  Also, this just crossed my mind, but I guess another gripe I have for the game is that it felt too easy, like even though I was using a dlc persona, I was having an easy time beating all of the bosses wayyy before I got Johanna, maybe it's just me getting overall better at jrpgs, but I swear that Persona 5 Royal's end game felt hard, and Persona 4 Golden just felt hard in general. Who knows, maybe I just grew a brain after playing several other Jrpgs after Persona 5 and Persona 4.   


Welp that's all I have to say about this game, this game was a roller coaster of emotions and I would heavily recommend that everyone on this planet to go and play this game. Also, I spent like 90 dollars on this game and it was totally worth it, I don't care what anyone else says.

First I'll say I only downvote out of protest, if you've never played P3 then you may as well play this. In some ways it's improved, but in SO MANY WAYS this game has lost its way, not even including the ESG propaganda that has found its way into the game. I will start with what I like.

I like that there is more to do. Playing the original game if you did everything perfectly, not likely in your first play through,  then you had a lot of days where you just went to bed. A lot has been added to fill in your time, and it's for the most part well done. I would like even more of this. Also a lot of things now adds to your social skills so you have far less grinding and progress more naturally in your traits. I like the additions of the monad doors, and the final secret boss fight. I like the improved graphics and more voice acted lines.

Now for what I dislike. THE INTRO far starters. My GOODNESS anyone and everyone start a new game for the original P3 and watch it. THAT intro was epic, this one is sterile. It has NO FEELING AT ALL. In the original Yukari doesn't say a word, and yet you are in suspense. The music adds to the whole vibe of the situation and tension builds. Then you meet her later and that intro matters. You don't know what she was doing, you don't know what she was going through and when you get to the roof it has a greater impact. This goes for the ENTIRE story as a whole. 

In the original Persona 3 game every vibe of the game is filled with depression, pending doom, darkness. You feel tension building until it reaches a crescendo at the end of the game. THIS GAME it plays the same story, but it's in monotone. You do not vibe with P3R. The story may be "good" but it is portrayed poorly. So original game had this line in the beginning that was changed, I can only imagine to stroke someone's ego. It went like this 

"Time never waits. It delivers all equally to the same end. You,who wish to safeguard the future, however limited it may be... you will be given one year; go forth without falter, with your heart as your guide..." Why change this? It seems for the sole purpose to take the line "time waits for no man" and change it to "time waits for no one." Don't be flippin pretentious. The original writing was fine. 

Now next up how they changed tartarus. I like to play solo, and exploring each floor in any persona game is just a pain. What does this mean? Well in the original p3 your party was useful. When you want to solo you send them to search the floor and fight on their own. Getting them to be stronger paid off, and when they or you couldn't handle a battle you had more empathy for them because they were actually being useful and could get hurt. The exhaustion system comes into play here too it also made you want to take care of your team and you had to make the most of each visit to tartarus.

ON THE SUBJECT OF TARTARUS! THE ORIGINAL WAS LEAGUES BETTER! Each floor acted as a maze, this one was easy just to rush from floor to floor, and you never have to fear the reaper because there's no way you'll accidentally run into him. While graphics may improve once again the vibe of the game is lost both mechanically and visually. Also what's the deal with "rush" it does not "rush" anything. There is no reason if you're over leveled for an enemy that attacking them outside of combat doesn't straight up defeat them giving you the rewards. 

Then do I need to get into the music. The music in the remake is TRASH. 

Alright, going to just mention one last thing the did that follows in the destroyed vibe of the game. Watch the final boss fight side by side between P3 and P3R. You will see which one feels better. 

So should you get this game...sure. It is nice to not have to have an old playstation or to use an emulator to play the game, and some of the added content is nice, However we can build a community project to add these features to the original P3 and when that happens there is no reason to play p3R. 

They could have done better, they should have done better, they should have stayed true to the original vision of the game instead of giving it the low quality of modernity treatment.

This game is so amazing that I wanted to give a serious review for this game. Luckily, I played this game alongside my friend who is an OG Persona fan and played the original P3 unlike me who is fairly new to the franchise and has only played 5 and 4. This review will be made from both of our perspectives. I will be writing down my friends perspective based off of words he gave me and any criticisms he had about the game. My perspective will include a lot of comparing to P5R as that's my base understanding of Persona games at this point in time.

New Player: I've always loved that Persona games could get me to smile and giggle because of the nonsensical dialogue in one moment to bringing me to the lowest point of my life in the next. This game in no exception. Whether it was a social link or a story event there were many moments like this. This games story has definitely resonated with me more than Persona 5 and I haven't even finished it at the time of this review. This game was visually stunning and is definitely a step up from P5R. I tried playing P5R after a few hours of P3R and couldn't believe the shift in quality. It's much more apparent that you think. Game play-wise, I didn't find much difference between P3R and P5R except for a few differences. Those differences being the shuffle-time over negotiations, and various affinity changes. It's no P4G shuffle time but it still trumps negotiations and the fact that it was left up to dialogue choices unless you had a specific perk from a confidant. There's also the Theurgy which in my eyes are like showtime moves from P5R except they're less random. I have to say, I really do like that each team member has their own base physical element. It allows for more interesting team compositions compared to P5R where I kind of just threw together a team because I wanted a certain perk from confidants or because I liked the character. I played the game on Hard mode and it caused me to think a lot more about things like that as well as what kind of personas I should be using as well. At some point in the game I was able to basically abuse the fusion system and inherit all of the skill I wanted onto one persona with a high STR or MAG stat and nuke enemies. However, I stilled faced my fair share of difficult fights and had to restart my Tartarus run or main boss fights. Eventually I was able to also abuse the rarity fortunes and grind money and exp in Tartarus as well as healing items, sp items, and twilight fragments. Outside of combat Social links, although not having the perk system that confidants did, I found more enriching than in P5R. Characters where much more memorable and likable with the setting being a bit more realistic. Some characters that to my knowledge didn't have social links in the original and still don't either now have hangout events that sort of adapt the perk system from confidants by allowing for buffs in combat or for theurgies. Outside of gameplay, the story was very interesting. The cast was really good in my opinion and there were some scenes where I felt their deliveries carried the entire emotion of the scene. So a huge compliment to them. I know that pretty much all persona games have unrealistic settings as it's a supernatural, superpower, fantasy situation but compared to P5R the story felt more coherent. The story felt a lot less all over the place while still keeping it's fair share of mystery. I know that the beauty of P5's story is that it was like a puzzle you had to piece together but it honestly got annoying having to stop after main story segment and select vague dialogue options because the context was hidden to you. It lead to a greater conclusion but caused a clunky mid-game. My last thing I have to say about P3R is that it's BGM is phenomenal. One of the key factors as to why I was so giddy all the time while playing was due to the incredible soundtrack. Although I have a select few in P5R that I still find incredible today, I think that overall P3R has better music.

The review from here on will be words I received from my friend about the game. He didn't talk so much about combat as it wasn't exactly what he was paying attention to when observing my game play.

OG Player: I love Persona and Persona 3 is one of my favorite games of all time. I was excited to see this game being remade but was interested to see what they had done or changed. I noticed that the game was way more vibrant and colorful compared to the original which is nice and it made the game feel like a quality game but it took away from the charm that the original had. The saturated colors of the original felt like it fit the theme of the game more and set the mood better. Aside from that, it was cool to see modern models and artwork of the characters I love. The social links are pretty much the same, noticed a few new things that came with the visuals such as a character cut-out for the Hermit S.L. I really enjoy the introduction of the hangout feature as it allows for people to really become attached to some of the other team members who lack social links. I'm not sure if they repurposed content from the FEMC content but it still includes a storyline and character arc for each team member. I wasn't too fond of the new voice actors at first but they grew on me overtime. Especially Junpei as I though the new VA didn't sound that much like the original. I also found the delivery of lines to be not as impactful such as the chairman. Although his jokes aren't supposed to be funny the delivery in the original at least gave me a chuckle. When it comes to the BGM I noticed a few changes. The opening to the game has changed and although full moon, full life is good. Burn my Dread stands on top. I also noticed that some BGM is the same but altered. for example, the dorm BGM sounds almost like a remix of the original. It's not bad but it's also not the same. Which was my overall POV on the game.

Overall, this is a good Persona game none the less. To OG players, it might be disappointing to see that not much has changed aside from some quality of life aspects and visual changes. the size of areas are the same meaning this game is smaller in scale to Persona 5. So is it worth the $70 pricetag? Well, to newer players yes. This is a complete experience for blind players like me no matter if the game is smaller or shorter than P5R. The game has an expected playtime of 50 hrs for the main story but I'm not even done and have over that amount. Of course because I've been entangled in the games side content. For older players, it's still a refreshing experience. The changes made are enough that it doesn't just feel like you're just playing through the original again. If the main factor that is driving away you OG players is the pricetag. Then you're best bet is to wait for a sale.
Every Persona game I have played has been nothing short of a work of art. from the gameplay to the story and its themes. this game is incredible.
An almost 1:1 Remake of the Original, this is the definitive way to experience Persona 3

Persona 3 Reload  is one of the best games I've ever had the miracle of playing in my entire life, rivaled only by the likes of paper mario. Everything from the superb storytelling(where it's plentiful),  beautifully written characters and delightfully collected story-line with faithful fan-service catering to intellectuals and adults.


On the Real, Persona 3 Reload fixes the flaws that the OG had and revamps its gameplay for a more complete experience. The gameplay can be a bit grindy and repetitive at times, but I'd say that's more towards the end game where most of the things you should be doing are already done.  If it wasn't for it's story, Persona 3 Reload would be an easy 7/10, but it's saving grace is its STORY. This game takes risks that future Persona games are afraid to take, all the while setting the design for it's two future games in the series. It takes a much deeper look into human psychology and the concept of death that haunts everyone. The characters do yap alot in this game, but there are plenty of meaningful conversations to be read.  Overall Persona 3 Reload is a strong 8/10.
If you don't like this remaster I have no words for you, Stupei.

As the newest release to the Persona series, P3R has the most polished gameplay, graphics, and music but struggles a bit on the more static portions: its story, main cast, and social links. The main story and big bosses did not feel that interesting compared to the other entries in the series, and some of the characters were really unlikable which made hangouts quite tedious sometimes. But, P3R did also have some of the most memorable characters I have seen in the series, notably: Aigis, Elizabeth, Kamiki, and Tanaka. Tartarus was also less tedious than Mementos but the lack of palaces or just intentional area design did make it a bit stale after so many floors. P3R also lacks of the follow up story DLC which many would say is essential to the themes presented throughout the game. I was still satisfied with the ending but did find it a bit confusing contextually. Although this remake does look and play amazing, I would still suggest newcomers to the series start at Persona 5 Royal instead and work your way backwards to Reload. It will help you appreciate both the other games in the series and the strong points of P3R that will hopefully carry forward into Persona 6.

Persona 3 is one of my favourite games of all time and I've waited so long for a remake that it kind of feels surreal to finally have one.
It improves so many aspects of the old 2006 release, bringing it in line with modern game design aspects, mainly to Persona 5.

For anyone not having played Persona 3 at all: Keep in mind that this game is very heavily leaning into its two main gameplay loops: Dungeon crawling and school activities / hanging out with people in your free time. If you for example hate dungeon crawling, I would not advise to buy this as you spend a lot of time in Tartarus. It was vastly improved compared to the original Tartarus, but it's still a lot if you are not expecting this kind of gameplay.

The good:
* One of my favourite stories/settings of all time
* Graphics are gorgeous
* Great sound design and voices
* Modern gameplay, A LOT of QoL improvements
* A vastly improved Tartarus experience

The not-so-good:
* OST is hit or miss - some tracks (new and old) are banger, while others are meh compared to their old versions
* Some outdated gameplay elements were left in, like having a Game Over as soon as the main character dies in combat
* No The Answer (post story arc) and no female main character, but maybe those will be added via DLC

All in all, if you are a fan of JRPGs with great stories and like dungeon crawling mixed with leisure activities, then you are in for one hell of a ride here.
baby baby baby baby

Persona 3 Reloaded, an updated version of the beloved JRPG classic, breathes new life into the iconic title while preserving the essence of what made the original so memorable. With revamped visuals, enhanced gameplay mechanics, and additional content, Persona 3 Reloaded offers both longtime fans and newcomers a compelling journey into the depths of the Dark Hour.

Graphically, Persona 3 Reloaded shines with its updated visuals that bring the game into the modern era. Character models, environments, and UI elements have been given a fresh coat of paint, resulting in a more polished and visually appealing experience. The vibrant colors, stylish character designs, and attention to detail contribute to the game's immersive world, enhancing the sense of immersion and atmosphere.

Gameplay improvements in Persona 3 Reloaded provide a more streamlined and accessible experience while retaining the strategic depth that defines the Persona series. Combat mechanics have been refined to offer smoother and more responsive gameplay, making battles feel more engaging and dynamic. The addition of quality-of-life features, such as fast travel options and improved party management, reduces tediousness and enhances the overall flow of the game.

One of the highlights of Persona 3 Reloaded is the expanded content that adds depth and replay value to the experience. New social links, story events, and gameplay mechanics enrich the game's narrative and character development, allowing players to forge deeper connections with the inhabitants of the game world. The inclusion of additional personas, skills, and dungeons provides fresh challenges for veterans while offering new players a wealth of content to explore.

The audio design in Persona 3 Reloaded remains as exceptional as ever, with a memorable soundtrack that perfectly complements the game's themes and atmosphere. The haunting melodies, upbeat tunes, and atmospheric sound effects contribute to the immersive experience, drawing players further into the world of Persona 3. Voice acting, a hallmark of the series, is well-executed, bringing the characters to life with emotion and authenticity.

Despite its many improvements, Persona 3 Reloaded is not without its flaws. Some may find that certain aspects of the game, such as the dated dungeon design and repetitive nature of Tartarus exploration, feel somewhat antiquated compared to more recent entries in the series. Additionally, the game's pacing can be uneven at times, with periods of intense action interspersed with slower, more dialogue-heavy segments.

In conclusion, Persona 3 Reloaded is a worthy reimagining of a classic JRPG that revitalizes the original experience for a new generation of players. With its updated visuals, refined gameplay mechanics, and expanded content, the game offers a compelling journey into the mysterious world of Persona. Whether you're a longtime fan of the series or a newcomer looking to experience a timeless classic, Persona 3 Reloaded delivers a captivating adventure filled with memorable characters, engaging gameplay, and emotional storytelling. Having played all of the other iterations of Persona 3, Reload is a retread of familiar ground with updated graphics, UI, etc. in Unreal 4. While the overall story remains the same, there are many small interactions and systems added to the experience to improve the smoothness of the journey. 

The main story additions that stuck out during my playthrough were:

-[b] Link Episodes [/b]: These provide additional interactions with your SEES squad mates individually to highlight their backstories and things they're going through at different points in the main story. A welcome addition that helps to further flesh out characters who don't have a dedicated social link for the male protagonist.
-[b] Study sessions before exams [/b]: Provide additional interactions to highlight chemistry between characters and the squad as a whole. Another welcome addition that shows it's strength especially after important events in the story, where the characters can come together as a group to bond.
-[b] New voice cast [/b]: One of the things I was more apprehensive with going into Reload, this worry turned out to be mostly unfounded. Some of the new casting choices that I particularly liked were [spoiler] Mitsuru, Junpei, Fuuka, Aigis, Yuko, Chidori, etc. [/spoiler]

The main overworld system additions that stuck out were:

-[b] Text messages [/b]: These provide an easy way to check what is available to do during the current day. These also provide additional interaction with your various social links and help to bring out more of their personality. 
-[b] Rewind [/b]: A quality of life feature that allows you to rewind to a certain day instead of reloading a save. Convenient for minmaxing or amending mistakes. Overall unnecessary, but still useful.

The main combat and Tartarus additions that stuck out were:

-[b] Theurgy [/b]: New ultimate-like attacks used by building your theury gauge during combat. Each character has a diffferent way to charge their gauge (using buffs, using physical attacks, getting critical hits, etc.). The animations are flashy and true to character. These feel very strong (at least on hard difficulty) and shave a lot of difficulty off of some encounters. 
-[b] Navigator abilities [/b]: Additional abilities to use during exploration (IE distressing enemies, providing def/spd buffs, providing an escape route, etc.). This also extends to combat where your full-scan is now activated on the same turn you use it, but you need to wait one full round before you can use it. Your navigator also has a theurgy gauge. All of these help to make that character feel more like a member of the team who is actively doing things.
-[b] Tartarus exploration changes [/b]: Locked chests, breakable pieces of the environment, a sprint key for the protagonist, Monad doors/passages, dark floors, etc. have been added to make exploration feel more interactive. Instead of running through a randomly generated terrain, maybe killing some shadows, and then going up the stairs...you are now doing that with some extra distractions in between to make it feel less monotonous. 
-[b] Great clock [/b]: A catchup mechanic that allows your teammates who you might not have used in a while to instantly catch up to you in levels. Can only be used after finding it on a floor and after using a twilight fragment to open a locked chest. Another welcome quality of life addition so you don't have to do as much monotonous grinding (grinding is largely invalidated anyways if you want to cheese by turning on peaceful difficulty to farm the reaper).
-[b] Shuffle time [/b]: Instead of keeping shuffle time the same, you will now be able to see all of the cards without playing the memory game. Now the major arcana cards have all been added to the cards in shuffle time, each unlocked with progressing the story or completing monad passages. These have different large effects (stat buffs, ability to pick extra cards in shuffle time, etc.) that help to make the Tartarus experience smoother. 

Overall, the updated Persona 3 experience was still incredibly enjoyable. As mentioned prior, it is the same story with additional character interactions and combat that doesn't make you want to contract apathy syndrome. The main issue I have with this iteration is the $70.00 USD price tag, with eventual DLC that will bump it up even more if it is The Answer. This would be more understandable if it were [i] the [/i] definitive way to play Persona 3, but the overall experience is still split between Portable with Reload replacing FES if The Answer is released as DLC. It's up to you to decide if the updated engine, additional character interactions, combat changes, and new voice cast is worth that price tag.

Fantastic game, a lot of care went into preserving and improving on what made the original so special to so many people with this remake. It's my favorite story of the series and holds a lot of meaning in how the game impacted me after I was exposed to it and I appreciate all of the work that was invested into it. The only issue I can have of this game is the lack of Male party member Social Links which was a bit of a letdown when P4 and P5 both have it, it feels like a missed opportunity when remaking the game. The Female party member Social Links being pretty late into the game kind of makes it a bit obvious for this as well since there isn't anyone on your team you can spend time with until later in the game, so having Male SL's would have made the issue a little less glaring; regardless, this game is amazing and will be replaying it countless times especially if The Answer DLC does actually release later on.

Let me get this out of the  away. Persona 3 has the best story but the game itself has many flaws and in my opinion didn't take enough from the newer persona games. This review isn't meant for people who believe story negates all the flaws within the game play itself. This review will mainly focus on the negatives because everyone else  has spoken on the positives.

Social System.
 Persona 3 has some of the worst social links in the series with Kenji, The Gourmet King, The Track Team manager and a few more. Another thing that really sucks about the social links in this game is not being able to have a single one with any of your male teammates. They attempted to corrected this with "Linked Episodes' which are just worse social links. This could have been done much better if they had just replaced some social links such as  Kenjis. I know they wanted to stay true to the original  and if so they could have just added the female route that corrects almost all of these issues within the social system.

The Combat
The combat for me was a huge letdown, I had hoped they would have added more from royal, but they added a worse baton pass that was useless in most fights, a one shot ability, and seemingly making magic way weaker than physical skills. On my first fight with the reaper I wanted to use this new theurgy I had just unlocked. It was stated to be the "Ultimate" attack little did I know they really did mean it. I ended up one shotting the reaper who I had been looking forward to fight my whole play through. It seems like every new persona game just makes it their goal to make the reaper seem like a joke compared to how he used to be.

The Fusion System
The fusion system stayed the same as it was in the original, but more easier than before, with it all being automatic.  I wish they had added the newer fusion mechanics from royal/golden instead of just making it simpler.

Tartarus
Tartarus in reload is much easier compared to the original and seemingly more boring because of that. I completed it all in one day each time with little to no effort and became bored of it pretty fast. I was pretty disappointed that the reaper was not allowed to spawn in the first two blocks, because in my opinion that is when the game is the hardest and you have the highest chance of taking enough time for him to  actually spawn, because of this he never showed up in my play through until I actually waited for him which took way too long. Still though the music is still amazing and the design for each block was perfect making it easier to push through the later floors.

Overall I still believe the game was very good but definitely not worth 70 dollars USD. If I was to point someone towards their first persona game, it would not be this, it would be royal. Especially because we will most likely get "The Answer" as some overpriced DLC or get a royal edition for the game. If you really wanna see the story of Persona 3 just go watch the movie or watch someone else play.

This is definitely worth the buy, and deserves to be GOTY, as I'm sure not many games will live up to the experience that this game gave me.

As a disclaimer, I never played the original P3, Portable, or FES prior to playing Reload. And my only exposure to Persona prior to this was playing Persona 5 Royal two years ago. So this was my first time with the Persona 3 experience. When comparing Persona 3 to Persona 5, I'll admit I think the gameplay of Persona 5 was slightly better, and definitely had more flair. But the story, characters, and structure of Persona 3 hit me like a truck in a way I was not prepared for. 

Obviously I won't spoil the story elements, but despite feeling like the game had a slow start when I first started playing, I found myself intrigued by how well everything connected in the end, even seemingly isolated events. The story just builds on itself. I consider myself a fairly stoic person. I very much internalize my feelings, so even when experiencing intense emotion, I don't outwardly express them. But Persona 3 put actual tears in my eyes at least 3 times. That's a feat that doesn't happen often in any game. 

What most surprised me was the characters. Again, no spoilers, but I'm very used to characters in all JRPGs having their character arc and just being "done".  But in Persona 3, it really felt like characters developed throughout the entire game, even those you got early. I will say that I think the voice actors all nailed the roles for each and every character. I know there was some debate about characters being recast from the OG, but in terms of viewing the game on its own, I think every VA absolutely nailed it with their deliveries.

True to Persona fashion, you build your relationships with characters, both party members and NPCs. Interesting to note that the male party members don't have social links but still have hangout episodes which are arguably just as valuable for character development. My only criticism about social links is that the party member social links are very back-loaded by only really being fully accessible in the 2nd half of the game. But even that has narrative significance in the sense of building those relationships over the game. 

Gameplay-wise, although I did say that I slightly prefer P5, the game is still classic turn based fun with modern QoL. The concept is familiar; your Personas determine your abilities and stats, with the MC having multiple Personas and your party having one each. Hitting a weakness will knock down an enemy, and knocking down all enemies triggers an all out attack for big damage. You get an extra turn per knockdown, and can pass your turn to another party member after a knockdown to specifically target weaknesses. What sets P3's gameplay apart from P5 is Theurgy, a mid-game "super move" that all party members have, and most ignore resistances/immunities. Considering different party members have different conditions for charging Theurgy, it keeps the strategy fresh. 

Much of Persona 3's gameplay takes place in Tartarus, which is an extremely long dungeon that you progress through during the game, with each border to the next segment being gated by game progression. It was notorious in the OG, but in the remake, it's not bad! I will mention that it sometimes suffers from some minor frame drops, not to the extent of chugging, but Tartarus's visuals effects do slow down the game somewhat on occasion. 

Now, I'm sure there's one big question and that question is length. Persona 5 was infamously long after all, so how does Persona 3 compare? I beat the game at 76 hours, so I'd say an average is about 80. It's long, but not obscenely so like P5, so it's more reasonable. 

And of course, the music slaps. While music is subjective and I know some people prefer the OG songs, every song I heard did a good job evoking the desired emotion, whether it be dread, hype, or depression. The music lives rent free in my mind at all times. 

Overall, I say this very rarely, but this game was a 10/10 for me personally. Will it be for everyone? Maybe not. But for any lover of RPGs, Persona games, or just stories with well written characters, Persona 3 Reload is a must play. I absolutely adore this game.

Good, but it's not the definitive version like some others claim. It's the version I'll most likely replay again and again, but it's not what I'd call 'definitive. I don't feel like there's ever gonna be a definitive edition of P3. 

I enjoy it, and am on my second playthrough rn (my first was on game pass), and I think in terms of gameplay it's a strong update. The dub cast, if youre familiar with the old, takes some getting used to, but I think the end product is overall much better. Believe it or not, a dub made 20 years after the initial game's release is better, who could have thought.

it does face some modern megaten-isms that mess with the balance of the core game, though, and I think it suffers there. Theurgy gets out of control by the end of the game. I don't think you should be able to charge or concentrate theurgies because of the sheer damage it can dump out, or maybe they just shouldn't be able to crit. One shotting gatekeeper bosses is fun at first, but then you realise youre doing it to every gatekeeper. Stacking crit is obscenely strong for most of the main game and very little outside of the superboss will really challenge you.

it also loses a lot of the art design from the original title. Now, let me preface this by saying that I think P3 does some very pretty things with it's UI, and yes, it does have a very nice menu. However, the complete loss of the old art style for anime cutscenes is an honest travesty, the new p5-esque style of cutscenes are a lot blander. They look fine, but when compared to the old one, there's an atmosphere that is completely lost on this game. It's like the life has been drained out of it, replaced with something that is, on the surface, prettier because it's in HD. 

Just compare the awakening scene from the original title to the awakening scene in this, that is the best example of what I mean.

I also kind of wish that it changed more about P3. November and December are still very dead months that grind the pacing to a halt, There are some old plot holes that were in the original script that remain even now, even some errors that were in the original translation that have remained unfixed. Also why is the Hermit link still like that? Please stop that, Atlus. Why does every modern persona game need a resident groomer character, the PS1 titles didn't need that. 

All in all, it's good. My expectations were low, and I'm happy to be wrong. I wish it changed more things in some areas, I wish it didn't change some others, but the full package is a solid experience that I had a lot of fun with.

[h1] PERSONA 3 RELOAD: A GOLDEN STANDARD IN JRPGs [/h1]

Persona 5 was my first experience with the MegaTen franchise back in 2017 and I instantly fell in love with it. Naturally, after completing the game, I tried my hand at the earlier entries; starting with Persona 3. The story really piqued my interest and I was really excited to get back to fusing Demons in the Velvet Room. However, I found it hard to keep engaging with the game due to it's archaic systems and graphics, so I dropped it about 3 months into the game's school year.

Fastforward 7 years later, I picked it back up with Persona 3 Reload and the game is astounding. From what I've played the plot seems pretty intact and faithful to the original source material. Although, the pacing early on is a bit slow and sometimes story elements are a bit all over the place, the game really finds its groove during the month of July. Every Social Link is unique and exposes the protagonist to their daily struggles. I especially loved The Sun Arcana Social Link and his journey to come to terms with his own fleeting mortality. Every one of them is very impactful and a real joy to experience.

On a another note, the new dynamic UI elements really help to liven the game up and bring it to par with Person 5's UI design, all while giving it it's own unique and distinct flair. The sound design is also on point by reorchestrating the original tracks that made the game special and by adding some new one's into the mix. The new "It's Going Down Now", "Color your Night" and the remixed version of "Changing Seasons" particularly stand out. In my eyes, the Persona soundtracks still stand leagues above the rest.

Combat is still amazing with the Press Turn/1 More system that keeps turn based battles fast paced and engaging all while rewarding strategic thinking. There's not a lot more to say on the matter.

In short, Persona 3 Reload is nothing short of a masterpiece. With an amazing visual style, great combat, fantastic soundtrack and a moving story to boot, it certainly holds a very special place in my heart and might as well have cemented itself as my new favorite game in the franchise.

Review based on achieving 100% of the game's content.

My first contact with the Persona franchise was through Persona 3 Portable. It quickly became one of my favorite games, prompting me to play the other titles in the series.
Did Atlus do a good job with Persona 3 Reload? Absolutely. Atlus did an excellent job for Persona 3 fans, enhancing what was already nearly perfect.

The story and characters are the same. Almost nothing has been altered.
If you think you would miss the female protagonist, mainly because of her social links, they added the "Linked Episodes"  that work like a social link without arcana and don't need to worry about dialogue choices. The characters that have the linked Episodes are Junpei, Akihiko, Koromaru, Shinjiro and Ken. Some new content around the city to facilitate your life and progressions with Social links and Social Stats 

The combat and Tartarus are great and enjoyable. My issue with the Original Game was that Tartarus became boring after a few hours due to the lack of variety in the content and the similarity of each floor. In Persona 3 Reload, the floors and the blocks are quite "unique" and with new content added. "Monad Doors" is where you can go to defeat a boss and get rewards. They also removed Margaret from the game and her challenges. The game now has the "Shift" mechanic, it is like Baton Pass from Persona 5.

The voice cast is fantastic, and the already good OST is even better. I enjoy the Persona game OSTs, especially the Persona 3 original soundtrack. However, everything sounds perfect here. I had the pleasure of listening to one of the best game soundtracks.

If you enjoyed Persona 3 or other games in the series and want to play this title but are hesitant to pay a high price for it, I believe Persona 3 Reloaded is worth every penny.

This game is an amazing remaster of the original P3. Everything about this game is amazing, and even having fully voiced confidants is a nice touch, The gameplay and graphics are good too. I would recommend this to anyone who likes JRPGS.

I loved the original P3, including Fes and Portable. I was skeptical at first since the Reload versions of previous songs weren't as good as the original, but I'm glad to say, my expectations are blown out of the water! This game is a true remake of the original P3 and added some elements from Fes and Portable to make the ultimate Persona 3 experience. It has the hard difficulty, great characters, and the best Persona story, in my opinion, all in this amazing remake. Did I mention that it has a BANGER soundtrack? Because it does! From songs like "Color Your Night", to "It's Going Down Now", all the original music is AMAZING! However, some of the Reload songs, remix's of the old songs, aren't as good as the original like "Mass Destruction". It will take some getting used to, especially if you are really used to the old songs, but there are some good Reload songs as well like "Changing Seasons". It really comes down to just getting used to them.  If you are a fan of the original P3, are new to P3, or just want to try out a JRPG, I could not recommend this game enough. After all, I spent almost 130 hours 100%ing the game lol. 9/10! Now I just hope that Atlus doesn't screw up The Answer, but only time will tell until we get "The Answer" to that question.

Atlus has always had a bit of a mixed track record in regards to their remakes and updated re-releases,
but Persona 3 Reload does a good job of balancing the old with the new while keeping the original feel and mood mostly intact.

In terms of gameplay and visuals, it's improvements all around. The main criticism you can level here is that it's too easy to become overpowered. That's sort of an Atlus trademark, though, and it's plenty fun regardless.

Script-wise, I think the localizers need better proofreading and editing, as there were times where typos, missing words and excessive repetition were notable. The original Persona 3 was very competently handled, so these errors do stick out.
Interestingly enough, this is an issue in Persona 5 as well, and I'm not sure what's going on there. It's definitely my main critique, because it leaves some of the new scenes feeling disjointed, and I think the VA direction suffered as well because of this.

The new voice actors themselves do a great job, though. By and large, they're as good as the originals, and Akihiko's in particular grew on me. If you're as detail-obsessed as I am, though, you'll have to get used to differences in delivery. My biggest complaint here is the aforementioned direction, and that the volume mixing on some actors is iffy. I'd imagine whoever worked with Junpei's lines wasn't having a good day?

Since I touched on the new content - there's really quite a bit of it. Nighttime is significantly expanded in particular, with both Tartarus having more depth to it and the actual social activities you can do at night being much wider. 
It builds upon the original game's strengths in scope by adding even more on top, and the dorm is livelier than ever.

The remixes of old music tracks are a bit of a mixed bag, with some being near-identical and others being slight downgrades or shifts in mood.
However, the original, new music tracks are complete slam-dunks across the board.

As someone who's played every other version of this game multiple times - if you're considering this as your introduction to Persona in general, I think this is a great place to start. 
It's also a competent retooling of Persona 3 itself and plays more smoothly than every other Persona game before it, with immense quality of life uplifts across the board. I have my nitpicks and qualms about it (animation speedup in combat when, Atlus?), but I'd give it a 8.5-9/10 overall.

I don't normally bother with reviews, but atlus decided to remake my favorite game of all time so I felt like I owe it to the game lol. Maybe I should reword that - a remake of my 2nd favorite game of all time, because atlus may have dethroned it! 

tl;dr at foot of review ;)

So I'm an avid fan of the original persona 3 for ps2. I absolutely loved the story, characters, and gameplay. Everything blended together amazingly for an experience like no other and I fell in love with it.
To say that atlus has outdone themselves for this remake would be a huge understatement. Every upgrade/addition made to the game is a positive 1.
I'll start off by clearing up that persona 3 ps2's version of tartarus (the central dungeon of the game) could be a real grind to get through. It was pretty samey and could get on many players nerves after while, especially towards the end of the game. Well somehow, someway, the crazy employees at atlus managed to fix tartarus! And not by a little bit, or by changing the vision of it entirely. I deeply respect them for sticking to the original vision of pre-generated floors to climb, while still adding in so many features that make tartarus a genuinely fun and engaging experience.
In addition to standard dungeon crawling, the persona series is famous for it's combination of social sim aspects and dungeon crawling. Persona 3 was the trailblazer that began that trend, and it changed the series. Social links (events spent with the friends you make in the game) are now fully voiced which is huge for the series. Now all the sad moments hit even harder than ever lol. Character writing is the exact same as it used to be too. 
On that note, I'm also very happy atlus stuck to their guns and didn't tone down the story whatsoever. I was a little worried that they may tone down the story to try and suit modern audiences, but I'm very happy to say that the story is exactly the same as I remember it, and I absolutely love it! In fact, with all-new added scenes and events that further develop characters who needed that development in the ps2 game, I can honestly say the story is the best its ever been! Some lines have also been reworded to make more literal sense, and all of them were for the better.
Said characters now feel fully realised, and the player incentive to bond with your allies is strong. Any new scenes are also very faithful to the original characters, and fit seamlessly within the narrative. The new character models look stunning, and blow me away every time I see them, in school life and combat.
The UI is as great as any modern atlus release, balancing smoothness, style, and functionality without overwhelming the player. The water motif used throughout the menus is as aesthetically pleasing as these menus can get, and every little detail has so much thought put into it. 
As expected with any atlus game in general, the soundtrack is simply amazing as always. Persona 3 is arguably the game that began the trend of great music in the series, with it alongside persona 4 being the reason the sound concerts exist. The tracks taken from the original game are as great as before. The remade songs are a little bit mixed, but mostly positive for me. I loved the majority of the new songs, and even prefer some over the originals now (i.e changing seasons -reload-). What about the new tracks? Well rest assured they don't disappoint, as they are all simply catchy and fantastic. Lotus juice, the man behind the rapping in many songs, is much more prominent in reload over the original, and sounds even better than he used to back in 2006! I admit I do miss yumi kawamura, the vocalist for those original games for the male mc, but azumi takahashi does an amazing job too.

The only issue I have with persona 3 reload is the lack of the answer and female protagonist. The answer, though not integral to the experience, is an addition that helps develop the main cast and conclude their character arcs upon the aftermath of what transpired in the main game. The female protagonist, as a female player, is an important part of persona 3. Again, it's not integral to the experience, but the changes it makes to the game by simply switching genders makes the game feel like a whole new experience. New social links, ost and some story changes, e.t.c. It also opens up the game to a wider demographic, i.e female players. I don't like to criticize games for what they don't contain, however, but for what they do. So it doesn't affect my view of the game, especially since they aren't required

Honestly, I knew atlus had it in them to remake persona 3 and make it a fantastic game, but I've been absolutely blown away by what we've got. I'm beyond satisfied with persona 3 reload, and I couldn't recommend it enough - especially for newcomers to the series. It's the perfect starting point, and I highly recommend anyone interested in persona give this game a try, especially since it's about half the daunting length of persona 5 royal. you can wait for a sale if you want, but I'm happy paying full price for 60+ hours of content, especially when it's such a wild roller coaster of laughter, sadness, and determination. I can't wait to jump back in and continue my 6th or so reexperience of persona 3 lol. Huge congrats atlus, you've outdone yourselves on this remake. persona 3 reload gets an easy 10/10 from me :)

Edit: After nearly clearing the game, I can say that while I'm very satisfied with what atlus has made here, I can't help but feel a little disappointed by the portrayal of some scenes in the game. the vast majority of cutscenes are great, but there are a few scenes that I found just hit the gut so much harder in the initial ps2 release. even just the 1st persona awakening scene isn't quite the same for me. additionally, while environment models generally look great, I find the lighting (or lack thereof) in certain scenery really hurt some of the immersion of the game, e.g iwatodai dorm, where lighting is so flat that there a virtually no shadows. neither of these are deal-breakers though, and are absolutely more of a nitpick than a genuine flaw that drags the product down - and because of that I still can't find it in myself to lower my rating a little lol. I still love persona 3 any which way and I'm very glad atlus decided to remake it after fan requests for years :)


tl;dr: this game is an amazing remake of persona 3 and I highly recommend the game to both series newcomers and veterans alike. waiting for a sale is a valid option, but I think it's worth full price for 60 hrs+ of gameplay. 10/10 :)

Alright so, coming from someone who had never even TOUCHED a Persona game, i was a bit hesitant at first I'm ngl. After seeing so many videos about it across my tiktok feed I finally gave in and man, what a game dude. Personally, I never got into RPGs in the past but after this game, COMPLETE 180. Combat? Outstanding and easy to understand. Characters? Obviously you're going to have certain ones that you might not like but I was honestly listening and reading into every social link story there was and i found myself loving every single character brought to the table. And to top it all off, the story?? I give my compliments to the chefs cause brother, they were COOKING! I could honestly go on and on but this is the first time I've genuinely wanted to review a game and put my own opinion out there. If you're having a hard time deciding to cop this game, my brother/sister, I promise you this game will have you going on such a giant emotional roller coaster you won't know what to do with yourself. Also, side note, Junpei's voice actor? His voice acting was INSANE! But thats all I can really say, 11/10 game, wish I could experience it again

This game is an improvement over the original persona 3, fes and portable in almost every single way. Better and more interesting combat, though it does remain largely unchanged (which is good). Direct control over your party which 3 and fes did not have. A more fleshed out story, slight adjustment to some of the social links, full voice acting for all social links in Japanese and English and not to mention the 'link' hangouts with your teammates which are basically just social links that don't actually level up. 
As a remake I think it succeeds on every level besides some very minor things like some goofy looking 3d animation in cutscenes. But in a 80 hour game that's an extremely minor nitpick. 

However I do think that persona 3 has some inherent issues that are pretty much engraved in its core so they were never going to be resolved with a remake. As opposed to persona 4 and 5 I think the world can feel quite empty. There often isn't much reason to go out and try many different ways of increasing your social stats for example. Once you have found the optimal ways to get the most points per time slot, there isn¬¥t much of a reason to diverge. This is also true for other persona titles, however in persona 3 you get way less to experiment with and not many new things get added during your playthrough. 

This repetitive emptiness is also reflected in the dungeon design. While I am also not the biggest fan of persona 5 dungeons I do think tartarus is a bit too reliant on the (admittedly very solid) turn based combat. If you do not enjoy the turn based combat you will not like tartarus. This is also an issue in persona 4 but that game does a lot to make dungeons feel more distinct. Tartarus has a change up every block but otherwise it¬¥s basically the most basic way to make a player grind. As a result the game is not very difficult. Even on the highest difficulty, merciless, most people who are familiar with smt games would not struggle much. This makes sense because of the inherent ¬¥grindy¬¥ design but it is still true. Surprisingly the addition of 'theurgy' which initially seemed to me like it would be way too strong ended up being quite well integrated and overall pretty balanced and enjoyable to use.

The social links in persona 3 have always been a topic of debate among fans. As long as I have been a persona fan the general consensus among fans has always been that persona 3 has the better story while persona 4 has the better characters. Ofcourse ever since the introduction of p5 which achieved success beyond any previous persona entries combined this discourse has become more skewed towards p5 but I still think that the comparison of p3 and p4 makes more sense. Back to the social links themselves I think that some are absolutely fantastic while others leave something to be desired. I do enjoy the darker tone of most of them. I like that persona 3 is willing to have character's that are morally grey or that have problems that aren't resolved. However this is somewhat offset by the clunkiness with which some of these plotlines are written.

Something I realised when playing reload is that I actually quite like the way the antagonists are written in this game. While I do not think it's always entirely intentional, the way they are portrayed leaves it up to the player to decide on where they stand. While over the top they are sympathetic figures, for the most part. Whenever they say things I am never fully convinced of their faults and while actions speak louder than words, I do think that their words could make up for it given the situation, narratively speaking that is.

As for the story, I think it is conceptually very strong, but I have always felt that there was a lack of engagement. For me it never really felt gradual and I am glad to say that I do not find this as prevalent in reload. At helps that the world feels more lively purely because of the higher graphical fidelity. 

I understand criticism from people that wanted the femc option back from portable and I do think it should have been there, but as a persona 3 remake I can also understand the decision to not include it as some of the links are questionable at best and translating something that purely exist in a psp game would likely be quite a different task from looking at a PS2 title.

Overall I would say that as a remake this game is near perfect, I haven¬¥t even really mentioned it but I also really enjoyed the nnew soundtrack for this game. As a game I think persona 3 is great but not quite on the level of persona 4 and 5 though I do think those games feel a bit too goofy or cartoony at times. but that¬¥s a different can of worms.

Normally I don't write reviews for games, But I'm making exception for this one. Persona 3 Reload is my first experience with Persona 3 and Persona as a whole, And I didn't think that it would affect me as much as it did. To cut a long story short, The last few months or so have been a completely chaotic time for me personally, Being betrayed by people who I thought were my friends and then accepting what happened and growing from the experience and making new friends, And playing through the game, It connected with me in ways that no video game ever has before. I never would have thought a game I only checked out because one of my favorite voice actors was playing one of the main characters would have impacted me as much, But here we are. Just for the fact that this game touched me in a way no other game has, I would 100% recommend it.

If you like the Persona series, this one is a fantastic installment. I played Persona 5/ P5Royal but hadn't played the original P3 so this review is a holistic view of the game not just reload's changes. 

The combat is engaging and satisfying, though Tartarus gets a little grindy. All the social links started off as relatively uninteresting to me but then had a twist that totally changed my opinion. I haven't yet finished the game so I can't comment on the ending but so far I like the setting and the direction of the story.

If you want to play for the dating/ romance sim aspects, I wouldn't necessarily recommend it for that, though I think the romance adds a little enjoyment. I wished there was more romance in p5 too, though, so I think its par the course for this series. 

Last, my biggest critique is that I know the original allowed the MC to be female but this version does not. I wish they kept that, for replayability at the very least. 

Solid 9/10 though.

This game's story is amazing, not because it does anything amazing with the story because it contains all the cliches you would see in a typical Shonen anime. The story is amazing because of the fact that you get so well invested with all the characters throughout your entire year. You learn about their backstories, their characteristics, their flaws, their growth, and what they want for their future. While doing so, you also develop your own character and sink yourself into their shoes. Persona 3's story, although created before Persona 4 and 5, stands taller in depth and meaning than its successors because it invests more time into your friends, which makes reaching the end of this game all the more depressing. Many games have been remade to milk money out of their name without actually making the experience more enjoyable. The developers of Persona 3 Reload definitely knew what we wanted and they delivered tenfold with the unreal engine graphics, replacing the old P3 gameplay with the new satisfying P5 gameplay, but letting us get engrossed in the original story that was created over 10 years ago that still stands the test of time. This game is what a remake should be where it brings love back to an old game, pushing it to modern day standards without removing its identity.

It is worth throwing out there that my entry to the series was through Persona 5 Royal so my views are very much colored from my experience with that game.

Persona 3 Reload is a fantastic game with a pretty great story (not without flaw but we will get into that) but I couldn't help but think to myself that the tower of Tartarus concept is outdated and it really feels that way when you play it.

As far as Persona games available on steam, I'd still recommend 5 first to a newcomer, then I'd recommend this. I don't think 4 golden is for me as I have abandoned it on several attempts whereas when I played P3R and P5R I made it a mission to play them through from start to finish in very short amounts of time.

To start, the story, characters and day to day of Persona 3 are all great. However when contrasting to 5 you can tell that some of the things are outdated. From what I am aware of, your social skills that you level up only impact in Social links with three individual people, not to mention there are only three, so by the time you max them out a huge chunk of evening progression feels lost (thankfully, unlike 5, they have dorm mate hang outs that both give nuggets of story, can unlock potential upgrades for partners and grant items or consumables). The unforunate byproduct is that it feels like your afternoons suffer from decision paralysis of who to spend time with while your evenings are largely barren.

As far as social links go (for P5 players, these would be the same as your confidants), the stories are really tear jerking. I felt especially moved during Maiko's storyline [spoilers] in which she talked about her parents current divorce - which viewed through the lens of a child makes it all the more heartbreaking... my only hang up with this storyline is the fact that it leaned into a child confessing to want marry the protagonist which made me feel very uncomfortable[/spoilers], as well as in Akinari's storyline [spoilers] which follows a terminally ill young adult trying to come to grips with his pending death - him creating a children's story that served as a fantastic metaphor for his character as well as the protagonist really got to me emotionally and by the time his story came to its full conclusion in the epilogue i was in full blown tears[/spoilers]. In addition to that, the story with two late additions to your team was also a story highlight [spoilers] The story of Ken Amada and his parents tragic death paired with Shinjiro Aragaki's tragic tale of not being in full control of his Persona made for a great twist that I didn't see coming. Shinjiro was one of my favorites throughout the storyline and when his story was tragically cut short (and in such a poetic way in the bossfight i might add) it really made tear up [/spoilers].

But it's not all praise however, my most major criticisms of the game lie in the hands of the games primary antagonists - this whole section will be wrapped in spoilers [spoilers] I like the idea of Strega as a whole, but they largely felt under utilized and explored to me. I would have really enjoyed it if they had mirrored their team to be opposites of SEES. Chidori being a noted counterpart to Fuuka, and Takaya an obvious counterpart to the protagonist, why not add an additional two that could be paired against Mitsuru & Sanada? Jin felt like a largely nothing character who just looked up to Takaya, but Chidori had a very interesting arc and her end was another high point for the game when her Persona fused with Junpei. Unlike Chidori who had a great character ending, Jin's felt like wasted time and Takaya's felt wrong to me. Junpei should have been FILLED WITH RAGE upon seeing Takaya and had to either be stopped or convinced to stop or maybe even an option to let him finish Takaya - Takaya was responsible for the deaths of Chidori AND NOTED SEES MEMBER AND CLOSE FRIEND TO SANADA AND MITSURU, SHINJIRO ARAGAKI! Not showing their mixed emotions and just turning the other cheek felt wholly wrong, especially given Takaya's lethality. It felt to me like they wanted him to witness the final battle and it didn't feel earned.
Beyond Strega though, my biggest complaint with antagonists would have to lie squarely on Ikutski's shoulders. I had a bad feeling about him just because of his callousness towards certain things, but otherwise didn't expect him to be wholly evil and responsible for a lot of the problems. For him to be introduced as a villain, only to be killed off minutes later in a cutscene felt SO OUT OF LEFT FIELD AND ANTI-CLIMACTIC that i can't help but just feel like it was shoehorned in to give Mitsuru some misplaced character development. [/spoilers]

In summary, the game is great, It has many of my favorite Persona moments - in certain ways it has the best of what Persona has to offer - but it isn't my favorite of the series and I have many of own gripes that drags it down from being a perfect release to me. The story is there, the dark themes are there, but the execution of certain character arcs, and some subpar, outdated, repetive game mechanics made what otherwise could have been a masterpiece into a great but flawed title.

I would recommend Persona 5 Royal to any first time player of the series over this, but if you are looking to scratch the itch and aren't intimidated by some heavy topics and themes, this is a great use of your time and will provide at least 65+ hours of entertainment

Welp.. That's another persona game played.

It's truly a complete feeling. It's like finishing a period in your life where everything was so exciting and new. It's the feeling of parting with your beloved friends and have to come to terms with reality.

Persona is truly an experience I wish on everyone. Any game. Any persona is truly enough to teach a person. My first was p5 as was most likely for the majority. Then it was progress through my persona(l) favorite p4g and finally here. Yes I plan to play the first two games, but these three is specific just leave such a mark. That kind of mark cannot be attained easily.

If I were to sell you on persona, I'd probably praise the music, story and characters. That is especially true in 3, 4 and 5. At least in my personal opinion. 

Now after my common rant. Persona 3 reload is an amazing experience that truly takes the genre to the next level. It was the turning point for the series back then, and I'm glad to be able to say that it did it again. After playing this I really want to play the original, which I happen to own, but first I'll play the other games again.

The persona trilogy (3,4,5) is my favorite game trilogy of all time, easily. It's full of joy and sadness. It's at times difficult and at times easy. It can feel boring, but that's life. It truly has served me well in escapism and has supported me through depression. They haven't cured it, but goddamn do they make it easier to live with.

Persona 3 has always interested me with it's themes surrounding death. And yeah I get the "Oh that's so emo" thing and all, but god it's so well implemented. The overall philosophy of the persona series is so fascinating. I highly recommend watching essays on this series.

But yeah overall it's kind of ok 15/10

Atlus finally brought the best modern persona game to current day platforms, and it's fantastic. For anyone who hasn't played P3 before, this is almost certainly the best possible way to experience it. Some very important things are missing, I personally still can't believe that they chose to not include the answer or the female protagonist (though one can always hope), those things are not what matters for someone who hasn't even played the journey before.

As far as the things that this does rather than what it does not, I think it nails almost everything that it does. There is a little bit of atmosphere compared to og P3/P3Fes, and that is in my opinion the one thing that it does not fully nail. It's not fully gone, but it is severely diminished. The music is great as always, with the new vocalist being pretty good, though she is a lot better on the new original tracks than one the ones that were remade. The combat feels great like in all modern persona games. I played through the entire game on merciless, and while it was not nearly as easy of a game as persona 5 royal, I still would not really say I was challenged. I died a couple of times near the start of the game, but once you've got access to more personas and the skills they come with, the game is still a complete breeze to go through. The theurgy skills they added are also ludicrously busted and obliterate any sort of difficulty from orbit. For example (final boss spoilers): [spoiler]I was able to basically oneshot each of nyx's 13 phases with just a tarukaja up on a character, without even debuffing nyx's defence by chaining theurgy attacks together. kinda ridiculous lmao[/spoiler]. However, it's still pretty fun to play, even if it is rather easy for the most part.

Overall, this is a very very good remake, but man when will Atlus stop pulling an Atlus whenever they release a game, you know? Like it's ridiculous that they chose to remake base persona 3 without any of the other extra things from fes or portable, but then again I did also buy this game so that's not really helping. Regardless, Persona 3 Reload is really good, it's a very very good game.

"Persona 3 Reload" is not just a game; it's an experience. Atlus has outdone themselves in revitalizing this classic, infusing it with new life while staying true to the original's soul. The game seamlessly blends elements of traditional Japanese RPGs with a compelling social simulation, creating a rich, multifaceted world that is both engaging and emotionally resonant.

[b]Visual and Audio Upgrades:[/b] The most striking improvement in "Persona 3 Reload" is the visual and audio overhaul. The graphics have been updated to stunning HD, making every scene more immersive. The character models are more detailed, and the animations smoother, bringing the world of "Persona 3" into vivid clarity. The soundtrack, always a highlight of the series, has been remastered, with some tracks re-imagined, adding depth to both the battles and the more poignant moments of the story.

[b]Enhanced Gameplay:[/b] Gameplay-wise, "Persona 3 Reload" maintains the series' challenging turn-based combat but introduces refined mechanics that make battles more strategic and rewarding. The addition of new Personas and the ability to directly control party members adds layers of strategy previously unexplored in the original. These improvements make combat encounters feel fresh and invigorating, even for those familiar with the original game.

[b]Deep Storyline and Characters:[/b] At its heart, "Persona 3" has always been about its story and characters, and "Reload" enhances these aspects beautifully. The narrative is deep and engaging, touching on themes of friendship, mortality, and the struggles of adolescence. The expanded dialogue and additional scenes provide further depth to the already well-developed characters, making each of their journeys feel more personal and impactful.

[b]Social Link Expansion:[/b] The Social Link system, a hallmark of the series, is expanded in "Reload," offering more opportunities to explore the relationships between characters. These interactions not only provide insight into the characters' backstories but also affect gameplay, influencing the strength and abilities of your Personas.

[b]Overall Experience:[/b] "Persona 3 Reload" is more than just a nostalgia trip; it's a testament to how a classic can be transformed into something new and exciting without losing what made it special in the first place. It's a game that will resonate with newcomers and long-time fans alike, offering an experience that is both familiar and fresh.

In conclusion, "Persona 3 Reload" is a must-play title that beautifully balances its RPG elements with a compelling narrative and character development. It's a rare gem that reminds us why we fell in love with gaming in the first place.  My only complaint is that Atlus removed Junpei's classic line [i]"Woot!  Check out my phat loot!"[/i]

Persona 3 FES is one of my favorite games of all time, first played it all the way back in High School and have been a fan since. So I had a lot of expectations going into Reload, what I was expecting was a faithful yet definitive edition of Persona 3. After 30 hours I think I'm confidant enough to say yes, with some minor gripes that are not going to bug the casual player.

Almost everything from the original P3 makes it in here, Social Links, requests, same story, same characters and only one main dungeon throughout the entire game. If you're going in this game from Persona 5 please remember that while systematically it is similar, the game's entire structure is different. But this is great imo, because the structure still works great for me 14 years later. 

The battle mechanics and Social Link mechanics have been vastly improved and modernized. If you were turned off by P3's aged combat and Social Link system, fear no more. If you are familiar with Persona 5's combat and Confidant system, you will feel right at home. My only gripe with Reload is the decision to not include the Female Protagonist option from Persona 3 Portable, including this inclusive and loved feature would vastly improve this game's quality and replayability immensely, this would make this the true definitive way to play and experience Persona 3. This doesn't downgrade Reload's overall quality but it's a feature I still wish they included. Overall, If you want to experience one of the most unique and emotional JRPG's of all time, I highly recommend this if you can at full price, or get it first thing it's on sale.

This game hits all the notes the original and FES does all while giving it a new coat of paint and a few new additions, none of which clash with the game's style, pacing, or gameplay at all. Though you won't be able to go the entire game without ever seeing these additions once, you will at least have to option to just, not use them if you are so inclined.

The story starts simple enough, but takes you to places typical for games made by ATLUS, and boy does it hit in the most heart-wrenching of ways. As everyone here probably knows, Persona is the more emotional, angsty younger brother to the Shin Megami Tensei series, yet that doesn't mean there's nothing here that fans of the latter wouldn't love- at least, that's what I think, as a fan of both.

If you're expecting something super hard, this game has it's challenges, but if you're just playing on Normal like me because you're not exactly sure where you stand, you won't have to worry about any spikes in difficulty or overly easy boss fights.

The music is amazing and hits every spot it's trying to perfectly. Mass Destruction and It's Going Down Now are permanently burned into my head now, but I don't hate that one bit.

For reference, I'm typing this after beating the game, and sure some of this could be recency bias, but as someone who grew up with the Portable version of this game, later went on to play FES, and is finally playing this version, it's everything I could have hoped for- minus the exclusion of FeMC and The Answer, though I suppose I could always hope it comes along as DLC, eh?

I give this game a 9/10. Go play it, it's worth every cent.

Persona 3 Reload is a shot for shot remake which has it's problems, there is new stuff yes but so far it's the same exact game, i did not miss grinding my ass off in tarturus, most boring main dungeon in any game period.
