10/10 - Yukari is still a b!tch



REAL REVIEW, after beating game SPOILERS


To start

Now, i think the biggest misleading thing were the trailers for the game because it made it seem like it was a reimagining of the entire story but no, it's the exact same story no changes which i have big problems with like 2009 writing for Persona was very questionable but i guess they didn't mind. Another thing that kinda annoyed me is that they replaced some of the anime cutscenes with pre rendered ones which some work and some don't. Added "some" new scenes but honestly this was their opportunity to make the game longer since their not limited to ps2 hardware, like maybe setting the game back further to like Jan 5th or something


Characters - I'll start with the voices since you can never replace the original's, the new voices are pretty forgetful, like i know the voice acting was bad in the original but Shinji's voice in the OG sounded like he didn't give a single fuck about anything while this voice is basically "Ehh whatever" type voice, and speaking of Shinji, bro did not survive one boss fight like seriously? i think his death is unnecessary in the story, yeah he's going to die anyway but why even make him a party memeber if he last's one month!? i thought they would fix this in the remake but no. For the others i don't really care about, like how am i suppose to care about Yukari if she's a b!itch the entire game and gets into everyone's personal business, Junpei is kinda like able he goes through his character growth but bro acts the same as he did at the beginning like he didn't go through some trauma shit, you'd think he be more serious after what happened but no



Social links - Is it me or couldn't they added more to like Akihiko, Junpei, Ken, esc, i know that would be more for Nyx but still, they instead decide to do like social episodes instead where you hang out with them but don't really get anything in return like in P5 a character would protect you if their link is strong, but here it's nothing. At least we got Scott the Woz back


Combat - What can i say? it's just P5's but reskinned, that's pretty much it, there's baton passes and stuff and showtime is replaced with character limit breaks


Music - They didn't need to remix some of the music because i think the OG's music still holds up


Nyx - Why her own section? well it's because she might be the easiest boss in the game i was underleveled on Merceless and beat her first try, f_cking Takya was way stronger than her, and the view of the battle does not hit the same as the OG where in the OG Nyx is this towering giant looming over you and you have this battle view of you looking up at her as she fills the entire screen. I will note and won't forget it, i beat her with her own attack, i had mirrors and deflected in her final phase and killed her instantly, that was a highlight. And last battle (Burn my dread - last battle) doesn't hit as hard as the OG though sadly


Cutscenes - They really love mo capped and it looks so silly and overexaggerated movement during serious scenes is very distracting

Closing thoughts

Nothing else to say it's the exact same game but a major upgrade to the original, is it worth $70 bucks? no wait for a sale or play it on gamepass while it's on there unless your a major Persona fan like me

It was hard to get into Persona 3 before P3 Reload. The tedious, boring nature of Tartarus, and the promising yet at times stale feeling atmosphere caused both FES and Portable to never give the true respect that Persona 3 really deserved.

All that changed...

I can confidently say that Persona 3 Reload is indeed the definitive version of Persona 3. 

Atlus made wonderful improvements to Tartarus like plentiful loot drops, shuffle card updates, and Shifts (a Baton Pass esque feature) to make the core combat game play feel wayyy less tedious. Atlus definitely leveraged the outstanding game play ideas of Persona 5. It's actually a joy to go into Tartarus instead of a slog.

P3 Reload has a beautiful, living vibe to it. It's the first Persona game to feature fully voiced social links. Hearing side characters speak actual dialogue is akin to the old phrase "show not tell"; I'd like to hear the emotion in the characters and not just read it. The entire cast of voice actors and voice actresses do a phenomenal job. Atlus also added gorgeous Unreal Engine backgrounds and dynamic lightings throughout the different settings. All of this makes the most grim Persona game, ironically, feel the most alive.

I genuinely love this game, and I put it up there with my love for Persona 5 Royal. It's everything a remake should be.

A masterpiece. This was done by people that certainly care about Persona 3 and not just the same thing with enhanced graphics to make money. I paid a lot, but this was worth every single penny. I had the nostalgy of playing this game that was so important to me in my teenage days mixed with this great feeling of having my experience enhanced in ALL possible ways!

From the game's graphics, it's soundtrack and to the many new events and dialogues that makes the whole thing more immersive and impactful. Persona 3 was a very impactful game as it was, but now i can say confidently that it is even more. If you manage to use well your time to explore all the new features, you'll have an opportunity to feel more connected to the characters, and many points of the story that were limited to interpretation are now much clearer, like the part of the Kirijo Group in the whole plot, not going into more details in respect to those who can be spoiled by my review. Tartarus also feels more dynamic and it's looks are amazing in every blok. Also the new features, specially how Monad is being used now, makes it a lot more insteresting.

I love how the romanceable social links also feel more immersive now, specially with the possibility of actually choosing this time, instead of forcefully having to date all of them, lol. One downside though, is that the soundtrack of the last battle was a bit disappointing, i liked the original better, but it's a matter of personal opinion, and the rest of the soundtrack was way better than the original, also in my opinion. Oh, and it would be even more cool if merciless mode would force us to have teammates controlled by AI as it was in the original for a harder difficulty, but i guess we can just turn off direct commands for that, but still, it's also a matter of personal opinion, doesn't make it any less of a masterpiece. 

1000/10

A beautiful remake of the original game updating it with modern Quality of Life features and adjusting the characters to make them still feel like they always have but less stilted while leaving room for their original character growth. 
I'll be hoping we get DLC for the missing aspects of this entry like the FeMC or The Answer but even without them playing this version of the game a delight and the new OST is both fresh and blends perfectly with the older music.
All in all I highly recommend this entry to any new or old Persona Fans

---{ Summary }---
As a VERY dedicated Persona (And SMT) fan, I have been looking forward to this remake for a VERY long time, and despite the current gaming world, I am VERY impressed by this remake.

10/10, would shoot myself again.

---{ Graphics }---
It's a Persona game, I shouldn't need to say more. BUT, I like yapping, so I will. Even with the absolute graphical masterpiece of a game Persona 5 is, Persona 3 Reload somehow makes it ever so slightly better. As far as the style and vibe, they are both around the same level of awesomeness, but the advantage Persona 3 Reload has is that it is running on a much better engine (Unreal Engine 4), as well as higher quality lighting, textures, and models.

It says a lot about a game when you can spend 20+ minutes just staring at the screen looking at everything there is to see and still have a great time. If there is one thing anyone will agree on, it's that Persona games look AMAZING, and this one is no exception.

---{ Gameplay }---
Again, it's a Persona game, and Atlas didn't disappoint. No matter what you like to do, you will have a blast with it here. Maybe you want to talk to women, something you can't do in real life. Well, there are the emotionally engaging Social Links for that. Maybe you're like me and want to find the best way to brutally murder monsters, something a little easier than talking to women. Well, there are well over 100 Personas to choose from, and who-knows-how-many builds to make from them?

No matter who you are, you will definitely fall in love with the game.

---{ Audio }---
I played on the English dub, and MAN, the acting is on point. It may be one of the best dubs I have ever heard. The comedic bits are done perfectly, emotional moments are ABSOLUTELY chilling, it's just *chef's kiss* perfect.

Also they have my boy Alejandro Saab. So that's a plus.

---{ Can you run it? }---
Most of the time, it runs very well. I get between 100 to 120 fps running 1440p in most areas. Paulownia Mall gets strangely laggy with reflections turned on, sometimes dropping as low as 50 fps, and loading into new areas in Tartarus could even reach 30 fps for a second, though my scuffed hardware is getting a little outdated. Worst case turn reflections off, it'll do wonders.

(My Specs:
GPU: Quadro RTX 4000
CPU: I7-9750H
RAM: 64GBs)

---{ Will I rage quit? }---
Only if you aren't used to JRPGs. One of my friends wants desperately to get into Persona, but he absolutely hates the fighting on account of his lack of turn-based combat experience.

I played on Merciless (Highest difficulty of the five) and only struggled on one or two bosses. Once I was actually able to make a build, I was just curb stomping bosses.

---{ Must I grind? }---
It's a JRPG. If you don't like grinding, you're in the wrong genre.

---{ Will the story replace my life? }---
Absolutely. Persona games have incredible engaging and emotional stories, and even among those, Persona 3 is far superior. The dark emotional stories and characters are far more interesting than almost anything made nowadays.

If the other Persona games have 10/10 stories, Persona 3 has a 15/10.

---{ Will I have a wallet after getting this? }---
Weelllll... 70$ is quite a bit, and while it sucks that Sega is hoping on the inflation bandwagon, for this game I definitely think it's worth it. You can easily get 100+ hours out of it, which goes far beyond the 1$ = 1 hour rule.

---{ How buggy is it?}---
The only bug I have experienced (Aside from frame drops) was this one time I clipped inside a destructible object in Tartarus. All I had to do was break it and I was free though, so no harm done.

---{ ? / 10 }---

I finished this game today at 8 pm.

After waiting months for its release I am at a loss for words from the emotion i feel from finishing this game. Such beautiful themes spread throughout this game and such meaningful relationships you get to experience with every character. This game asks and answers the question of what is the purpose of ones life, and is death terrifying? Throughout this game you see the struggle the S.E.E.S has to experience, every member struggling with mental challenges and grief. But throughout all of this every member has good in them, the idea of death is inevitable what matters is what you do during your finite time in this world. This is what connected me to this game. It's themes are so beautiful and perfectly crafted, No matter how awful the next day may seem there's something you can look forward to and fight for. You'll know exactly what I am hinting towards by the end of the game. If I could I would remove all my memory of this game and play infinitely for my first time, and even if I can't do that I an grateful I got to experience this game in its beautiful state. 

Overall Review: 11/10 - The most beautiful story I've seen

Thank you for reading.

Persona 3 is the best persona game- Reload just made all the original stuff pretty and better paced.
now its the entry i started with way back, so ima tad biased. my literal one compliant is they didnt make a certain boss fight have that otherworldly voice effect while changing phases. the original final boss fight was so impactful that i simply expect it to sound like kylo ren. but besides missing that delivery specifically almost every other voice acted thing in this game is a straight upgrade; i had to get used to akihikos new voice- but i did fast. the performances for what was voiced before are fantastic- but its all the new voice work too; all 10 phases of a social link are fully voiced. ( provided they speak )

they also added a social link lite for the party members not under the arcana; and theyre so natural they fit in with the fes stuff seemlessly. also as i played i wanted to see if two optional side quests were in and i believe both are in (you can save two doomed souls provided these hidden objectives are accomplished) however i knew how to trigger only one of em i did see the mcguffin for the earlier one while triggering the latter.

this remake is a reward. and completing the game just recently with like 45/48 achievements in one go should tell ya its a welcome shift. i still dont think the og persona 3 was all that hard- and this is easier, but the changes arent dumbed down theyre just easier by accident of being fulfilling choices. the baton pass in p3 combat feeds into the loop nicely. the Monad doors were also great challenges and they push you to enter them because they deactivate if you move on without taking them. a nice lil risk/reward, very much a persona 3 typa choice. some challenges like bosses can be retried straight away a nice way not to overkill the punishment youre getting. but i do remember once messing up massively against a regular enemy and i had to reload on that death- it was like the only death i lost anything in. it doesnt feel like being babied though it just skips a whole reload which is nice considering the bosses are some of the highlights of the games feel. so getting right back in there has a very positive relationship with the theme of the game.

i spoke too long- persona 3 is better than most jrpgs even in its own series- this is a straight upgrade of that wonderful game- and for once players dont have to negotiate positive changes with some dungeon and extra waifus.
REJOICE!!

[h1]Persona 3 Reload is JRPG at it's finest [/h1]

This is my first game from the Persona series and I can safely say that it [b] Blew. Me. Away. [/b] I don't even know where to start. Although this is my first game of the Persona series , I know a lot of the spoilers from the original games and experiences from megaten because I had an interest in them which influenced me to buy this as my first Persona game on Steam thus making me feel like this is a really faithful remake outside of a few additional contents that I would list in the end. 

[h3]What is Persona 3 Reload? [/h3]
In the world of Persona 3 Reload , there is a time that only happens when the clock strikes exactly at 00:00, that time is referred to as the ‚ÄúDark Hour‚Äù. Humans are turned into coffins and they are unable to remember everything that happened during this time and the school you just transferred to will be twist into a very tall tower called ‚ÄúTartarus‚Äù . During ‚ÄúDark Hour‚Äù , ‚ÄúShadows‚Äù roam about. People that retain their human forms during ‚ÄúDark Hour‚Äù are referred to as ‚ÄúPersona Users‚Äù , this includes you and your team members. After awakening to your persona powers , you were recruited into S.E.E.S (Specialized Extracurricular Execution Squad) and together with other S.E.E.S. members , you are tasked to find out the truth of the cause of ‚ÄúDark Hour‚Äù , ‚ÄúShadows‚Äù and ‚ÄúTartarus‚Äù while juggling your school life.


[u] Social Links [/u]
Social links are a casts of characters introduced in the game. To someone that has never played a Persona game , social links are basically stories of specific characters. As you interact with each character more , your bond deepens and you learn more about their life , motivations , struggles etc. Each character is tied to one of the major arcanas of tarot cards, interacting with these characters will further your progression of said ‚Äúarcana‚Äù and each major character only has 1 arcana per character. The cast of characters in this game is faithful to the original games with some great additions like [spoiler] Aeon arcana [/spoiler] that were available only in specific versions of the older versions of Persona 3. You can feel the writers pour their hearts out writing a story for each character. Each character is uniquely designed and each has stories as good as their design. There are a few that missed the mark , an example would be the [spoiler][b] Moon arcana [/b][/spoiler] where although faithful to the original script , should‚Äôve been in my honest opinion , changed . Another thing to note , all social links are now fully voiced , which is a HUGE plus for immersion. These arcanas are also meaningful to progression , maxing an arcana unlocks a specific item that lets you fuse a specific persona. 

[u] Music [/u]
I have absolutely nothing but praises for this category. Every track in the OST is an [b]ABSOLUTE BANGER [/b] . The decision to bring back Lotus Juice, the main rapper from the original OST back into this game was just the best decision they have ever made. Changing the main female vocalist to Azumi Takahashi from Yumi Kawamura , the original‚Äôs female vocalist , was also a ballsy move for a remake but that decision only elevated the music in the game. Note that most songs are mixed based on the original game's music but with a modern twist. 

[u] Main cast [/u]
Without going into spoiler territory , the main casts of characters , like social links , were elevated in this remake. ATLUS has opt to change all voices for the main casts (I am playing the English dub) with the original voice casts as other characters in the game . This decision to change the voices in my honest opinion was perfect. Even with new casts , the main casts' voices were not out of place and in fact raised the bar for what I expect from a game with voice acting. 

[u] Gameplay [/u]
To keep things short , there are 3 elements for gameplay 

[b] Turn based RPG [/b]
The persona series (after the original persona 3's release) is famous for it's "One More!" and "All out Attack"s. These mechanics incentivise players to exploit enemy weakness and team building, If you hit a weakness , you get one more turn. If a weakness is hit , the enemy will get knocked down. If the enemy is knocked down , you get to initiate an "All out attack!". The gameplay loop is essentially these and it is goddamn satisfying. This is not factoring the absolute eye-candy of a UI for the battle screen or menu screen that makes the transition of menu-ing extremely satisfying. Who can forget about the music , the popular opinion is to hate the newly mixed version of "Mass Destruction" but I think it isn't that bad as people think, as for the new track made for player side advantage , "It's Going Down Now!" , let's just say it has been playing in my head since the ever first trailer they showcased this song till now which is playing while I am writing this review.

[b] Personas [/b]
To explain to someone that has never played a persona game what personas are is a bit tricky. I would say that they are "stat sticks" , you equip personas to inherit thier stats , weakness and skills. Persona's are mainly based on myths and legends with most designs made by Kazuma Kaneko very long time ago for ATLUS's other games like Shin Megami Tensei. The gameplay loop for this section is that , the longer you play , the more personas you will unlock , each persona is unique , design , weaknesses and skills. There are 2 ways to get personas , one is to get them as a reward from the victory screen , the other is by fusing 2 different personas to create a different personas , this lets you choose what skills you want to inherit into the newly fused persona , making everyone's progression different as the chances of someone else creating an exact same skill set persona are small albeit not impossible.

[b] Time management[/b]
Persona games are famous for it's "Calender" system. You get limited time slots per day to do what you want. Usage of a time slot can be spending time with a character to deepen a bond, or work part-time at a cafe , grind EXP , pray at the shrine , and many more. There are also unique days where there are special events to stop making the system stale. Note that climbing ‚ÄúTartarus‚Äù consumes one of these time slots are practically mandatory to climb a specific amount of floors per month to actually progress in the story. 


[u]Cons[/u]
Although I mentioned that this was a faithful remake , the decision to not include Female main character and The Answer DLC together with the game when I paid full price for this game is a bit absurd. This is turning a blind eye to the useless day 1 DLCs ATLUS has been practicing for years. Another reason I think will make people shy away from this game is how repetitive climbing ‚ÄúTartarus‚Äù is (this was alleviated for me because of how good the music for battles were but I can‚Äôt say this for everybody) . Last but not least , the team members you get to use are not all built equal , there is technically a clear line on who is ‚Äúgood‚Äù and who is ‚Äúmediocre‚Äù , in the end this is still a single player game so just who you want. 

[u]Conclusion[/u]
Like I mention , this is my first game from the Persona series and this is how I viewed the game and would explain to someone that is interested in purchasing the game. I would admit I skimped pass a lot details but I think my review has provided enough context for what the game provides and how the gameplay works for people that has never touched a persona game. I appreciate any criticism provided and will edit the review if needed. Thank you for reading.

Am I the only one who's experienced missing textures and geography on the school? I actually fell through the map when I tried running through a hall thinking it was just missing textures and still had object collision, it did not. Also, read that the Soundtrack DLC is currently a garbage .exe file instead of normal mp3 files, so another thing I won't be interacting with until its fixed. How does a triple A game studio miss big things like this? Undertale didn't mess this up, and was made by a single person. :/
ALSO, major thing: the gained EXP points aren't factoring out from the characters' total EXP correctly. For example, my total EXP began at 608 and I got 55 EXP from a recent fight, instead of my new total EXP of 553 I end up with an EXP total of 601. This is making my run much more difficult to level up, and I'm playing on Easy mode right now! This is something that really needs to be fixed IMMEDIATELY.

The game is faithful to the original while improving the mechanics the original had and adding new things. Persona 3 Reload is an amazing game that explores depression and how one's life can change rapidly, the story is fun to see and how the bonds between your friends evolve as time passes. The combat is fine, not too hard nor too easy but it could be improved, at the same time, it isn't the most urgent matter and honestly, it can be left the way it is as of right now. The fusion mechanic is fun to use and I spent some time just fusing Personas for the fun of it

As of right now, Persona 3 Reload stands as a 10/10 for me and I hope Atlus continues to make games like this

Probably the first Persona game I'm going to 100%. I remember playing this back in the PS2 FES days and it hooked me into the SMT series pretty quickly. However, being semi-new to JRPGs the difficulty seemed so much higher back then (in the days where you MUST HIT WITH THEIR WEAKNESS EVERY BATTLE and run out of SP after like 3 floors, imagine my fun when I played my first mainline SMT game lol). I honestly would suggest anyone who liked P4G/P5R to pick this up (and just so you know how much love they gave to this remaster, do a comparison and watch a clip or two from a let's play of the original/FES).

The "new" mechanics (really nothing new, so much as borrowed from P5R or updated from the original with QoL in mind) are welcome. I could never really sink hours into P3FES like I already have with this remaster, and that's thanks to the game feeling like P3 but playing like almost a new entry in the series. The beautiful visuals (the tower looks like a completely new location), seeing Elizabeth while listening to the beautiful Velvet room soundtrack, everything makes this a much more welcome addition to the Persona series (especially after Tactica, no hate, was just let down a bit with that one) and I could see veterans of the series loving this as much as new-comers.

Persona 3 FES is my favorite game of all time. Seeing the iconic title that helped pave the way for modern persona games warms my heart. The features this game adds from the original version, or FES, or portable are all amazing quality of life improvements, make the game a little less grindy, or just give you more time/ ways to hang out with party members. The unique features this game adds are amazing and made an amazing game even better. If you like persona 3/FES you will love this game. Getting used to the new OST and voice acting is a thing that might be an issue for many people (me included. I learned to appreciate the changes.) This game is an AMAZING first experience for someone who's never played any version of Persona 3. If you haven't played Persona 3 or any persona game and want to try it out PLEASE do yourself a favor and experience this game at least once. The realness of this game and the topics discussed in this game, as well as the the writing for the plot and all social links are amazing and really make you think about your own life. 10/10 Would recommend

I played a bit of P3P back then when it was on PSP, it had great premise but I couldn't find it that enjoyable, due to the fact that how tedious the Tartarus grind was, ended up watching videos on Youtube about the story (which is the best one out of all modern Persona!). 

I enjoyed P4, absolutely love P5 on how they perfect the gameplay. So the moment P3R was announced, I immediately bought Premium Edition and have been grinding it ever since. (Sought after Collector's Edition but sold out way too fast)

The tediousness is still there, but it has been improved with some of gameplay changes in P5, it feels better on how to progress now, everyone has an ultimate ability with F\_/uka becomes an extremely OP navigator. The Sim schedule during daytime is still stacked, but there are some adjustments and enhances that allow you to utilize the night time more, making it less daunting, unlike the previous 3.

Overall, I like that they stay faithful to the original (90%) while adding some changes (~10%) that actually make the game better to progress and allow more depth into each characters even more.

P3R, by far, has the best plot and character development for me, the more serious tone is also my liking more than P4 & P5.

P/s: Elizabeth's scenes are amazing!

A solid remake full of Quality of Life changes and a bunch of upgrades to graphics and lighting. Runs well on Steam Deck with 60FPS with no reflections, low shadow quality and 100% render scale, but even with these settings, it still looks good with a bit of fps dropping on Tartarus. On PC its a buttery smooth 120fps with no frame drops with 2-3 rare instances of crashing during my 100+ hours playthrough. Persona 3 Reload is one of the best JRPGs released this year. Like any other Persona game, you can expect a great cast, a good story, great music, a simplistic but excellent turn-based battle system, and a year in a Japanese Student's life (romance option included). Also forgot to mention the animations... they're so damn good.

With all the good things added to this game (a remake), it makes me excited for the next Persona game. Well done Atlus.

Persona 3 changed my life several times, giving me a unique perspective on life that I didnt have when I was young. With that being said, you can already guess I am one of those unnecessarily judgemental fans.

I have played the first hour of the game, despite me wanting to boycot this game knowing that this is NOT a definitive edition. But since I owe the makers of P3 a lot, I decided to give it a go, regardless.

First things first, the presentation. The graphics are a massive upgrade, no one can deny that. But The way the beginning is handled, its mystique is a downgrade. Two scenes come into mind: The man listening to a radio being trapped in the dark hour and Thanatos' Awekening. Both scenes do their job, but incredibly poorly. Both scenes lack their graphic nature to set the tone. You are supposed to be confused and feel a little tension when these scenes pop up. For crying out loud, P3P had limitations and they at least made custom portraits for the first Shadow-Victim.
"Thats just the beginning, the rest is stellar" - I sure hope so! But if they can't handle the beginning how can I be sure this game is worth its money?

My second point I can not stand: Sound. 
I had several moments where I felt I wasn't hearing right. I know the old tracks. I know them WELL. When I enter the dorm, I want clear trumpets and beats, a real welcoming fanfare. Why on earthg is EVERYTHING I heard up to now so flat?
The track that plays, when the first big shadow attacks, you know the spooky one that should make your heart pump and skin crawl? I barely heard anything stick out. Not the beats, not the loud piano at the beginning, its all flat.
I actually got my headphones because I felt I was missing a whole track in the song.

Why does every song sound like Atlus' neighbours were complaining about noise and everything got quiet to not stir trouble?

The voice cast is different, but great. Whenever I heard a new voice I said "Hey thats fitting, I can live with that"
Except for Ikutsuki. This man is hollow in this game. No joy to be heard when he tells his stupid jokes. And thats not critique towards the actor, its easy to just make a playful voice. The direction is at fault here. I wanna refund, I am sure the P-Studio put a lot of work in there, but man, just put it into P6 isntead of milking fans.

I'll come back when the game costs 30‚Ç¨, thats what the first P3 at launch was priced at! ;)

TLDR:
- Its not a definitive Version, no FeMC (Thats on me doe, still, I want to mention it)
- some out of tone changes to the presentation (2 scenes handled very lightly when they should have had impact)
- music is flat all the way (Either my ears are bad or there really arent Highs and Lows in there...)
- some voice-roles are misdirected

A wonderful remake of a classic RPG. If you loved any of the previous Persona entries, you'll love this game. If you've never played a Persona game, make this one of your first! Hope to see The Answer and FeMC in the future as DLC, but really happy with this game!

It's definately reminding me of the old P3 game I used to enjoy, with a couple differences on path stuff and combat options.  I don't grind to win as much or feel I need to. 

What's good:
-Music
-combat
-story

What could be improved
-the ability to save anytime, cut scenes included.
-less skipping time you might want to use
-more customization as a main character  (I mean this kind of became a requirement for role playing avatars years ago)
-storyline path writing  (this story was good, but in lots of places you lack agency or only have two options so the story lacks the kind of agency you should feel.  So I constantly am reminded I'm the character you wrote, not taking any of the aspects of the personas I should be conveying as myself.  Like you start with six and progress to many more.  But in real life you would seamlessly switch from one to the other in conversation.  At first you might sound like a fool, but you might talk like you are in charge to convince someone of your leadership.  You could even switch to a more of a lover, flirting your way to try and convince them to get what you want.  This kind of writing tree implementation would be hard to do, but really cool to play in.  Giving the illusion you could immerse in the universe in a much deeper level.  It would also be used to write like soft requirements for opening the story.  Like you require 5 death persona to take this path, or 3 sun.  Leading to like a way bigger game, but one with more story tree options.  Also you may want to consider writing an ending for each of the Tarrot so that the game has more replay value... any way this was my desire for the writing since Perona 1.  I wanted my personas to hold real life weight in the story.  I wanted to see an ending for each card type.  I also wanted to be able to craft my own story in the universe or one that felt like it.

I really loved these games, and I look forward to any releases and or future games in the series.  Hopefully you guys love it enough to keep these stories and world being developed.  And i hope you grow into something even more captivating, fun and engaging.

Normally I would recommend these games, but I'm not blessed with the weight to help dreams grow.  I can only say thank you.

Fantastic RPG, a lot of people: myself included were real skeptical since most remakes these days be very lackluster but I'm here to tell you this game passed the vibe check and has exceeded my expectations. 

A lot of people get put off by JRPGS because they're slow in the beginning but P3R is very straight-forward and easy to follow. You'll get hooked fast and there's a lot to do to in game outside of combat, after all nothing is better than an RPG with slice of life elements. My GOTY So far, if you love RPG's I highly recommend this masterpiece

Atlus tells stories in a magic way. I love how they approach apocalyptic and chaos with this magic, like the old Shin Megami Tensei times but without the magic (yes, it's only chaos 100% of the time there). Yes, this game is another masterpiece of their own, and I'm so glad it exists. In conclusion, we can say that Persona 3 and Persona 5 are amongst the best JRPGs of our time.

I didn't like it as much as P5R, but it's still a great game. A lot of the social links were pretty meh and not gaining new abilities from them was disappointing. The beginning of the game was also a bit slow and initially your team feels a bit randomly thrown together with a lack of proper setup. That being said, the characters and story really came together and grew on me. P3R just needs time to cook before you feel super invested. The core gameplay loop is solid and Tartarus surprised me with how fun and chill it ended up being. Definitely more enjoyable than mementos. If you haven't played P5R, go play that first, otherwise if you liked that game you will like Persona 3 Reload too.

This game is beautiful and a wonderful experience. All remakes should aspire to be like this.

After playing this game on and off since release, I have to say it has redeemed itself after my first initial bad impressions at the start.
I'm new to the story of Persona 3, and I was worried it was going to be extremely slow and repetitive, but luckily that ended up changing after pushing through the first introductory bit of the story, and started having me on the edge of my seat ever since.]
Tartarus can be a bit hit or miss when it comes to the excitement factor - but if you wanna just have a hyper-fixation on an enjoyable battle system, it definitely does apply.

In my case, I have purchased the "Premium Edition" which at the time of launch was $99 - I decided to not use the overpowered personas that were immediately available because I wanted some form of challenge on my first playthough of the game - but it was refereshing to see series favorites show up again here (and even be made from non-DLC characters).

I look forward to beating this game and coming back with the overpowered personas and having a field day in tartarus while I try different clubs / relationships on my next playthrough.

The voice acting is really good (but this is coming from someone who is not used to the old cast).  They did borrow heavily from the feel of Persona 5 Royal - and that is not as bad of a thing as some angry reviewers have been crying about.  Atlus did an amazing job adjusting the look and feel of the modern UI to fit with the darker themes that P3R offers.  The seamless transitions pared with the easy-to-follow social link system is a major upgrade from what was offered in the original (which I've seen/heard bits and pieces of).

I do wish they did more with this remaster by making the story a bit faster to catch on - but I completely understand why they wanted to keep it the same for the purists and people who grew up with this game.  This is not Persona 5 slapped on to a beloved franchise.  This is a completely original art direction that has made this game the best version that it could be (with hopefully a female protagonist being released in future DLC)

Overall, I 100% recommend this game - and I do wish to say you don't need to buy the most expensive version to get a good experience.  The base game is pleanty for those who want to dive into a new world by a beloved video game publisher.

10/10 - will play again (and again, and again...and again....)

This game is something i think every gamer should experience at least once. It brings all of the original content and more to the table. It is probably one of the best remakes of all time. I don't know if they did it on purpose but you can skip every random encounter in tartarus and just do the major battles and still have enough levels for story events. Of course this is very disengaging and just turns the game into a bad visual novel with random decently polished megaten combat thrown in every month.
I still recommend doing it if shadow combat is getting old for you, as it always does, because shadows have no personality and there is no way to interact with them, just badly designed enemies overall and it sucks they reuse so many of them. 

I specifically said that the combat is decently polished because shifting (baton pass) is broken, and so is theurgy (magatsuhi skills) you can always just avoid using them if you don't like it, but it's still something that should be critiqued.

Anyway, I recommend this game still, but only for beginners to JRPGs and anime fans. While persona fans love to claim it's dark and deep it still has all the anime stuff like an hour long beach segment where you are forced to hit on girls, a wit studio animated shower scene of a teenage girl, and a hot spring scene where the genders get mixed up. It doesn't matter if you put death, self harm and suicide in this game because it's still persona and it's incredibly cheesy. Nothing can make me take [spoiler]The gang getting crucified and watching Mitsuru's dad get shot[/spoiler] seriously, some of these scenes are just terribly executed and goofy, and it's only amplified by the voice acting.
The only good scene is when the teacher finds out you have been edating each other, it's so bad it's funny and the (JP) dub of it has severe contrast to the rest of the game being all serious anime mode. No, I'm not spoiler tagging that, you deserve to have it spoiled it's so bad.

Now I get that music is subjective and all, but this OST has been downgraded from bad to baddddd. The remixes just sound weak and it's odd that they decided to keep the midi horns. The main vocalist went from exaggerated vocals to baby's first vocals, sure it has better English pronunciation but it has just lost a bunch of energy. And Lotus Juice is still maybe the worst rapper ever, he could definitely spit some so called "bars" if a sentient human being wrote the songs, but he is out here rhyming biz with biz so there is no hope. 

So it's a high quality remake that makes the worst game I have ever played tolerable. It's probably up there with persona 5 in the hall of mid JRPGs, and it definitely surpasses P5 because it's from before they started doing that stupid mascot thing. Jack Frost will always be the true mascot and Morgana and Teddy should stay on e621 where they belong. 
If you haven't played many JRPGs, enjoy anime and/or are 15 years old, try it out! If you are normal, emulate the original first to see if you are interested in the story or themes, because games are stupid expensive and the steam refund time limit is not well fit for RPGs!!!

Also Junpei sacrificing himself to kill Nyx is a really odd writing decision??? Like yeah I always wanted him dead, but that is such a weird thing to rewrite...

We are not "Born to die", does a book begin just to finish? Does a song open with a beautiful chord purely to end? Yes, we are born with the inevitable fate of death, but that is merely the final act of the play. we are born to love, be joyous, to sing, dance, cry and feel. We are, in fact, born to live.

Uh..

PERSONA!

Pros:
- Graphics and visuals are good and detailed. The cutscenes are remade with more detail and amplified from the original version. Hence the overall story re-experience is great.
- Some convos (possible spoilers) with the antagonists which deepends the lore of the enemies are added.
- The dungeons are remade to make items more accessible (I'm talking about the golden hands, the twilight fragments, and breakable objects). The Monad dungeon is also simplified.

Cons:
- Unfortunately, this is coming from someone who played SMT Nocturne and other Persona games: the combat is pretty darn easier than Persona 5. The existence of theurgy and shift mechanics made the fight way easier.
- The dialogue mechanics are bad that you have to press auto button for every cutscene change.
- The rush mode is not really rush mode. It does not make the whole fight faster.

I dont know where to place:
- There are some music that you can really jive and vibe into especially the back ground music. But the boss fight and the ending song (true ending) sound better in the original.
- The boss fights have attack patterns (i.e. scripted). I gave this a plus especially if you have played the older versions, that the usual strats for some bosses cannot be applied to the remake. But, this is evened out by the Theurgy + Shift mechanics which made the fight significantly not only doable but way easier.

Overall, regardless whether you have played the original Persona 3 (or the Portable version last year) or not, I recommend this game overall. Especially if this will be your first Persona game, it is a good entry to the gateway of all Persona series. But not quite for Shin Megami Tensei series (I am talking about the main SMT) since that series is way more punishing than the Persona games.

Overall I am really liking this version of P3. I played through a good chunk of P3P prior to this version and the new graphics and cutscenes are a really great addition.

I liked my time with P4G and P5R as well, but I think I actually like the flow of this game more as it gets you into the action quicker and it feels like I have more control on how the story plays out. Granted this is a result of a lesser focus on the characters and story so if that is more your thing, this might be a bit disappointing for you.

I never played The Answer in P3FES but I don't know that I would miss it all that much. If it comes later as DLC that would be fine with me. I am more bummed about the lack of the female protagonist from P3P. Yes they fleshed out the social links a lot more for this version, but some people would still really prefer to have a gender option and it seems like a big missed opportunity.

My biggest gripe would be that they are charging the new AAA standard price of $70 which I honestly don't think this game does enough to justify. The skeleton of the game is the same as it has been since the PS2 days but with updated graphics and QOL updates, and even those are based on P5R which isn't exactly new. Still really enjoying my time with the game but it feels like it should have done more to finally be a definitive version, or stuck with a $60 price tag.

I‚Äôve played Persona 3 FES back in the day. Reload as a whole is better in a lot of ways, but there‚Äôs some key issues that bring it down. To that end, i def can‚Äôt say it‚Äôs the ‚Äúdefinitive‚Äù P3 experience. 

Weaker cutscenes. I get that in some ways they injected more of the canon personality of the mc and as such some scenes needed to be changed. But the generally weaker Storyboarding and sound design does reduce the emotional impact.

Akihiko was debuffed. Especially considering his character, it hurts the story and what he stands for. 

End game wasn‚Äôt balanced around the skills you can get towards the end, rendering the final battles as weak. Which sucks, cuz the final battle especially was powerful in the OG. Reaper also was less threatening.

Alecks Le‚Äôs VA work on the scarf guy was a bit of a disappointment. The environment lighting in places like the dorm and top of Tartarus aren‚Äôt that good. The NPC models are such a noticeable decrease in quality that it becomes distracting.

On the plus side, the new voices fit pretty well. Some more than others, and some being an improvement over the OG. The SL‚Äôs being fully voiced adds even more to the game. Some of the script changes are for the better. The added link episodes have been good and the graphics overall have been better. Gameplay and its animations have improved a lot. 

Overall, there‚Äôs some serious issues I feel but overall pretty good.

Persona 3 Reload is a Remake of Persona 3. It stumbles in some areas like the intro and cutscene direction. But excels in combat and the social sim aspects. Overall I recommend it and it is by far the best version of P3. However because of the flaws I come away from the game feeling a little bit disappointed; Maybe it is because it didn't hit as hard the second time around, or maybe it was because of the flaws (Cutscenes and Lighting) I mentioned earlier really mattered to give the original its atmosphere.

But overall it is a spectacular experience and I could relive most of the Original game, even if I still prefer the old release. And if you are a new player who did not experience the original there is definetly a lot to like here.  9/10

Being a huge fan of the original P3, I love this rendition of the game.  It adds modern features and more opportunities to spend time with party members, while being faithful to the original, outdoing its predecessor in multiple avenues.  Highly recommend for anyone who loves dungeon crawlers, visual novels, and amazing stories.

The remake is kind of weird. You need to wait like half a second before you confirm your commands as you go through dialogue boxes and combat, and it gets in the way a lot. The actual visuals in the menu backgrounds are ok, but literally every screen in this game looks so busy because the MC is popping some sadboy anime pose every chance he gets. It was cool for the rebel thing in 5, but I think 3 should have been more subdued. I love P3 and the sadboy MC, but the menus are a little ridiculous this time. With that said, the S. Link menu is the exception; that menu is simple but mad stylish, and it works perfectly.

The Velvet Room menu however is maybe one of the worst menu layouts I have ever seen. Atlus is very clearly starting to elevate form over function. I actually tilted my head to read the tiles the first time I went into the fusion menu. That is ridiculous, and I have no idea how anyone thought that menu was ok to put in a videogame.

$70 for what I've seen so far is cutting it kind of close, and that comes from an Atlus maniac that swallowed the EO collection price without question. If not being able to control your party members is that big of deal to you in FES, this is for you though. Otherwise, just go play FES.

For Anyone who wants to see all the detailed features from Old and New here it is[b] (I've also marked story spoilers):[/b]

[h3]New Features Added to Reload:[/h3]
1. Fully Voiced Social links
2. Theurgy Feature (SEES Members Ultimate Attack)
3. P5 Personas added to compendium (P4 & P5 Main chars as DLC)
4. Shift Mechanic (Similar to P5 Baton Pass)
5. Brand New Sountrack/Remixes
6. Yamagishi Tartarus Exploration Navi Skills for Team (Uses SP)
7. Save Anytime in the Dorm/City & Tartarus First Floor
8. Mail Features (Social Links/Events available for the day will text you)
9. Additional Side Stories for SEES Members
10. Added Dark & Light Attacks from P5
11. New EN Voice Cast (JP Voice Cast remain the same)
12.[spoiler]Added Side Stories for Strega[/spoiler]


[h3]+Added Features+[/h3]
[b]From Base P3 & FES:[/b]
1. Animated Cuscenes
2. 3D Exploration for Dorm/City 
3. AI Controlled Party Members (Switchable to Manual)
4. Aigis Social Link
5. Walk Koromaru Events
6. Elizabeth's Requests & Dates
6. Monad Depths
7. Fusion Spells (Renewed as Theurgy)
8. Persona Heart Items
9.[spoiler] P3 Fes Bad End Scene[/spoiler]
10.[spoiler] Elizabeth Boss Fight[/spoiler]

[b]From P3 Portable:[/b]
1. Teleport to last floor in Tartarus (Can now use both teleporter and door)
2. Skill Cards & Duplicate in Shrine 
3. Controllable Party Members (Switchable to AI)
4. Extra Turn for Exploiting Weakness
5. Male Sees Member & Ryoji Social Links (Added as Link Episodes Additional Story)
6. Can Heal via Tartarus Clock (Pay per use with Twilight Fragments)
7. Access All Party Members Equipment via Menu
8. Tartarus The Lost


[h3]-Removed/Not Included Features-[/h3]
[b]From Base P3 & FES:[/b]
1. Tiredness/Sick Mechanic
2. Required Romance for Social Link
3. Split up in Tartarus (Changed into Scout - Only 1 Member Advances to the next floor to scout the floor and look for items)
4. Removed Kendo Club/Swimming and Music Club (Can only choose Track Club and Art Club)
5. No Social Link Breaks, Reversal Only
6. Can no longer interact with members in tartarus (Conversations happen automatically in the background during exploration)
7. No Auto Heal when returning to first floor of tartarus
8. The Answer

[b]From P3 Portable:[/b]
1. Female Protagonist Route Option, No Theodore
2. Exclusive FeMC Social Link Characters (Rio, Saori,[spoiler] Yuko Easter Egg[/spoiler])
3. Co-op follow up attacks for SEES Members
4.[spoiler] FeMC Route Option to Save Shinji[/spoiler]
5.[spoiler] Vision Quests & Margaret Boss Fight[/spoiler]

[i]Persona 3[/i] is already a game that‚Äôs aged remarkably well. The story, music, visual design, and social gameplay have stood the test of time, so remain largely unchanged at their core. What‚Äôs more, the updated visuals, additional [i]Linked Episodes[/i] for the male cast, and new music tracks all feel like they were always a part of the game, and will be sorely missed when revisiting the original in the future. 

New quality of life additions have also made the experience significantly more fluid. I‚Äôd particularly like to highlight the retroactive addition of [i]Skill Cards[/i] and selectable skills during [i]Fusion[/i], making experimenting with [i]Persona[/i] builds far more accessible, and actually fun, as opposed to the mind-numbing roulette spin that was [i]Skill Inheritance[/i] in the original.

One of my main gripes with the original [i]Persona 3[/i] was its inconsistent combat difficulty. Even on normal, [i]Tartarus[/i] bosses could be ridiculously challenging, while [i]Full Moon[/i] bosses were an absolute cakewalk. That‚Äôs why I was so pleasantly surprised to see the immense amount of effort put into rebalancing these encounters. [i]Tartarus[/i] bosses aren‚Äôt pushovers by any means, but, fittingly, feel more like mini bosses, while significant story bosses are now far more challenging. 

[i]Tartarus[/i] as a whole has been more fleshed out. Ideas from the original, such as [i]Monad,[/i] have been reworked to fit the experience more organically, and the [i]Arcana Burst[/i] mechanic keeps each run a little different. I also can‚Äôt neglect to mention the fantastic visual re-design of [i]Tartarus[/i], which really goes above and beyond.

As a whole, combat encounters are easier, but not because they‚Äôve been dumbed down, but rather because you‚Äôre spending much less time fighting the game‚Äôs mechanics, as was sometimes the case in the original. With welcome additions from newer [i]Persona[/i] titles, changes to ailments and KOs, as well new [i]Theurgy[/i] abilities, combat is more enjoyable, while keeping you on your toes when it wants to. 

Overall, [i]Persona 3 Reload[/i] is a deeply faithful remake that expands on what is, in my opinion, one of the greatest games of all time. With a phenomenal soundtrack, a fun and addictive gameplay loop, and a timeless story that never fails to reduce me to tears, if you‚Äôve been holding off on giving the game a go, there‚Äôs no better time than now.

Aside from some extremely minor gripes I had with the new opening sequence, this is easily the definitive way to experience Persona 3.

Persona 3 Reload combines gameplay additions from both Persona 3 FES and Portable, with added QoL features from Persona 5. Tartarus also gets a massive makeover with new gimmicks and extra challenges. While the game is still fairly easy, Atlus finally gets the difficulty setting right in a Persona game.

It's still Persona 3 at its core, a game from 2006. Some parts of the game particularly the social link and available activities does show its age compared to its more recent successors. However, Reload added extra scenes and link episodes that do much more than just flesh the parts of the story that I initially found lacking. The game is almost entirely voice acted too, which certainly helps a lot in its presentation. While some of the new voice cast can take some time to get used to (Yukari and Akihiko in particular), I ended up liking them over the course of my playtime.

I still think Persona 5 Royal flows better as a whole in terms of pacing, social links, and free time activities. But with all the new things Persona 3 Reload adds, it definitely takes over it as my new favourite in terms of combat and presentation.

As someone who has played Fes and portable I have to say that Persona 3 Reload is my new favorite version of Persona 3. First of all and obviously one of the main parts is the graphics upgrade I thought that fes had fine graphics for a ps2 game but this game blows that and Persona 5 graphics out of the water, very detailed and very cool visuals to look at while exploring Iwatodai and Tartarus. The next change is Link Episodes which can occur after hitting certain parts of the story I appreciate them for fleshing out great characters even more. Tartarus also had some major changes that make it more fun to play through then the original and combat is fluid and fun. Tartarus is still a bit grindy and sometimes can be a little annoying at times but it is miles better than Fes' tartarus. In conclusion this game is very faithful to the original with some added changes that makes this my definitive way to play Persona 3 now.

This is an absolutely incredible remake which fixes nearly every issue with the original, expands the story to flesh out previously one-note characters, overhauls the already outstanding visuals and music, and is in my opinion, the best way to experience the story of Persona 3. While reported that this remake would not include content from P3FES and P3P, that is only half true. The Answer from P3FES and the secondary protagonist from P3P are missing, but many additions and changes from these versions are included in this remake. This game runs well and I had not experienced any major technical issues in my playthrough. The only problems I had with the game were that I found the game to be a little bit repetitive and boring at points, but I would chalk that up to the fact I recently played the original in anticipation for this remake. I would give this game a 9.5/10 and absolutely recommend it to anyone who is even slightly interested in it.

The very first Persona game that I played was Persona 3 Portable, which was a decade ago. I was in high school then; it is no exaggeration that P3P defined, to a large extent, my taste in video games. I have sunk hundreds of hours in Persona 4 Golden, Persona 5, and Persona 5 Royal, yet none of them even come close to Persona 3's themes, philosophy, and its long-lasting emotional impact it had on me. And a decade after finishing Persona 3 Portable, I am fortunate enough to be able to play and, after 71 hours, finish Persona 3 Reload. Who would have thought that not succumbing to despair and ending my life would lead me to this time of my life where I could once more experience and savor the game that defined my youth. Once again, Persona 3 taught me that one must strive to live life to the fullest, even though I am constantly on the verge of giving up hope and falling to the bottomless pit of despair. I am a broken young adult, still incapable of finding my purpose. Yet I will do my best. I have to live. Live life to the fullest.

The combat and UI was clean, the potential for players to min-max while staying easy enough for the casual audience, the challenge was perfect. The game innovated on the Persona style while keeping it faithful to the original. The bosses stayed true in terms of theme but they innovated and added slight twists and turns that will surprise and delight players who have ran through the original.

I update my review after finishing my playthrough.
Thank you, ATLUS, for reminding me of one of my most memorable gaming journeys in such a beautifully updated form. I appreciate and cherish all the little new additions and changes that round out the narrative and the gaming experience; I especially love all the little new SEES member interaction events that feel like a whole new social link and allows the group to feel more like a community of comrades who slowly grow into friends. I adore all the voice acting. Playing Persona 3 again allowed me to remember the major reasons and motivations behind my own creative endeavours, and I am sure the memories of Persona 3 Reload will be important to my future creative output. Thank you for the Reload, and thank you for the Persona series!

Finished the game. Overall a 9.5/10. I very much enjoyed replaying Persona 3 through this remake. The Final Boss fight felt a bit easier to me, but the optional Super boss is still irritatingly hard AF due to the rules enforced upon you. (Solo ONLY, No Drain skills, Null Skills, Reflect Skills, No -Karn spells, No usage of passive counters, and you can't use Armageddon too early). 

Overall though, the game definitely feels a lot more easier than the original PS2 release due to the absence of the fatigue system and having full party controls.

Character wise, in SEES, some characters were slightly toned down and some others definitely benefited from having better voice actors (Yamagishi especially).  
A new feature in-game called Link Episodes added some cool backstory and insight into the party members without S Links. 
 
For the S links, it was pretty much 50-50. I didn't think much about the Strength S Link when I played FES way back then, but the voice actress made her 10x better than what it should be. Hopefully fully voiced S Links is a series standard going into P6 because it really adds an extra layer of character. Sun, Hanged, Temperance, and Tower were good. Magician and moon I skipped through the dialog cause I truly did not care. Devil I felt like was just there to fill time at night (I felt this way before in the original).

In typical Atlus fashion, this game features really good new songs, some meh remixes in there as well but overall the sound track is very good. Atsushi Kitajoh is definitely good at making lyrical songs but his weakness lies in his mixing of instrumentals and guitar tracks. They sound flat and lack punch compared to Atlus' Toshiki Konishi and former composer Shoji Meguro. 

Art Style is on point, new artist was appointed in charge for the game but she still managed to capture and improve the essence of the original. Art in the UI in particular is immaculate. Usage of 3D models with 2D art on the menu interface is a really nice touch. 

if only they could channel just a little bit of that passion into improving the games assets, textures, lighting and overall appearance. I believe they could get an even larger audience. At the end of the day, a good looking game will always encourage more people to try regardless of how you feel about graphics. The same way Tales made that graphical leap from Tales of Berseria -> Tales of Arise. Atlus, you have the budget to do this, this is the 2nd game you have made using UE4. From SMTV -> Persona 3 Reload. Some game design choices seem weird. Like having no Ambient Occlusion makes the game look very off in the brighter enviments. It looks great in night sections of the game which is why the difference is really noticeable. The beach setting made it more apparent. The walking and running animations (in cutscenes) seem very rigid and Janky. It's nitpicky, but It's these little things that Atlus keep getting away with that irk me a lot. Hopefully with the UE4 expierience they can deliver with P6.  

Overall, the game itself is very fun and I can definitely recommend this game to any JRPG fan. Story wise, the strongest out of the modern persona games. The $70 price point might turn off many players that wish to get into the series but that is up for the consumer to decide. You can always wait for a sale.

Absolutely breathtaking. I don't have many games where my day revolves around getting home to play more especially for a game whose story I am already familiar with; but somehow if i wasn't inherently thinking about the game itself I was humming "Memories of You" or the new opening "Full Moon Full Life" as i was going about my day. Characters I never really used in the original were given really nice overhauls (they did my boy Ken Justice). 
I bawled like a child at the ending and at a few key points throughout the game, and i wouldn't have it any other way.

I'm gonna let my personal opinion stew so as recency bias doesn't cloud my judgement in saying this is the best Persona game. But I will say with all the thought provoking ideals and themes this game presents and how smooth the gameplay ends up being it will be really hard to go back and play 4/5 with the same mentality as before. Just know you are getting a quality game that was worth every damn penny and be sure to take your time playing/enjoying it.

Persona 3 is the type of game where, if you manage to reach the end, it will offer you a profound message on accepting life unconditionally and to cherish every waking moment spent with others.

Though it lacks some of the original PS2 version's charm, content present in other versions, and features questionable song arrangements, Reload skillfully updates one of the greatest games of all time for modern audiences while retaining the heart and core of the original. Beyond the social sim aspect, combat received countless improvements from years of polish, and it makes this version arguably the most enjoyable to play by a huge margin.

I cannot recommend this game (and this series) enough. It will be a slow burn, but trust me, it's worth it.

Having played Persona 4 and 5 Royal, I was shocked to see that Persona 3 Reload did much more for me in the 47 hours I played (first playthrough) than either of the other two did in 78 and 113 hours respectively (I even replayed Persona 5 after finishing this game just to see whether I was misremembering an actually great story from P5R... I wasn't).

I think the best way for me to recommend Persona 3 Reload is to discuss what I disliked about P5R (having revisited it) because the two are very similar in a lot of ways. [b]The following will have thematic and story spoilers over Persona 5 Royal. I will just say that Persona 3, 4, and 5 are all wonderful games if you've never played them before. I'm speaking more to the experienced and perhaps tired Persona fan who's been dulled by the mechanics of these games but hasn't tried P3 out yet and is looking for an interesting story.[/b]



















To me, P5R's biggest weakness is its philosophical thinness. The majority of the game is like a college kid who talks about Marxism in a cool light because it's hip and "modern" and therefore correct.. without trying to ponder over why libertarianism exists in the first place. Scratch that, it IS exactly that, but set in a high school setting. The game mostly subscribes to the "greed is bad" view without looking at the positive outcomes of semi-corrupt governments and big companies today like Tesla (even though the people at the top might not be what you call "ideal comrades"). 

To be fair to P5R, I enjoyed the last part against Maruki but was quite disappointed in the "true ending" rationale against Maruki's vision; the thieves basically just say "I'm happy with this reality, so boohoo Maruki I'll do what I want, I don't care that it might cause suffering for lots of people". I myself believe that a far more pragmatic argument against Maruki is the dilemma problem: if two people want mutually interfering outcomes, like say, there's a war between countries X and Y and I want X to win while the other person wants Y, then who decides what's the right choice in terms of making either of us happy? And if you then say that we could just avoid war altogether, then what about, say, nationalistic sentiments and imperialistic desires? Why should a person like Maruki then get to decide that a person's nationalistic / imperialistic sentiments are wrong? There are countless more examples like this on even simpler bases. It should be noted that since Maruki's power could eventually be arbitrary as per the game, he could arguably just become God and herald infinite unity across the world (but then this discussion turns meaningless; more productive would be the assumption that Maruki doesn't want to change people's wishes, which would be coherent with the last dungeon's "testing room" logic).

Persona 3 Reload, in contrast with what I just described, is a cogent and coherent piece that combines the stylistic elegance and modernity of P5R with a vivid depiction of the human struggle of death, of yin and yang. It is a wonderful story that, unlike P5R, mostly avoids platitudes and does not stretch its rhetoric to political infinity for the sake of sounding modern / politically correct. Additionally, P3R's ending is easily one of my favorites of any game I've played and will stick with me for a while, at the very least.

This is a game I can easily recommend to anyone who desires an intellectually stimulating story set in a mechanically and stylistically charming atmosphere, and not the other way around.

A very good remake of one of my favorite games ever. 

The new cast for the EN dub do a good job at portraying the characters, though I ended up liking the Japanese voices more.

Tartarus is much more tolerable this time around, and I even found myself grinding out of my own volition, whereas in the original I only did it when necessary. The game definitely feels easier compared to the original even on the highest difficulty, especially with the addition of theurgy attacks. I always felt like I was cheating when using them, since you can pretty much kill everything within a couple turns if you know what you're doing. One of the better changes to the game for me was the removal of the fatigue system, it was really annoying to be forced to stop advancing because your teammates were tired. It also made leveling up Social Links harder since you had to do other things in order to feel better, which made you waste a lot of time. The schedule is also less tight in Reload, giving you more time to do S.Links and such.

From what I can tell the main story remains largely unchanged but there are little bits and pieces spread across the game that help with some of the pacing issues the previous iterations had. The introduction of "Link Episodes" for male party members, in lieu of Social Links, adds a refreshing layer to character development. There are now more things you can do in the dorm such as cooking, reading, and watching TV, providing passive combat abilities as rewards. 

The remastered songs have a mixed reception, but personally I find them good overall, with a few exceptions. The new songs are all among the best the series has to offer. I've seen people say this game feels more like Persona 5, but I don't really feel that way apart from the obvious graphical and gameplay advancements along with some QoL stuff. I think this remake really improved upon the original game in nearly every way possible and I would say this is the best way to experience the core P3. I don't mind the absence of The Answer, mostly because it was extremely tedious to play. If Atlus does add it as a dlc later on I hope they streamline it for a more enjoyable experience.

Just amazing, I cannot but recommend the game, especially to people who swear by persona 5 having that been the only one they have played.

The only gripe i have with the game is that menuing is a bit annoying, stats and equipment should either be the same menu or be a button press away, but aside from that everything is just perfect

gotta be honest, i started playing the series at P4, then P5, then P5R and back to P4G and only after P4G did i play P3, but i played portable. honestly, couldn't be bothered to finish it. i got to the final boss, and fizzled right out. the later games just gave 3 a horrible disadvantage, especially being P3P. now that P3Re is a thing, i feel i can finally experience the game that some old friends absolutely swore by, in a much easier to digest form, and on a much more visually vivid and stunning canvas. the game so far has immersed me as if i was back playing P5R again. the dungeon exploration feels much more vibrant and dynamic, the battles are pretty much the same for the core format, not that that was ever the problem. the music is a little hit or miss for me so far, the opening theme absolutely slaps, the battle theme is...eh. the nighttime theme... i have been honestly sitting here while writing this, standing outside in game just to listen to the song. all i will say is, if you're like me, and felt that you were robbed of a good P3 experience because it was either out too early in your life to have known it, or because the only one other than this on the market is portable, then i implore you to give this version a try, it will not disappoint you.

As a long-time fan of the series, it's with a heavy heart that I find myself writing a less-than-stellar review for the latest installment. Despite the game's outstanding music, compelling character development, and engrossing storytelling, its pricing strategy and lack of innovation leave much to be desired.

Price vs. Value:
The decision to price the game at $70 sets high expectations for quality and innovation‚Äîexpectations that, unfortunately, aren't fully met. This discrepancy raises concerns about the future direction of the series, echoing fears of a shift towards a quantity-over-quality model seen in other franchises like Assassins Creed or Call of Duty.

A Closer Look at My Concerns:
‚Ä¢	Innovation and Gameplay: The game's failure to introduce new mechanics or evolve its design philosophy is disheartening. The dungeon design, particularly Tartarus, remains as linear and repetitive as ever, lacking the thematic depth of Persona 4 Golden or the creative ambition of Persona 5. The level design falls far behind that of Persona 5, which pushed the series forward and attempted to get away from the linear repeat floor strategy that we saw throughout the earlier entries.
‚Ä¢	Visuals and Performance: The character models look incredible, but everything else is simply subpar for a $70 game. The 3D models of all the personas look like they still belong in the PlayStation 2 era. They reuse the same generic character assets during the story scenes. The maps for the battles, just look like simple level designs created in the unreal engine by an intern. For example, the train map, its just a big open space, with seats that don‚Äôt scale very well, and just barren emptiness. Like come on we should expect more from a $70 game.

          We still have loading screens and tiny instanced areas. For such simple level design in a game that released in the year 2024, Atlas needs to finally figure out how to reduce all this time loading. Its unbelievable and again feels like something from the PS2 era. Further, I have a 4080 and the latest I-9 processor as of 2023, yet my game feels so unoptimized and slows down sometimes when exiting menus or runs slower in the loading screens. This game should be smooth as butter for how simple it is, yet my experience feels like the same experience I had in gaming back in 2006.

Why This Matters:
The gaming community deserves transparency and fairness in pricing. Charging $70 for a game implies a certain level of quality and innovation, neither of which are adequately delivered here. This practice, if not addressed, risks diminishing the series' soul and identity, turning passionate fans into disillusioned critics.

Looking Forward:
My critique comes from a place of love and hope for the series. It's crucial for developers to listen to feedback and strive for excellence, especially when asking fans to invest more financially. I intend to 100% complete this game to get my money‚Äôs worth, but I am highly disappointed. The only other $70 games I‚Äôve played were Tears of the kingdom, and Tekken 8, which were absolutely worth the price as they innovated and propelled their respective series forward.

I naturally have bigger expectations for higher price point games, and this remake still falls just a bit short of it.

What I liked the most was it's added story beats and refinements of systems taken from the future titles, such as Linked Episodes to flesh out the male party characters, more things to do during day/night time that makes it a bit more easier to do SL/Social Stat grinding, and the overall bump up in the combat mechanics to give a lot of fun options to just grind out encounters.

I didn't like that all the major SL didn't get that much of a touch up of the original, the lighting on the default settings not really making the game look that great in many areas (I recommend -5 or so in the brightness settings to better it a bit) and while all the new additions is nice, I actually do think it's still too much especially with the combat - it gives too much power to the player even on Merciless, and all the additions to spice up Tartarus kind of make it going back to just bloat with the additions and modifiers you can apply during that section of the game. I'm still ultimately of the opinion that Tartarus needs a block cut as I don't think all those floors are that justified to go through.

It's still absolutely a remake worth a playthrough, just maybe not worth it's full price tag.

Returning to P3F/P3P and also trying P5 they didn't quite have the same draw for me as P4G between the characters and how the dungeons function.

This remake/remaster has implemented my favourite upgrades to the UI/combat from P5 and integrated them perfectly into a game whose story/characters/dungeon has managed to suck me in more than P5 could. I believe that the characters in P4G blow these ones out of the water [at least of the characters I have met], and I still prefer how the dungeons in P4G work; so personally speaking I still prefer Persona 4 over this game [though, if it could one day get a remake treated with as much love as this, that would be my GOTY with no questions asked] however this version of P3 has sucked me in way more than any prior version and allowed me to actually experience this excellent game.

TL;DR - Awesome game, a complete improvement over the original

I played Persona 3 FES about maybe 3 or 4 years ago and since then this has been the most impactful and beautiful piece of media I've ever had the pleasure to experience. The characters, the music, and the signature SMT-like gameplay mesh together so perfectly. This remake manages to improve upon every feature the original had and brings new life into every nook and cranny of this game. Nothing ever felt like too much or too little, it was all perfectly executed. It stays faithful throughout the entire game while also adding tons of new features that simply makes the game even better and more engaging. Tartarus in the original games were admittedly really boring and repetitive, although it did still have fairly good level design and music. This remake realizes that fact and goes the extra 10 thousand miles to add a bunch of features to make the gameplay actually interesting and cool. The level design is improved in Tartarus and every segment looks so good. Every character gets so much style and personality and the UI goes hand in hand with the fun gameplay. All of the UI menus, transitions and everything else has so much vibrance in every way. Even the pause menu and the menus within it are so dope and cool to look at, incredibly stylish. One of the main parts of this game's improvements is the voice acting. When it was revealed that everyone would get new VAs, i was obviously worried, but every new voice actor performs their acts flawlessly. Most of them are almost indistinguishable from the original, and even though the others may not sound just like the original, they still fit their character perfectly and do an amazing job all the same. The music in the original Persona 3 games is iconic, and the music in this remake does every OG track justice. Every track is remade to perfection and it never went too far or sounded bad at all. I could never say it's necessarily "better" than the original OST, but it's still so so good all the same. There's just so many additions and changes that i love and appreciate so much. It doesn't matter if you played the original or not, this remake will still take you along for an amazing ride with plenty highs and lows in its story. It's a journey full of amazing story-telling, characters, gameplay, and music. Persona 3 Reload is a perfectly worthy successor to the original, and i loved and cherished every single second of it. Don't let these clowns on the internet or in the Persona community dissuade you from playing this game. If you want to play it, then go ahead. Playing Persona 3 FES and this remake are such beautiful memories to me, and i hope you can also make some good memories with this game too. Thanks for reading, if you did, and have a good rest of your day
