[h1] This is honestly my first time reviewing a product, but i felt this was appropriate for my first. [/h1] 

I remember getting into the Persona series back when P4G released back on Vita, and subsequently playing P3P soon after beating P4G. That was around the time frame of 2012-2014 and now 10-12 years later i got to play the remake of one of my favorite entries in the Persona franchise. 

1. It was slightly tough getting used to the new Voice Actors (at least for the English audio, plan on playing with the Japanese audio my second play-through) but more or less felt like they were pretty well fitting for the all-star cast that makes up P3.

2. I appropriate the fact they went so far as to voice act ALL the social links this go around for every rank, to which is honestly a first seen in the series from 3-5. It seemed a tiny bit easier to rank them up than normal...or i just got lucky with remembering what were the best dialogue choices for them alongside having a Persona of their arcana on me as i hang out with them.

3. New game-play mechanics they introduced through [spoiler] Theurgy [/spoiler] helped shake up the combat style enough to keep things fresh for older players, while those only experiencing 3 through this remake will be in for a treat compared to its original counterpart.

I wasn't really posting this to give a in-depth review covering pros and cons of the game, more so just giving my opinions on my own personal likes from this remake. I think Persona 3 Reload was done well enough to be the perfect entry into the Persona series as a whole, or the best experience of 3 for players who only played P4G, P5/P5R or both.

I love Persona 3 and it is currently my favorite Persona game out of all. I started with Persona 3 Portable, then Persona 3 FES for "The Answer". Then I bought the P3P port on my Switch. That's how passionate I am with this game.

Now, with that out of the way, here's my honest review, humor me for a bit:

I've seen many trailers of this game since last year, found out a lot of things like new and arranged music, the content compared to the original games, etc. I was kind of disappointed that we won't get "The Answer" from FES in Reload, nor we get to play as FeMC from Portable. I was also neutral in terms of the new singer Azumi Takahashi replacing Yumi Kawamura. I've heard some sample music from YouTube and there are some parts that she's good and there are also some that is quite out of place for my taste. Despite that, I want to try this game without my nostalgia blinding me to what Atlus has cooked for this remake.

[h3]Graphics:[/h3]
What can I say, the graphics is good compared to the originals, even compared to Persona 5 Royal. [b]9/10[/b]

[h3]Music:[/h3]
The soundtrack is [b]GOOD[/b] on its own right. It has its own identity. It was never meant to be a "Yumi Kawamura" style, and I am fine with that. Lotus Juice spitting fire as always with the rap. "Color Your Night" and "Changing Seasons -Reload-" also slaps. [b]10/10[/b]

[h3]Gameplay:[/h3]
[b]THEURGY![/b] A welcome mechanic. It is like a "Limit Break" for playable characters that can turn the tide of battles. You can only use it when your gauge is full though, and every characters have different ways to charge it fast based on their personality. It's neat and I like it. The rest still plays like neo-Persona. There's 1 more when you hit weakness or land critical hits, and there's "Shift" that works the same as "Baton Pass" first introduced in Persona 5.

They also added some stuff during the exploration of Tartarus:
- There are some "petrified" shadows with shiny things that they're holding. Players can destroy it and get valuable materials for selling or get "Twilight Fragments" that are very important, which I will explain further down.
- "Twilight Fragments" are valuable items because you will need this to unlock special treasure chests and use the clock in Tartarus (Yep, you can't use your money anymore). You can find these fragments while exploring Tartarus, exploring the areas of the map, or by progressing your Social Links then talking to Elizabeth.
- [b]GREED HANDS[/b]. These special shadows are addition to the existing "Hands" shadows. They will sometimes appear when you first step on a floor, and they swipe all the chests available in that current floor. The only way you can reclaim the treasures is by correctly traversing which direction the shadow went. (Yes it is random and there is no way you can know for sure as far as perception is concerned). I kinda hate this new mini-game but after I unlock the navigator's "Tartarus Scan", which skips the mini-game entirely and proceeds to fighting, I am no longer bothered by it.
- Monad Gates. There are two types of it, the first one is the type of gate that appears randomly on a floor the moment you arrive. When you go through it, you will fight a mini-boss that blocks your way to the treasures. But once you defeat it, claim the treasures, and go outside, you will have full map of the current floor you are in and the next floor, which is neat. The second type of Monad Gates are the fixed gates stationed in some of the floors with a two-way teleporter on it. Similar to the random gates, you have to defeat mini-boss to proceed, but this time, there are multiples of it, like 2-3 mini-bosses. The treasures you get here contains tarot cards, some lore documents, costumes, etc, so it's definitely worth doing.
- [b]SHUFFLE TIME[/b] is back, but without the actual shuffling like the original games. It's kinda like in Persona 4 where you just pick the cards you want. There's also an Arcana Burst mechanic wherein when you maxed out of Arcana cards to pick, you can never pick another Arcana card for that night, but the usual "Sword", "Coin", "Cup" and "Leaves" cards will be upgraded 1 level up. I personally like this change because I'm not fond of the cards shuffling in the original games, it makes me dizzy.
- Ambush. You will need to progress to the game before you unlock this but once you unlock this, it will guarantee a preemptive strike or "SEES Advantage" during battles whether you attack the shadows in the front or back. You can also upgrade your ambush by buying URLs in the Net Shop or the guy in the club. A neat addition in my opinion. It makes preemptive strikes easier to do.

They also made changes to how Social Link works with people that the protagonist can romance. You are not forced to enter a romantic relationship with them in order to max their Social Link anymore. Also, technically not a Social Link, but you can now hangout with your team members at the dorm. You can cook, tend plants, watch TV, and read books with them. They also award you with social stat increase and some useful items. I personally like this addition as it adds more character depth and development between the SEES members.

I might have missed some other new gameplay mechanics but this is what I remembered on top of my head. Overall, [b]9/10[/b]

[h3]Story:[/h3]
Story is pretty much the same as the original, but they added some scenes that added more context and character depth like [spoiler]Strega scenes and Takaya scenes[/spoiler]. I'll not expound further in this as it is spoiler territory, but I personally love these scenes.

As stated by Atlus themselves, the game doesn't include "The Answer" part of the story, first introduced in FES. It also doesn't include FeMC and her unique Social Link characters. If you don't want that, then avoid playing this game. But personally, I don't mind and I still like that they made it faithful to the original Persona 3. [b]10/10[/b]

[h3]Replayability[/h3]
There is a New Game Plus available on this game, meaning your clear save data can carry over to your next new game. This is useful for people who want to try the game again to experience new dialogue options normally not accessible due to lack of social stat points, try to romance a different Social Link, or to just complete the achievements that they missed on their first playthrough. But story-wise, there is not much worth replaying the game as it has only two endings that I know off. One is the good ending and one is the bad ending where you [spoiler]kill Ryoji[/spoiler] and the game will end prematurely. [b]8/10[/b]


Man, overall I love this game and Atlus made a good remake to satisfy this Persona 3 fan. If you're a fan of Persona especially Persona 3 and don't mind the missing "The Answer" or FeMC, or if you're new to Persona in general and a JRPG fan, I highly recommend playing this game. [b]9/10[/b]

(copying my full review from backloggd so cw for me waffling for too long)
Ever since I played the Portable remaster Persona 3 has really stuck with me, standing out as my favourite story and concept in the whole series despite some gameplay problems. My love for P3 only intensified after watching the movies and I was planning on playing through FES as well when Reload was announced, so I decided to wait until this was released to get a full Persona 3 experience.
I should start off by saying that I love the idea of a new version of this game only because it infamously has no complete version, and I absolutely don't want remakes of 2, 4, or 5 because they all hold up perfectly fine as complete games (I don't want a 1 remake because it sucks too bad to ever be playable). Even this apparently won't officially include FeMC from Portable, which is understandable but a little disappointing given that some of the best content in the series is locked behind that route. As a trend I think remakes, reimaginings and rereleases are oversaturated right now and above anything what I want is Persona 6 or anything truly original.
But none of that changes the fact that this is now my favourite game in one of my all time favourite game series.
What I was most afraid of going in was the Persona 5-ification of 3, a remake that drained the incredible personality of 3 out of the game in favour of replicating 5's success. While you could definitely argue there's a little too much 5 in here I can personally say that the atmosphere and unique gameplay that made me fall in love with 3 is completely intact. Atlus haven't backed down from embracing how dark and strange 3 is compared to the later games, and the soundtrack is true to the vibe of the original with remixed and new tracks blending in seamlessly. It's amazing how smoothly they manage to flesh out and expand every aspect of this game, from character and environment designs to plot beats. The new and the old are indistinguishable, something i honestly never expected. It's still Persona 3 in all it's flawed glory, but with massive quality of life overhauls and more story content.
And speaking of that story, in a series about the power of making connections with others, P3 stands out as by far the best and most coherent exploration of that idea. Every link emphasises and strengthens the core themes of the finite nature of life and the importance of connecting with and uplifting others, even the rare mediocre ones like suemitsu or tomochika. It's a story with real stakes and real tension that isn't afraid to kill major characters for the sake of being true to itself, something that few games in the series can claim. The imagery is unforgettable, and the emotional climaxes hit like a fucking train, especially with the knowledge of what comes later. Despite having already experienced this game once, and this story twice, I was completely and consistently gripped all the way through. While 4 has my favourite cast, SEES comes in close second with a universally believable and likeable team that have great chemistry. It might even be the only squad where I can't say I dislike a single member.
I do have a few minor complaints which I'm going to put here because this review is a mess and I don't know where else to put them; i do wish they leaned into 3's weird little original mechanics like party members getting tired or sick and fleshed them out into more coherent systems, rather than just cutting them entirely. Also overall I think smoothing out the gameplay makes it WAY to easy for anyone familiar with the series; I played it through on Hard and it felt like a Normal playthrough of any other persona game, which is kind of a shame for the definitive version of one of the more challenging persona games.
Going to rewatch the movies soon with some friends so I'll have more time to ramble on aimlessly about how much I love 3 then but for now all I want to say is this is near-perfect and truly beautiful, an easy contender for my favourite game of all time and one of the greatest remakes ever.

Persona 3 Reload is a fresh take on a game that was held back in 2006 by a dated combat system and graphics. It more than fixes both of these issues, while also remastering the soundtrack and adding a few new tracks. It's a much more welcoming experience for newcomers to the series than the clunky tactics-menu-combat of the original. While still not sporting the most beautiful graphics it is quite alright for anime-style games. The UI is beautiful, as is expected from a modern Persona game, however some transitions feel laggy despite there not being any actual lag. All in all it'll be a quite pleasant ride for 60 - 90 hours (depending on how fast you breeze through the story and/or Tartarus and how many social links you interact with).

After beating Persona 3 Reload, I think it's fair to say that it is genuinely one of the greatest JRPG's of all time (imo). It takes everything from the original Persona 3 and makes it 10 times better while staying true to the original story. It makes the overall experience much more enjoyable and adds plenty of quality of life features that make the game feel good to play, and not feel like a slog to get through. If you have a spare $70 lying around, get this game because it is 100% worth your time with its 60-70 hour long story.

(note: am currently in July, opinions may change but having played FES and unlocked most existing social links I'm fairly confident my overarching feelings on Reload won't change)

Essentially Atlus Persona 5-izing Persona 3. It's a fairly faithful remake of 3 with both combat and social life mechanics brought up to Persona 5's standards.

If you've played Persona 5 and/or 4 Golden but struggled to get into Persona 3 FES/Portable due to the downgrade of quality of life features, this is the perfect way for you to enjoy Persona 3. I do wish they could have preserved some niche aspects of the game like FES's more robust tactics system, showing full turn order, and maybe be able to toggle some OST options between original and Reload tracks, but for most fans this will be the definitive version of Persona 3. 

Also a great place to start for anyone who hasn't played a Persona game, despite some mechanics being lost in translation and some fairly sus social link moments Persona 3 is a story about learning how to appreciate life despite its several tragedies and the inevitable approach of death. It's a tale uniquely told by living through the day-to-day life of a Japanese teenager and making connections with the world around you, with characters managing the difficulties of the supernatural Dark Hour in the main story and the difficulties of ordinary life in the social links. As silly as it sounds it's a story that helped me look at fiction and storytelling in a new light, and I'd recommend it to anyone who's even passively interested.

This is my 3rd playthrough of a persona and 2nd review of one. Last review was of persona 4 golden which I gave a 8.5/10. This time I‚Äôm doing persona 3 reload though I will add a little bit of persona 3 portable into the review as well.(fyi my next persona playthrough and review of persona is persona 5 royal in April so stay tuned).without further ado let‚Äôs review:

Story:9/10(the story is phenomenal. The theme of life and death and related topics plays so well in my opinion to the games story. I‚Äôll admit like every persona I‚Äôve played the pacing can be kinda wonky and there was some padded filler dialogue BUTTT it‚Äôs great nonetheless and I am emotionally invested/attached to persona 3).

Setting:8/10(I believe the setting taking place in tatsumi port island is bland yet effective. It‚Äôs a new city it feels vibrant at first but the longer you play the less that magic to it is there. Compared to the small town of inaba which also carry‚Äôs the rank of an 8/10, inaba has a small edge in comparison because everything surrounding inaba compliments it. Tatsumi ports island only really has one area that‚Äôs fine and no other area really mattered.I still loved every minute actually being able to move around in the game unlike in persona 3 portable).

Art:10/10(absolutely stunning. Beautifully made. The use of the unreal engine was great. World design is ravishing and character designs in animated scenes and normal scenes are just great. Nothing more to say, it‚Äôs just pretty much perfect to me). 

Music:10/10(portable and reload have perfect soundtracks. I genuinely listen to the soundtrack pretty much daily. Compared to 4 golden which DOES have an amazing soundtrack there are some tracks I just didn‚Äôt like while persona 3 I simply like them all. The remixes to the popular titles are funky at first but I got used to them and grew to also love them).

Characters:10/10(near perfect cast. Junpei?fun loving idiot that you hate at first but grow to love,Yukari?kind of annoying at first but the more you get to know her the more you can relate to her, sympathize for her and like her,mitsuri?she‚Äôs just perfect,Akihito?meathead who isn‚Äôt 100% dumb and has some fun dialogue,Aigis?perfect and best girl,shinji?pain,ken?pain,koromaru?WHAT THE DOG DOIN?As for the side characters, the social links while overall do lack overall value compared to persona 4 golden BUUUTT seeing as this was Atlus‚Äôs first game with social links persona 3 reload and portable have some memorable social link characters like kazushi,chihiro,maya(if ya know ya know),keisuke,maiko, AND Akinari. All memorable to me and my fav side character social links. I‚Äôll say which main cast social Links are in the game play section).

Battle/fights and gameplay:9/10(oh look, we‚Äôre already in the gameplay section.might as well get social links out of the way. My favorite main cast social links are mitsuru(which I only did in portable,‚ÄòI‚Äôll do hers in new game plus on reload),Aigis and fuuka. The addition of interacting with all your teammates as a pseudo social link also really made me like junpei and Ken more than I did in portable. I can‚Äôt directly speak of male social links in portable cuz I played as the male in portable as well.social links out of the way, here‚Äôs the rest of the gameplay review:WOOOOOOOOOOOOOOOO the fights are fun just like in any persona game. The boss battles are fun and just as great in portable to me and also on par with persona 4 golden which has some great bosses. The hot topic though is Tartarus. I liked the concept of Tartarus in portable but I didn‚Äôt have a lot of fun being in it most of the time, i loved the dungeons in perosna 4 WAYYYY more but in reload? It made me fall in LOVE with how Tartarus look and feel. I just had a great time. Personas themselves are also great design wise and how they work. Using dlc persona‚Äôs we‚Äôre fun, I totally didn‚Äôt use sataneal to ease the grinding(I‚Äôm lying)).

Overall:9.5/10. BEST PERSONA GAME I‚ÄôVE PLAYED YET AND YOU SHOULD TOTALLY BUY IT AND PLAY IT.

Old hands will be disappointed by the difficulty being cut to P5 standards and people who started with 5 will have issues with the fundamental flaws a remake could only band-aid like the bad scheduling system but for the most part, this game is a blast. Has some stuttering issues so haters may want to grab on console/wait for Denuvo to get patched out though.

Since the game is bad at explaining two new additions, I'll explain them:
1)They added pseudo social links with the male party members, you gotta do them quick or they vanish forever and the rewards are smaller but they're mostly at night and still result in you getting a fusion item. I missed Koromaru's on my first run since you just get hinted at it by someone saying he likes to play outside.

2)They added lounge activities with each party member at night, each party member has two they can do (Koromaru's walks don't count, his are TV and brushing him) Doing each activity 3 times with someone results in a major permanent power up such as Yukari's SP cost for healing moves going down to 25%.

a love letter to the original. stays faithful while maintaining it's own identity with the new additions. just the shifting mechanic alone makes the combat so much more enjoyable, and it made the night time actually feel alive and not empty, thank you atlus for this wonderful remake <3

[h3]The Good:[/h3]

Characters don't feel like they revolve around you as the main character. All of the party members grow on their own as the story progresses and it kept me interested in them throughout the whole game. SEES easily tops both P4 and P5's casts due to their own individual character arcs throughout the story. Junpei goes from the classic anime protagonist's best friend troupe to a determined teammate who keeps the mood light after serious events. Never losing the shine of his original personality, but growing into the new responsibilities he now has. All party members have a similar sort of evolution as the story progresses. I love both P4 and P5 but very few characters in those games truly grow out of their gimmicks.

Combat is basically the original P5 combat copy pasted. Baton Pass (now called Shifting) allows for your whole party to combo their abilities in one turn to hit enemy weaknesses. The new combat ability in this game is the 'Theurgy' system. Basically an ultimate attack that all your party members will passively charge as a fight goes on (but can be kept between fights). It's neat. They have beautiful animations, but they're WAY too strong into late game. Like, one-shots most bosses strong. Offensive Theurgies stack with Charge / Concentrate spells + standard buffs and debuffs + Boost and Amp passives if it matches the Theurgy element. Did that make combat boring? Not really. You're not playing a Persona game to experience challenging combat. You play to stack overpowered shit and see how high the numbers go. And the numbers go high.

Moving on to the other half of this game, Social Links are still as good as ever. I enjoyed all of them, but that's completely subjective. However they objectively don't fall behind P4 or P5's stories. Encouraging a classmate and fellow athlete who refuses to accept help for his clearly failing body, helping a dying man find meaning in his last moments, comforting a child through her parents divorce, listening to an anonymous woman rant about her daily life through text chat in an MMO. The many choices are varied and you will most likely find a character you relate to, or just really like. Sadly (and predictably) this game keeps the long-since outdated system in the original P3 of the male party members not having a social link. There are special events where you can hang out with them, and you even unlock new personas at the end of them, however they are not attached to a Social Link and will not give the usual Arcana Burst benefit from it.

Tartarus begins just as dull as you'd think from a randomly generated series of floors. However, Shuffle Time events after combat give you permanent stat boosts and exclusive bonuses through the Major Arcana cards that show up. Then as you climb further up, you unlock new Major Arcana cards that provide new unique bonuses as well. The dungeon evolves and new doors, treasure chests and special shadows start to appear, all of which provide valuable items and advantages.

Persona 3 has the best story of the three hands-down, with all of your main characters tragically involved in the main plot someway or another. It may not have the recognisable antagonists of P5, nor the unique draw of the TV world in P4, but the Dark Hour (and the mysteries surrounding it) surpass the other two games with its twists. Obviously I refuse to spoil any of it. I miraculously avoided spoilers until I finally got to play this game and I want nothing more than for others to have that experience too. Story is always going to be subjective, but I've played all three of these games and this one kept me locked-in the whole way though.

Party members in combat all gain special passive bonuses by hanging out with them in the dorm. Yukari gets reduced costs on her recovery spells, Junpei gives your whole party bonus crit chance, Aigis gives your whole party bonus physical damage etc. Really gives your party their own identity in combat rather than just being there as human shields for the MC.

[h3]The Bad:[/h3]

Not a real issue honestly, but this game is shorter than the other two. P5 on a first playthough took me ~90 hours, P4 around 80. This game I clocked in 65 hours to finish it. A decent amount of that time was spent either AFK or unnecessarily min-maxing persona fusions too. So I'd estimate maybe 55-60 hours actually playing. Still a long game, but I felt the need to mention it just in-case an assumption was made that this game was as long as the other two.

Party level imbalance became a massive issue as I went further into the game. There is a system that is supposed to fix this. There is a chance that a magic clock thing can spawn at the end of a floor that will give your lower level party members XP, and give them a boost up to the MC's level. Issue is that this only does 13 levels at a time. When I'm at level 60, and poor Junpei is chilling below level 20, I'm not going to use this system due to it requiring multiple uses of this clock to push him up to my level. Me, Yukari, Misuru, Aigis. For the whole game. I enjoyed my harem squad but I would have liked to try my other party members out at some point. The game even suggests to you multiple times to swap out party members to account for enemy weaknesses, but I cannot do that without getting boned by the massive level disparity.

Now for actual party imbalance. Yukari and Mitsuru are super busted, Mitsuru was literally out-damaging me for a decent portion of the game (if you've played another Persona game you'd know how insane that is). Yukari's healing allows your whole party to live every attack, and also allows her to spam her Theurgy multiple times per fight due to her healing giving her a huge amount of charge. On the other side, both Ken and Koromaru are too risky to actually use due to them having weaknesses to Curse and Bless respectively. Mudo and Hama insta-kill spells are kind of common among shadows in this game. So although the idea of having a dog and a literal child in my squad crossed my mind at some points, it was just never worth it.

Opening the main menu at any point forces the game back down to 30fps. Not a big deal or anything but it takes a few seconds to get back up to a normal frame rate even after unpausing. It made pausing the game for any reason feel like a chore when I got back to the gameplay. Again, only for a few seconds, but it turns out you have to whip out the menu a lot and it got old real quick.

This game is great, Persona 3 has always been a great game. Ive played nearly every version of the game, i still got the ps2 disc on the shelf and my ps vita as well. They say this is the definitive version, and I can see where they are coming from but in my opinion this game has a few downsides, Personally for me I find the original soundtrack to be better in many ways, don't get me wrong the actual new tracks they added are great but the remix'd tracks are worse in my opinion, I miss the old mass destruction, like loosing a family friend. I thought they would have learned to add a soundtrack toggle after the psp remake and how people were upset over the new songs. They removed a lot of great features like the fatigue system that rewarded the player for actually taking care of themselves, which makes the bathroom useless anymore and the school doctor useless except for 1 side quest. Another interesting oversight for a remake was not adding in the abilities for links like they do in 4/5 so I find that im doing them for ones that seem interesting and for fusion xp and to get a girlfriend. I like the combat, its really easy like persona 5 best strategy is to go into mini bosses with full Theurgy and they literally cant do anything so I end up steamrolling most encounters. They changed shuffle time for some unknown reason? I think it was fine in the originals just be good at knowing when to press the button? Eventually it will become somewhat like persona 4 shuffle and give the ability to pick 2 cards. I really like this version of the game but for me personally if I do decide to replay I will play Portable no offense I just think it sticks toward the original vision for this game, I still believe there is value to this game just like there is for owning the original versions of persona 4 and 5, sure they may be differences but they can provide a different way to experience a game just like reload.

My first Persona Game was P5 Royal on the Switch. After not saving and losing around 5 hours of progress I stepped away from the game and haven't picked it up since. When i heard this game was releasing I was ecstatic. i can get back into the series without the thought of having to deal with regaining progress. And I'm glad I did. I love this game. I haven't been able to put it down for the past week. And it made me want to pick P5R back up and play again. I highly recommend playing this. I've already convinced 3 of my friends to buy it as well.

Persona 3 Reload is what i would like to call a "Faithful Re-imagining of The Original 2006 Persona 3" and all i got to say is That this Game is (In my Eyes) a Masterpiece and a game that Should Raised the gold standard of not only JRPGs or RPGs but How you write a Tragic But Amazingly Well Written Story. The New QOL Changes and Features for things such as for Character Interactions and General Gameplay have Been things that should have been in the original Like How It actually gives you a choice to romance a Love interest and now doesn't force you to go down the love route (Which should have been in the original in the first Place but Okay Atlus). The New combat features such as shifting (Which was ported over from Persona 5) and the new Theregy system is quite fitting and fun to play and experiment with. The graphics and Ui design has always been incredible sense Persona 5 but Reloads new graphical changes are still fitting to Persona 3 art style but now better to look at and absolutely Freaking Beautiful. Im not going to explain things like the ending because the story and the good ending are incredible and the ending still makes me cry more than it did back in 2006 and the messages it makes are more important and fitting now more that ever. This Game is a Masterpiece, go buy it or wait for a Sale. Its one of the best games i have ever played.

I have been a fan of Persona since Persona 4 on the VITA. Having beaten P4 and P5 and with over 200 hours in both games, I was keen to find out what happened in the famed 3rd entry. This remake is simply Persona 3 with all the advances of P5. Only 25 hours in, this is a polished gem of a JRPG, elevating turn based combat to the next level, much better paced than nearly every other JRPG out there, with interesting characters and a plot that I want to unfold. Perfect game to play on the Steam Deck. If you like JRPGs, this is simply one of the best out there.

Rather than a negative review, this is more of a mixed review.

I was a bit skeptical of the remake, so I wanted to hold off my excitement of reviewing a remake of one of my favourite stories in a game of all time to have an objective review. I waited till I finished the final boss and experienced the good ending before I said something. 

You can tell this was made by people who genuinely care for the Persona 3 IP and not some soulless remake. The conditions for social links are still strict, the themes and stories are still very much the same, the gameplay and everything has been given a lot of quality of life improvements, though in the case of Tartarus I haven't quite felt it was really that big of an improvement. There is a lot of mention about Tartarus dialogue and all that, but it's more akin to Persona 5's mementos chatter than the interactions that you could have in Persona 3 Portable (talking to the members by interaction in Tartarus).

Gameplay wise, I have no qualms. In fact, it surpasses previous iterations of Persona 3 in that aspect.

However; in terms of the story, I feel differently. I very much disagree with a lot of the story elements. The soundtrack was done by an apprentice of Shoji Meguro. Yumi Kawamura isn't returning for vocals (she's pretty old so I don't blame her for not being able to hit the same chords as she used to) and they have a new singer named Azumi Takahashi on board. But I personally don't really mind that as they both have proven to be able to make songs when they are new content. (eg. It's Going Down Now)
Not to also mention Lotus Juice, who has the midas touch when it comes to Persona music.

I mention the soundtrack is due to the fact that although it sounds fine as it is, it does not have the same impact as the original version. When fighting the final boss of the game, the music is a lot more... muted as compared to the original soundtrack. I can't go into much into specifics out of respect for people who don't wish to be spoiled. In fact, I'd go as far as to even say it feels more 'persona 5-ish' in the newer tracks, which I know some people are fine with. I'm unfortunately the annoying crowd that prefers the old J-pop feeling of Persona 3. I like some of the remixes, but some of them are just not... for me, which is the nicest way of putting it. 

Not only that, but in the ending, there are flashbacks to the whole game as if the game was spelling it out for you that this was your journey. In the older iterations of Persona 3, there was no flashbacks and simply just an intimate scene where there is only dialogue. In my opinion, that's more effective as it makes the player think of the journey they had rather than having the game spelling it out for you. 

Next, I can mention without much spoilers is the MC awakening his persona scene. When he awakens his persona, the shots are too clear as compared to the chaotic angles and shots of the original and FES. When another persona appears from inside Orpheus; in the original version he tears out of Orpheus like a beast, while in Reload, Orpheus literally deflates like a balloon and is stretched open. I'm not going to say which is in my opinion more interesting, but you can infer my feelings pretty easily on your own. 

I'm of the opinion that small attention to details always add up to the bigger picture. It matters to me how things are presented. In my opinion, this seems more in the direction Persona 5 has in its art direction and storytelling style. I understand that it's to get new fans into Persona 3, but I feel like this made it lose Persona 3's individuality to cater to them.

To spell it out like Persona 3 Reload; the remake, while telling the same story as the previous iterations of Persona 3, doesn't have the same impact and effect as the originals in terms of story due to changes like these. 

It's a little bit forgivable as they do not have the old team on board as they're on board working on Metaphor: ReFantazio, though this led to the original vision being muddied in between despite having the apprentices, in my personal opinion.

Due to this, it's also hard for me to recommend this game narrative wise to a person who wishes to enjoy Persona 3's story for what it is, it's not worth it at $70 dollars if you are like me and care about the story. 

But, if you're not iffy about things like that, go get the game. A review like mine won't stop you from getting it anyway. 



TLDR: It's a remake done by people who care about the original IP, but the original people who made the said IP aren't on board. The impact of the story and everything about it is lesser than previous iterations. 

I find it quite hard to recommend it to people personally because of how much the previous iterations of Persona 3's approach to their message about finding meaning in life that resonated with me. The impact of the message, however, isn't there in Reload. 

So, if you want to experience Persona 3 at its best(in terms of presentation), I'd recommend playing FES or Portable (even doe people call it the cheap mobile version of p3 or even p3 the visual novel).
This game has so much charm it could start Yukari's social link.

I don't think I'll ever truly be capable of assigning words and meaning to what Shin Megami Tensei - Persona 3 means to me. This game is more than an experience but something that enraptured a solid fragment of my soul. This game does and has done more for me than any film, book, piece of art or life experience has. No matter when, be it my darkest hour or my brightest day, Persona 3 not only lifts me up but fills me with the will to live and the will to keep on living.

I first played Persona 3 FES in my most formative years, the years where my deepest depression had taken hold and I simply lived, wandering aimlessly. And being a JRPG fan I got an emulated copy (something I have since rectified, though I don't have a PS2). I stayed up night after night until 4am even when I had school in the morning because these people, my companions whom I fought in the Dark Hour with meant much more than many friendships I had yet and since. Defeating Nyx had far more importance to me than exams or colleges.

And now, in another dark time of my life Persona 3 Reload graced me, lifting me up once more and giving me the courage to SEES the day. Jolly good show.

Just a warning for people coming in for the first time: the first half of the game is fucking [i]miserable[/i]. This is still the case in Reload. The second half of the game is excellent, but just consider if you really wanna sink 24 hours of soul-crushing boredom and awkward pacing into it in order to get there before you buy.
Giving this a positive review just for the second half (and because it's genuinely surreal that they actually remade the game) but I'd give it a "mixed" if I could.

I absolutely hate remakes. Especially from Atlus. They can't help but to shove in unnecessary content that takes away from the original story and themes. The original Persona 3 was my favorite game of all time. Worst possible combination, right?

Yet somehow, no... Atlus has managed to craft an experience that manages to surpass the original in nearly every sense. I've played the OG seven times now and obsess over even the smallest details such as unnamed NPCs around town. This is all to emphasize that I cannot even begin to explain how Atlus managed to include touches I think even some of the biggest Persona 3 lovers could miss, yet make the larger experience as a whole leagues better.

The story of Persona 3 is in a league of its own. The themes are deeply profound and impactful. As the credits finished rolling and I was sent to the title screen, I couldn't help but to call my parents and tell them how much I loved them. 

Please, do yourself a favor and play this game. This is something everyone should experience in their lives.

I've been waiting for this!


Atlus kinda knocked it out of the park with this remake tbh. I expected P3R to be brilliant but its surpassed almost every expectation for me. Femc and The Answer epilogue are sadly absent here, but at least we getting one of those as dlc in the future. The tartarus grind does eventually feel a bit tedious still, but there's a lot of improvements that alleviate that feeling and ensure it stays fresh for much longer compared to before. In terms of positive changes overall in P3R, there's too many to list all of them, but I'll highlight some noteworthy ones below.

The new VA's are outstanding. I'll admit I had some doubts about Atlus' decision to get a completely new cast, but each VA gives at least 100% here. Every party member gives nuanced and passionate performances that made me laugh, cheer, and cry in P3R. Zeno Robinson as Junpei is particularly amazing.

The visuals are stunning and a massive step up from FES as you'd expect. The animation work in particular is astonishingly detailed even in small and subtle ways. Seriously just take a moment to watch your friends in the Iwatodai Dorm now and again. I never thought I would be so captivated by watching someone sitting on a couch eating pocky. 
When it comes to character portraits, they're not drawn by Soejima Shigenori this time i believe, but they are absolutely gorgeous and do a great job conveying each character's personality.

There are many, many more opportunities to spend time with party members, regardless of whether they have social links. This is a hugely appreciated addition that does wonders in fleshing out characters that felt somewhat neglected in P3 FES.

Much appreciated introductions of new mechanics to spice up both gameplay and story.
From theurgies, computer software, randomly spawning challenge doors in tartarus, ways to quickly level up neglected party members, etc. There are a lot of new changes that vastly improve upon the now dated gameplay of FES.

The gross transphobic content from operation babe hunt was fully removed. Not just in the US region version of the game, but in every version. Props for that Atlus! Considering your decades long record of queerphobic content in your games, I didn't think you had it in you. If Persona 4 ever gets a similar remake, it could certainly benefit from a similar adjustment.

And then theres the music. There was never really any doubt that the music would be great in a Persona game but wow. This OST pays respects to the original tracks and evolves them in ways that make sense and feel fresh and fun. There's a handful of tracks here that are up there with the very best in the series for me. Color Your Night is some once-in-a-lifetime magical lightning in a jar type shit. Absolutely sublime.


Overall, P3R is a spectacular effort from Atlus and is now the arguably definitive version of Persona 3. It improves upon so much, yet retains every aspect that makes P3 something so very special. This is an absolutely essential jrpg that must be experienced.

Overall, it's a great game. I enjoyed the battles, and Tartarus is surprisingly fun to play. The soundtrack is great (the only complaint is that you can't play the Digital Premium Edition soundtrack in the background), and the graphics are a significant improvement from P5R.

However, this probably is an unpopular opinion, but I find the game very slow-paced at the beginning. It didn't captivate me well for the first couple of months in the game, and I only continued because I had heard that the story improves later on (which it does, but I couldn't help but feel a bit bored initially). So, although I still recommend the game, be aware that its pace and story might not appeal to everyone.

[h1][b]Persona 3 Reload[/b][/h1]

[b]Rating: 8/10 - Great[/b]

[b]Persona 3 Reload[/b] is a [b]Great[/b] game. After playing it I could finally appreciate the [b]Persona 3[/b] story since, at least for me, the absolutely disgusting-looking visual novel sections of [b]Persona 3 Portable[/b] ruined my first experience with it and made me tune out. There are a few pacing issues in the story in my opinion and I do wish that [spoiler]Strega[/spoiler] had more screen time, but otherwise it's almost on par with [b]Persona 4 Golden[/b] and surpasses [b]Persona 5 Royal[/b]. There are also many really well written S.Links in the game, but sadly the ones that aren't good tend to be either boring or straight up terrible.

The gameplay changes made were also very good. The changes made to the look of the different Tartarus floors really helped with the feel of exploration and the additions to combat were all [b]Great[/b] in my opinion, I was especially fond of the Theurgy attacks. My only gripe with the gameplay would be that they didn't add the Shuffle Time from [b]Persona 4 Golden[/b], since I very much prefer that.

Overall, for me at least, this turned out to be a better version of [b]Persona 5 Royal[/b], more interesting characters, better combat (even if the differences are barely noticeable), a better dungeon crawling experience and an overall better story.

Keep in mind, I have never played the original Persona 3 in any of its forms, so this is my first introduction to the storyline and characters from this game.

I love this game. This is one of the first games I've purchased on PC so soon after its release, and I have to say that first off, this is incredibly well optimized for PC. Mind you, I'm running it with a Ryzen 5 2600x and a 1060, and while high settings chug a little bit at the mall, medium settings don't look much different to me from high settings and run everything perfectly fine at 1080p. Great optimizing on Atlus' part.

Storyline and characters are great too. The visuals are awesome, combat is something new that I haven't experienced before, and overall I'm having a blast. Highly recommend this to anybody looking into getting into Persona, as this has hooked me and I'm not getting off of this train any time soon. The $70 pricetag is a bit steep in my opinion, so maybe wait for a sale, but I'm having an awesome time playing this and cannot recommend it enough.

An incredible experience I'll never forget, probably my favorite Persona game now. This is one of the most beautiful games I've ever played, I can see why people have been impacted by this game's story. There's a lot to learn from this game, and a lot to love. Every facet of the story and it's social links make you ponder on different aspects of life, often painful but meaningful. I wish I played it earlier but I'm glad I did now, this is a very special game. Play it and learn something new about yourself, about life.

As a long time fan of Persona 3, and someone who has played both FES and Portable, I waited to review this game until I got into more of the new content exclusive to this version of the game to see what would truly set it apart, and I must say, Reload has blown my expectations out of the water. Atlus remakes are (were) always plagued by baffling changes to things that were better off before, but I can confidently say that this is a remake made by people who truly understand the weight and meaning of the original, and they have done a damn fine job bringing it up to modern standards. I adore the original game, but there were definitely areas where it lacked. Its flaws were a product of its time, and those flaws no longer exist in Reload. The new story content is phenomenal, and perfectly compliments the story of the original without stepping on its toes or undermining it at all. Besides the story content, the quality of life features brought to the core gameplay are everything I could have asked for, both in battle and in social life. I've written this review from the perspective of a long time fan, and I am 100% confident that the game holds up from that perspective, but I would also like to say I am confident that Reload would also be a phenomenal entry to the series. All in all, this is truly one of, if not the best game Atlus has made.

Atlus did an amazing job at making this remake feel extremely faithful to the original game while adding QOL and new features that only improve on the original PS2 and FES experience.

I liked it and I truly see while despite its predecessors this is widely considered to be the true start of Persona as we know it.
To be as spoiler free as possible the general theme of this game is impeccable its a simple message they want you to take away, live your life to the fullest because time is finite, you need to decide what life really means to you and live it in the way that's best for you. Its simple yet beautiful and I would recommend this game off that alone to anyone who is interested in a heavier topic like that.
Aside from that the story of this game, and whats happening is deeply intriguing, just what if there was something in our day to day life we never knew about, and what wait does that carry? I found myself really enjoying this thought and delivery through its cast of characters, even when originally I would scoff and go "I don't really like (insert name)" I spent time with them all and, by the end I found I had stopped because even those I didn't relate to I grew to understand and I think that is what anyone would want when spending so many hours with a character, I simply can't do each of them enough justice without major spoilers but they're great and all have their own roles and stories that grow as you play.
As for gameplay this is greatly improved from the original especially Tartarus which while I found it to be a slog at some points even in a modern adaptation, the updates to combat, things like scouting, and a lot of the games systems smoothed the climb out massively. I would still say in terms of strictly gameplay I think Persona 5 has best moment to moment combat, however this is not far off, and what it lacks in its gameplay it makes up for in what I would consider to be a stronger story. There is simply no way to make something like Tartarus fun all the time just due to what it is but this was a step in the right direction and made it at very least much more enjoyable. As always Atlus tops this off with beautiful UI that simply nobody else makes, some people will argue if its better or worse than the original but that doesn't really matter, both are great.
I do want to say this just for any purchasing concerns because that is a reality when it comes to anything like this, and especially now that games are starting to be 70 USD base, if you are someone who either likes the charm of, or doesn't mind a lot of the grit of an older game Persona 3 Portable is completely fine and good, but if you want the fresh coat of paint, or just want to play the remake, which I will say this is a well done and honest remake, then I think this game is a worthy purchase. If you judge off time to finish alone you will easily make the mark because Atlus makes long games, and I personally would rather pay that for a extremely long game than something I can easily finish in 15-25 hours. I think this is worth it in the end for the price, obviously that is up to every individual but I would still recommend it despite the price.
Overall this game is great, the story is amazing and if it that is what you're playing it for you won't be disappointed, the gameplay while not perfect is still great, and despite what people may say the remade music is still impeccable, the soundtrack as a whole was great. If Atlus continues to make games of this quality I am excited to see where they go. If you have the money and the time I would say this game is worth playing.
I think the most honest way I can rate this game is like this, what I want from a game is when its done and I get up, what does it makes me think, what does it make me feel, what is it trying to tell me and does it accomplish that. This game checks all of those boxes and is solid throughout, I liked it.

Persona 3 was one of the first JRPGs I played and was hooked immediately back then when I was younger and that only kindled a love for JRPGs afterwards, looking into what made P3 stand out from the other Persona and SMT games made me appreciate it even more for having such a dark and immersive world I could just get lost in. However I can't say that P3Reloaded did the same, the game is beautiful and the gameplay is smooth, but it lacks what made it stand out from the others, it's identity is mostly washed away for the sake of being more like P5, from the models taken from P5 to the remixed tracks and even the inclusion of a baton pass system, it genuinely feels like they took what made P3 unique and just shoved it under the rug. I will still say that if this were to be cheaper it's definitely worth, but unless you plan on dropping 70$ for this game I can't recommend it.

As a passionate teen gamer, I recently dove into the world of Persona 3 Reload, and let me tell you, it's an absolute blast! From the captivating storyline to the unique blend of gameplay elements, this game has quickly become a favorite in my collection.

Engaging Storyline:
Persona 3 Reload weaves an intricate and emotionally charged narrative that had me hooked from the get-go. The storyline is filled with unexpected twists, heart-wrenching moments, and a cast of characters that feel like friends you've known forever. The game tackles some deep and meaningful themes that resonate with the challenges of being a teenager, making it not just a game but a profound experience.

Stylish Visuals and Design:
One word: stylish. The visual aesthetic of Persona 3 Reload is simply stunning. From the character designs to the unique Persona creatures, the game oozes with a sense of cool that sets it apart. The animated cutscenes are a visual feast, and the attention to detail in the environments adds an extra layer of immersion to the overall experience.

Innovative Gameplay Mechanics:
The fusion of social simulation and dungeon crawling in Persona 3 Reload is nothing short of genius. Balancing school life with battling Shadows creates a dynamic and engaging experience. The Persona summoning system adds a layer of strategy to combat, keeping every encounter fresh and exciting. Plus, the integration of the calendar system adds a real sense of time pressure, making every decision count.

Memorable Soundtrack:
The music in Persona 3 Reload is an absolute banger! The eclectic mix of genres, from J-pop to hip-hop, sets the perfect mood for every situation. The soundtrack has a way of enhancing the emotional impact of key moments, making them even more memorable. I often find myself humming the tunes even when I'm not playing.

Replay Value:
With multiple story paths, social links, and the addictive nature of the gameplay, Persona 3 Reload offers incredible replay value. Each playthrough feels like a new adventure, and the decisions you make genuinely impact the outcome. It's the kind of game that keeps you coming back for more.

In conclusion, Persona 3 Reload is a masterpiece that caters perfectly to the tastes of teen gamers. It's a rollercoaster of emotions, a visual spectacle, and a gameplay experience that's hard to put down. Whether you're a seasoned Persona fan or a newcomer to the series, this game is a must-play for anyone looking for a fantastic JRPG experience.

I never got to play this game when I was younger, but being able to experience the modern adaptation of this game with quality-of-life and game play overhauls makes me optimistic for the future of my favorite game series. I love the story, art, and feel of this game... and it reminds me of how Pokemon (when it was good) would release modernized versions of previous games. Between the hype in the community and the quality of the game getting better and better, there is no doubt this game series is in an absolute golden age. I am hoping that some of the feedback received can be applied to improving future iterations of the series much like how the implementation of agile played a huge part in improving the seemingly flawless Persona 5 into Persona 5 Royal. 

KEEP EXECUTING THIS:

1. After 5 different installments into the series, all confidants and their social links are voiced (except the hermit, but it adds to impressiveness considering you are texting the hermit the entire time).

2. Staying true to the original concept of the franchise makes be believe Altus is among the most humble of studios. My favorite part of the franchise is the element of psychology that connects you with the characters in the game world. Finding your place is challenging, but being able relate to Carl Jung‚Äôs persona archetype system each game really adds value to the game as well as the team‚Äôs reputation. Compared to many modern studios, Atlus stays true to the dynamic between its original business model and value to the consumer. 

3. Graphics. I don‚Äôt really need to say much about this because it‚Äôs iconic, but the UI designers are extremely talented. When I was at SCAD, most game art majors would reference persona as the most iconic art in any series of games. 

AREAS OF IMPROVEMENT:

1. The game can improve on a few elements... Outside the main cast, it would appear many of the NPCs are lifeless. This is one of my biggest issues with this game, and by far it is the most noticeable in the club. 

2. Some quality of life updates from Royal were neglected. I really enjoyed being able to negotiate enemies, and I do realize that this is a remake of Persona 3... But I can't help but feel it was still something that could have been added. This does not quite take away from the experience of the game, but I am hoping that future installments of the game can have the negotiation tactics in the series. 

3. It starts off extremely slow, and while it picks up later, usually hooking in the viewer is crucial to story telling. I realize of course this is a remake, so I am hoping the next installment in the franchise can have a quicker tutorial than prior entries.
YES.

Did Persona 3 NEED to be remade? Absolutely not. But the additions really do heighten the experience and while some changes are slightly disappointing, Reload is still a beautiful re-imagining of Persona 3 and left me feeling the same as the original and perfectly captured its themes, such a inspiring and hopeful experience.

I wanna preface this by saying that I've only played through the portable remaster and exclusively the female route, so don't look for too many comparisons between this and the original male route. 

With that said, this game is like a solid 9/10 for me. I've played through Persona 4 Golden, Persona 5, Persona 5 Royal. Unlike those games, it runs on an entirely new engine, the Unreal Engine. As a first attempt for Atlus, the game looks beautiful visually - at least in the sense of still retaining that Persona artstyle while looking new and fancy. This is probably the strongest game in the series when it comes to its theme. Otherwise, it's a little lacking in multiple areas - but well-rounded enough that it bounces back. 

Storywise, the game has a great focus on the theme of death, which can always go wrong in a variety of ways. For the most part, if you have played the original Persona 3, there is absolutely no big story changes. This a one-to-one faithful remake of the original, with recreated visuals and added flair. There may be some added scenes here and there to elaborate on certain story points. Atlus also added plenty of character moments to help the team you're apart of feel more cohesive. If you're new here, the game will do plenty to keep your intrigue - but don't expect some god-tier writing from Baldur's Gate 3 or something. This time around, the characters feel less like they're there to rub your ego and more like their own individuals that will even clash with your decisions. There are new link episodes for primarily the male party members that vastly improve upon their lacking presence in the original games. These add plenty of character building and more emotional weight to the story for those characters specifically. 

For gameplay, this is the same formula used in most Persona games. You summon demons in all sorts of mythology from different aspects of your personality called "Persona" to kill shadows. It plays somewhat like a dungeon crawling pokemon game, but it's a lot more complex than that. When you're not fighting the enemy shadows, you're living your daily life and making friends. More friends is good, since it'll boost your personas' abilities while even letting you unlock higher tiered ones. If you're worried that all of previous games' QoL are gone and nowhere to be seen, have no fear, since almost every single mechanic from the newer games have made the transition. You can actually reject and turn down romantic interests without breaking their social link now. All characters have a new ultimate mechanic called "Theurgy", speeding up battles immensely. You can pass on turns to other teammates when you hit enemies' weaknesses, there's a somewhat convoluted autosave mechanic, there's plenty of different ways to boost your social stats for some of those requirements later on, and everything in the game is quick and abbreviated. It knows that it's a pretty long game and won't make you sit through hours of animations to get to the action. Even the infamous railroading at the start of Persona games is pretty absent here. You get into the freetime around the hour and a half mark. 

The voicework and OST are amazing. If you play in Japanese dub, the voices suit all of the characters. If you play in English dub, some of the voices may sounds a little grating at times - but to be honest Persona dubs are always relatively decent, this one especially. I swapped between the two to keep dungeon-grinding a little fresh. Between this and AI Somnium Files, the English dubs in both are pretty decent enough to consider if you have the option between Japanese and English. The OST got a whole makeover, whilst still retaining the important key parts of their original counterparts. The new vocalist does an amazing job, but in my opinion - she does far better vocals on the newer songs. While listening to some of the tracks play out in-game, it sounded like some of them lacked the impact and tenacity that the original tracks did. That's not to say she did a bad job, even then, the songs still sound great. However, the new vocalist has a more soothing voice that's suited to the more somber songs in-game.

The UI is something to die for. Although, it was a little disappointing that they decided not to go with some of their original concepts (since those would be more thematically appropriate), the game has so much flair and style that it doesn't matter. This is best UI from any persona game ever, with Persona 5 Royal's being in close second. 

All said, some gripes or things I didn't like about the game:

1. No way to turn of motion blur in-game. (I know there's a workaround on PC, but this should've just been added in regardless)

2. Personal gripe - Tartarus (Main in-game dungeon) gets super dull after a while - with samey environments for 20-30 floors at a time. 

3. Some of the Theurgies (Specifically MC's) feel very underwhelming and experimental - rather than polished.

4. Social Links are the EXACT same, so some of them are very...controversial to say the least. If you didn't like the social links in the original, you will not like them anymore here. (Same just with FULL voicework). 

5. There are not many in-game engine cutscenes, which is a HUGE shame in my opinion. These look way better than the anime cutscene style that they tend to shoe-horn into the games, but that is ESPECIALLY the case here. The new in-game engine looks so nice that it's a waste that they decided not to animate more scenes with it.

All in all, this game is worth the price point if you're a longtime persona fan. 70$ is a little steep if you're a newcomer. You might not like a lot of the game's themes and topics. If you can't buy into the anime wackiness and tropes, this isn't the game for you. If you hate JRPG grinding, this ALSO isn't the game for you. I would nab the game on a sale of 50-60$ if any of the above apply to you. As much as I love Persona games, I have to admit, ALOT of the writing is pretty poor and struggles when compared to modern writing in videogames. I've loved these games for decades, but at the end of the day it's just an anime power fantasy with an overdone highschool setting.

For those who have played Persona 3: FES, This is not a replacement for that game. FES is still, in my own opinion, the Definitive edition of Persona 3. 

As a standalone, however, this does well to introduce new players to a modernized version of the game that set the series into it's current form (high-school students combat Shadows). While some bits have been cut or altered, nothing vital to the narrative is missing beyond the Second story line from FES, the Answer, which is rumored to be coming as DLC and ties up some threads left at the end of the game. in return, new events have been added, that flesh out your team members that don't get Social Links, and new mechanics have been implemented to shake up the combat. Tartarus' design has been totally re-worked, it seems, to go with the updated visuals for everything. 
 It does feel shorter than the Original or FES, I did a 100% run in 54 hours. 

Most if not all of the Social Links are now Voiced all throughout the story, which I don't believe was the case for FES, only certain important lines were. On the flip side, many scenes that were animated are now converted into FMVs, which can be disappointing in some places, but also fits well in others. 

The UI feels a bit rushed in places. the Time transition screen is in particular incredibly basic, only showing two solid blue bars meant to imitate clock hands. I also had some stuttering that I don't get on more graphically demanding games, which I feel can be attributed to the ever-maligned Denuvo software. 

The DLC packs are wholly unneeded, only adding new Personas from other titles and costumes, so for those not interested in them, they can be skipped. The Soundtrack is also somewhat aggravating, being integrated into it's own software, instead of just being audio files to be played. 

The dialogue (using the English Voices) was mostly solid, thought there were some spots that felt a bit awkward to listen to, the VAs seem to fit their characters well enough, and did not sound like they were just reading lines or phoning it in. 

While I feel this game could have done with some more polishing, It is still a solid Persona game for first timers to the series. people who never had the chance to play the games on the PS2 will be able to enjoy this fine, and for those who have played, may be able to enjoy the nostalgia while seeing some new events and dialogue.

The game has some performance issues on the Steam Deck, but it's not totally unplayable. 

EDIT: As of 2/7/2024 with the Proton hotfix the game holds 60 FPS much more consistently. There are still some areas in Tartarus (such as the 2nd block) that has areas that will dip into the mid 40's and the Velvet Room that will fluctuate between mid 50's to 60.

First thing before you start the game, turn OFF reflections. This tanks FPS in a few areas such as the mall area. 

Even then, FPS will fluctuate wildly. The annoying part is the game will run 60 FPS in most parts of the game EXCEPT the following:

Tartarus (certain sections near the windows tanks FPS to the 30s). The 2nd level of Tartarus occasionally dips to the high 20's specifically in the one room layout with the 2nd floor path. 
Velvet Room (the Velvet Room elevator will go past lights every now and then, and these will briefly tank FPS down to the mid 20s)
Dorm Bedroom (this place is at 40 FPS for some reason)

There is a config.ini "fix" to totally disable raytracing (even after you disable reflections ingame), but this doesn't seem to fix anything. 

If you're so inclined, set the frame limit ingame to 30 FPS with reflections turned OFF. The game will always maintain this framerate except for the brief dips to 20 in the Velvet Room as it passes by the lights. 

The game itself is fantastic, but I'm waiting for a performance update patch from Atlus.

[h1] PERSONA 3 RELOAD is an amazing remaster of my favourite and in my opinion the best persona game.[/h1]

[h3]The gameplay has been vastly improved from FES and makes it more alike P4G and P5R.[/h3]
The added character interactions are very welcome and make the game feel so much more personal, [b]being able to hang out more with the male cast and Koromaru is great.[/b]
The music is pretty good! The new tracks fit in quite well and while Azumi Takahashi (The vocalist for the Reload songs) is [b]still great[/b] in her own right, nothing can truly compare to Yumi Kawamura and her style (on the FES tracks). [b]We still get Lotus Juice[/b] saying literally anything and it sounding great!
The voice acting for all social link events is very welcome as it [b]adds a new dimension[/b] to them.
[b]Tartarus is breathtaking[/b] to scale and the added and reworked events in there are awesome.

[h3]Playing the game on Merciless difficulty felt similar to playing FES however the game is significantly easier to beat as [/h3]
Dark attacks and Light attacks no longer being just Instakills and [b]having their own attacks[/b],
[b]Theurgy moves[/b] (Special attacks) being a thing,
And [b]Shifting[/b] (Baton passing from P5).
[h3] Personally I didn't have too much of an issue with any of the bosses on this difficulty but that could probably change. [/h3]

[h3]As of writing this, the only things I find to be a let down:[/h3]
The music is good in some areas a step down in others.
Some of the Fusion spells are missing which is a shame.
[b]No FES' Answer or Portable's Kotone[/b] (FemMC) is a let down but hopefully those will be fixed through DLC and hopefully not another release lmao.
Some of the stuff they change is a tad weird

[h1]Overall I really enjoyed being able to experience this game again, Cried just as hard as I did the first time.[/h1]

I'm a huge fan of persona, and this game has delivered in every way I could have hoped for it to. It still feels like the original persona 3 did, but now that it's been updated it's far more rewarding to play and I feel more invested in it than I ever did in FES or Portable. As well as quality of life updates, the music is the best it's ever been in the series (the new track for nighttime exploration is my favourite) and tartarus feels more involved and interesting.
I've been playing on steam deck as well as desktop, and I'm really happy with the performance on both. You may notice some slight performance issues on deck at first, but that can be fixed by going into the config menu's graphics settings and turning reflections off (which doesn't actually turn off reflections, it just turns off ray tracing from what I understand).
Overall, I really recommend this game to anyone considering getting it. It doesn't disappoint!

Theres not really a good way to put it into words but.
Persona 3, the original, was my favorite game ever made. It was and still is, very important to my childhood development, my outlook on things, as well as a fantastic teacher to me.
Reload, not only captured that magic once again, but playing through the story as an adult really changed my entire perception of it all, its meanings, its story. Its characters. Looking at it all through a matured lense is a new experience tbh.
The facelift, the QoL, the gameplay mechanics are all VASTLY improved, which is all the game needed tbh. Coulda done just the graphic update and not gave the new stuff/remove fatigue and I woulda loved it
As for the music, while the remixed tracks didnt originally thrill me, nor the new VA's.
I grew to love them just as much, if not more than the original.
Memories of You's new rendition is a big highlight. Honestly its near perfect.
Score? Fuck idk if the game qualifies to be scored.

The original Persona 3 has always had a soft spot in my heart. I played the original PS2 game back in 2007 when I was 11 years old with my two older sisters. I can honestly say that this remake was everything that I wanted in a remaster of Persona 3. (Although hopefully The Answer + female protagonist option will eventually come as DLC). 

If you liked the other persona games, then you'll love this one as well. While I adored Persona 4 & 5's silliness, I preferred Persona 3 because it was darker / more mature and because of its focus on characterization.

Persona 3 Reload are the best parts of what made the original Persona 3 so iconic with its story, characters, and soundtrack while incorporating all of the graphical and quality-of-life improvements that ATLUS has learned through the years, culminating in Persona 5 Royal, being meshed together into a extremely enjoyable, updated version of P3.

Yes, P3 Reload are missing some features of previous iterations (for better or worse) and it is not absolutely perfect, but its additions (like the Theurgy system) are very welcome features in which I hope to see in future Persona games.

The bottom line is that if you are a newer fan of Persona, being introduced to the series with P5/P5R, this is a great addition to your digital Persona game library. Older fans may have gripes with added/removed features, but overall, this is one of the superior versions of Persona 3 available.

Original Post: The original is one of my favorite games. This is a pretty flawless remake of a masterpiece with modern quality of life changes. If you like Persona or Shin Megami Tensei games, you'll love this.

Edit after completing the game and 95% of the achievements: I stand by everything I said before. The game is great and the quality of life changes are superb. The UI is snappy and immersive, the new music fits in seamlessly with the original music, the new character art is exceptional, and the game plays so smooth that its almost unbelievable.
The story is amazing and left largely untouched save for the addition of new social elements that feel like they've always been there. The story is also darker than most of the other Persona games, which I personally love.
The changes to Tartarus are also great. In the other versions of the game it could get to be a slog on the higher floors, but they've added enough mechanics and detours that it stays pretty fresh the whole way through. I did feel like the additions made the game a little easier, but the inclusion of Merciless right out of the gate compensates for that pretty well.
All in all, I cannot recommend this game enough if you are a fan of Persona, Shin Megami Tensei, or just story-heavy jRPGs in general.

To all of the people online that are complaining about the lack of The Answer and the Female Main Character, I get it, but if you look at the credits list for modern games and stop to realize just how many people and how much money it takes in 2024 to make a long-form story oriented game, you will begin to understand why The Answer will probably be a DLC down the road and the Female Main Character won't happen. When a company like ATLUS is remaking a game, they can't always bank on massive sales to cover those costs. It is a bummer, but that's just how the world of games works now.

This review is not for the hardcore Persona fans. It's bound to be incredibly unpopular, and I accept your Jester points with open arms. 

I‚Äôve been recommended the Persona franchise and specifically Persona 3 for years by people whose opinions I trust. With the release of Persona 3 Reload, I figured this would be the optimal time to try out those folks‚Äô recommendation. 

Personally, it‚Äôs just not for me. The characters are all extremely tired anime tropes at this point. Japan‚Äôs obsession with high school aged students is just beyond me. The shared trauma between the cast is all incredibly predictable and the framing of the game‚Äôs story through the lens of high school and the clubs activities that are part of high school somehow cheapens everything, as this kind of plot anchor has been so commoditized by anime.

The game is mostly walking around, being presented with walls of text, and building up your ‚Äúsocial links‚Äù. This treats the player as almost infantile as the interactions here are so sterile and on rails that daytime game play might as well be a 20 minute episode of an anime that you just watch rather than play. At night, you can enter Tartarus, the portion of the game that‚Äôs fully ray-traced, a procedurally generated dungeon that really doesn‚Äôt have any particular variety and goes on and on, similar corridor after similar corridor. I don‚Äôt think combat even exists outside of this one location, and unfortunately it‚Äôs such a humdrum experience due to the lack of inspired design that I can‚Äôt image playing 70 hours of crawling around this single solitary dungeon. 

The art and design of the Personas themselves, the monsters you collect and summon, are very cool. I wish this game had more emphasis on them and the combat itself. It seems like more of an afterthought to the social and daytime systems, however. You will spend most of the game outside of combat and outside of Tartarus in general. I do believe there are specific things you have to do outside of Tartarus to get certain Personas, but I‚Äôm not sure.

The music of Persona is incredible, as everyone parrots again and again. I‚Äôm not an original Persona fan and I‚Äôve been listening to Persona 5‚Äôs OST for years on and off. It‚Äôs just damn good music. 

If you‚Äôre new to the series, aren‚Äôt a very big fan of modern anime, and are curious if this game is for you, it probably isn‚Äôt. There‚Äôs not much new going on here that hasn‚Äôt been done time and time again, and I have to wonder if all the praise comes from people who don‚Äôt consume much media outside of Japan. There are better stories in games to be told with more depth, better gameplay, and less tired tropes. 

*As an side, this game is also currently very broken on Steam Deck, despite being Steam Deck verified. There are areas of the game where single digit frame rates are all that‚Äôs possible. There‚Äôs allegedly a Proton  fix coming, but the fact that this is ‚Äúverified‚Äù is farcical.
