I'm a long-time lover and player of Persona 3 since back in my tweens. I played and beat the original P3, I played through P3FES, I poked at P3P on the PSP, and proudly proclaim that it is my #1 favorite game of all time. Needless to say when I saw this remake was in the works I was beyond ecstatic to see it come to life, and now playing through it I can firmly say that it holds up very well to my fondest of memories.

First of all, the game is gorgeous. The overworld is very nostalgic for me, but it also is simply just beautiful to see a PS2 era game have such a modern glow up. Tartarus is also very beautiful and mystifying, I love the way the floors are redesigned and have their own unique touches on how their floor plans are constructed as well as their overall aesthetics, and it creates a very new and exciting experience to go through each of the blocks and see what's going to be next in store.

The gameplay also feels very polished, seamless, and significantly less frustrating now with added notes taken from the more recent additions to the series. I appreciate finally being able to control every member of my party's moves in battle, as well as being able to switch players in mid-battle to take advantage of extra moves during critical hits and weak point strikes. I do miss the original "shuffle" aspect behind shuffle time, though the new version is significantly less frustrating as you don't have to keep track of what you want on screen and can instead easily select what you want as it appears in front of you.

And, of course, the new voice acting is actually much better than I thought it would be. I will forever miss some of the classic VAs from the original, but the new VAs are absolutely fantastic in their roles and breathe a lot of life into the characters I know and love. The writing for the characters has changed over time, but not in ways that hinder the original intention of their depth, and instead bring a different look into their personalities as they are.

Persona 3 has dark and disturbing themeing, which talks very openly about the harrowing depths of depression, suicide, and both losing touch with life and reality as well as and finding new lust for existence, and I appreciate all the additional details added in to this remake that continues to push those themes even harder and more forefront than ever before. Being unrestricted to the filesize of the Playstation 2 disk has opened many new doors that this game couldn't explore before, and I'm as excited as ever to be able to push through those doors and see everything this gem has to offer.

In short, if you're a new fan or an old fan of JRPGs or the Persona franchise as a whole, I highly recommend picking up P3R whenever you get the chance. It's unfair to compare this game to the newer installations, because while it has taken some notes on newer gameplay it's still nothing like the new games and holds its own individuality high and proud.

Compared to P3FES, the new voice actor's are good, but don't entirely live up to the original performances. 

Tartarus no longer feels like a chore and the combat is much better. While the new in engine cutscenes are pretty, the removal of many hand drawn anime scenes from the original (like Makoto awakening to his persona) was a very poor choice that takes away from the tone the original gave off. Most of the new music is good, although some of it feels like a lesser version and just a worse cover of the original tracks. 

All of this can be overlooked with how polished this game is in the new engine, but not including The Answer to (probably) later be a DLC, is some BS. Also, leave it to Atlus to release useless DLC behind a $30 paywall when they're already milking a nearly 20 year old game for $70.

I don't usually write reviews for games, but I feel like I am obligated to, as it's the first game to ever make me cry and genuinely help me realize something in my own life as well.

I never finished P5R so I felt like I had to finish this one and since I wanted to play the original, then I had no reason not to. I heard that a lot of the issues in the OG were fixed or made more enjoyable and it shows as Tartarus is a blast to explore, social links really make you feel for the characters or cheer them on, and the slow realization that in the end, even if there's a happy ending, sacrifices must be made, and if you play the game you'll see what I mean.

The real reason this game grabbed me so much was the main character, he's a blank canvas, despite other Persona protagonists feeling that way, this one made me feel like I was answering to things to my decisions, that *that* would be the option I would've made if I was actually in his shoes. My social links felt like actual bonds and the emotion was poignant, I haven't had the most decided or balanced mental IRL and a lot of the meanings or themes of the game hit hard, it made me think about what I was doing with my life and how I should deal with it myself but not with the feeling I was alone. I romanced Mitsuru in my playthrough, despite being aromantic, I still felt the love form and how since it was my decisions, it felt like that love was mutual between us, now I know that sounds a bit weird but it's a genuine thing I felt and even if it's weird, screw it, I was weird the moment I came into this world. This game made me re-think my life while I still had the time to, and made me feel such poignant emotions I hadn't felt in years since my Grandfather passed away almost 4 years now, I urge you to give it a try, even if you don't like it, I don't want to spoil it for you.

I could give an honest review of this game and explain everything; but really, if you're thinking of buying this game, you're one of two people. You either have played the PS2 or PSP version and are super excited, or you're fresh off of Persona 5 Royal and are looking for more. Either way, you generally know what you're getting into. As an old SMT and Persona fan, the only thing I can say is that the QoL updates alone make the experience worth the purchase. Really though, there's no reason to not include the FES epilogue in Reload, or the alternate protag from FES too. Considering Atlus hasn't really been a developer known for DLC, it's doubtful they'll add the epilogoe and other stuff later, which is a shame. It really was an odd choice to not add it in.

Persona 3 Reload is a dream come true for many fans of the series. Persona 3 is great, but it always suffered from being the first game in the series to use the "modern Persona formula", so it was lacking in many aspects compared to 4 and 5 despite all the things it does so well. Reload fixes this, updating the game with new graphics, content and a modern combat system. Reload is the gold standard for what a remake should be. It faithfully recreates the original as it was, fixing the things that weren't so good, and enhancing the things that were good.

The story is the same with a few additions. The updated graphics make it easier to get immersed into the world, and the addition of full voice acting for the social links are also so nice. There are new "dorm events" which are essentially mini social links with the main cast, mainly to help with the fact that half the main cast don't have real social links of their own. Some social links also start earlier which makes it a lot easier to get everything done vs the original game. Certain characters, such as the main antagonists, are given extra scenes and dialogue to give them some much needed character development. 

Gameplay wise, Reload uses a modern Persona gameplay system. You can control every party member. The baton pass feature from P5 is back and each party member gets 2 ultimate attacks plus extra characteristics and stats depending on how many dorm events you do with them. Tartarus has more varied aesthetics, with more unique mechanics and easier traversal. There are extra, optional "monad floors" that you can enter if you're looking for challenge. The new Tartarus is a massive improvement on what was arguably the worst part of the original Persona 3, and is now one of the best dungeons in the entire series, behind only the palaces of Persona 5.

My only complaint about Reload is what it doesn't have. It's missing The Answer DLC, as well as the P3P content such as the female mc and her social links. These aren't too big a deal, since there's enough new content to make up for what was load and Reload is still the definitive version of P3 now, but it would have been nice to have all the previous Persona 3 content be included, especially femc.

Overall Persona 3 Reload is another great addition to one of the greatest game series of all time, and it's arguably the best one. However, I would recommend playing the game on Game Pass rather than Steam. As much as I love this game, 70 USD is asking a lot, especially when the much more content dense Persona 5 Royal is selling for 60.

I feel I'm about halfway through the game as of writing this review; however unless there is some form of major fumble later on in the game I can say wholeheartedly this is the remake of Persona 3 I have been dying to play. Style oozes from every ounce of the game from its UI to it's improved soundtrack. While it makes minor alterations in places I would have left alone, it makes just as many positive changes to the experience that make Reload a stellar update to a classic PS2 RPG. Genuinely Fantastic.

The story is a genuine masterpiece with an absolutely perfect ending, the characters are some of my favorites in any game ever, but the animations are really lackluster and make characters look like they‚Äôre gliding on ice whenever they run, for a full blown remake at full price some of the design choices are downright embarrassing such as Club Escapade having literal mannequins inside, and the presentation and lighting being really underwhelming.

Tartarus looks better than ever but remaking all 260 floors of it really highlights how outdated of a design it is, P5 had the palaces as the main course with Mementos acting as a side dish, so Tartarus being tbe focal point feels like a side dish with no main course, I would‚Äôve loved if it had some human designed dungeons maybe at the end of each section.

Overall while this is my favorite Persona game and up there as one of my favorite games ever, it still has its faults and a lot of missed opportunities for a remake, plus even though the ending is still incredible, it felt weirdly directed, especially a Junpei voice line that felt like it played too early, and what I assume are localization changes making Aigis‚Äôs dialogue a lot less impactful, none of it detracts from how perfect the ending is, I look forward to it being ruined by The Answer DLC

The core game is good, but something about the engine makes things feel kinda... souless? That sounds cheesy as hell but that's honestly how I feel even after having not played the original game. I'm not sure if Persona 5 used this engine but that game's environments seemed way more full of life and heart than this game but the characters models here look way better. Music wise I do like a lot of the original Persona 3 songs and I do like the remixes here I just wish they gave an option to use the original sound tracks instead if you wanted to. Combat wise, it's good old SMT with shuffle time at the end like in P4 which is something I admittely wished they phased out in this remake in return for a traditional reward system but it's not something that ruins this game for me.

Overall it's a good game so far, story is interesting and moves at a faster pace than 4 and 5, and it has the same solid foundation the other modern persona games all had. If you liked P4 and P5 there's a high chance you'll like this game. Is it worth 70 dollars? Hell no, wait for a sale. I'd give it like a 7 out of 10.

A true masterpiece of a remake. I played Persona 3 Portable a while ago and as someone who loved the original Persona 3 I can say with confidence that Persona 3 Reload is now my favorite Persona game! As much as I love P5R, this game is just too perfect. Persona 3 was always on par with P5R to me so now that the gameplay and graphics have been updated, this game has finally managed to dethrone it. The story and characters are amazing. This game may come off as edgy and dark but it's themes and message are very meaningful. Without spoiling too much I can just say that Persona 3 is a game that means a lot to me and has changed my outlook on life. And I'm not the only one who feels that way. The soundtrack, UI, themes and story are my favorite from the Persona series and if you're willing to give Persona 3 a try, then I heavily recommend you start with Reload!

Not just a great remake of the original persona 3, but one of the best jrpgs atlas has put out to date. The game plays incredibly smooth and looks gorgeous; brimming with style at every turn. Time will tell if this can be considered the definitive way to play persona 3, as it does still lack the content available in the portable version of the game. That being said it does bring a significant amount of new content to persona 3, and improves greatly upon the original's classic but dated design elements. There is something to be said for the difficulty of the game for those who are fans of the SMT games as a whole; it is much easier than the original   game simply due to the fact you can grind without penalty. That in addition to baton pass from pesrona 5 being brought over to this game as well as the theurgy mechanic means you simply have more powerful options than you did in the original which does make fights easier to approach. This is not a bad thing in and of itself, but for returning players to this game you may wish to play on hard difficulty or higher in order to preserve the tension that was felt in the original game. I have not beaten the remake yet, but having beaten all versions of this game previously multiple times, I can say atlus has done a fantastic job with this re-imagining of a beloved classic.

Persona 3 FES was the first game that got me into the Persona series as well as mainline Shin Megami Tensei. I had enjoyed the narrative the most while also appreciating the more unique gameplay compared to both earlier and later entries (I am a rare Persona fan that has actually played Persona 2, but not rare enough to be a Persona 1 player.) I had my gripes with the original in the form of more janky game mechanics like downing enemies and bosses being very clearly overpowered for chain-stunning, party members having very inconsistent viability when your only method of control was the tactics system (aside from having direct control on the main character), not much development for nearly half of the party because they lacked social links (unless you played portable, which would still have the same problem anyway just with the same gender as your MC of choice), the fatigue system as a whole (even if it became irrelevant in the mid-game and onward), and the lack of presence some antagonists had.

Persona 3 Reload has fixed just about all of this for me. I'm still going through the game (currently in September, so I only have a few months left in the game) but I feel I can confidently say that P3R, even without The Answer, is the definitive way to experience Persona 3. While I wish The Answer was in the Reload from the get-go, despite the very controversial status it holds due to its quality in FES, I feel that the main story of Persona 3 with FES and Portable's QoL changes are more than enough to make the game stand on its own. Maybe Atlus will just give us The Answer as DLC anyway. I can actually mix and and match my team without concern of, say, Koromaru being near worthless in FES because his skillset is primarily Dark magic so he'd miss his instakills when I want him to use Fire skills or whatever. In Reload I can actually make use of Koromaru as a mixed Dark/Fire magic user and support with crit boosts and increasing my team's physical damage output. I can actually go at my own pace and take a moment to grind if I need money or extra EXP for my lower level party members without fear of the fatigue system just ruining the pace. Direct control on all party members does have the side effect of making the game generally easier, but I think this is worthwhile to actually have enjoyable gameplay and shifting the difficulty around having actual coverage as a team than just on your main character while your party members are forced to play support. Even then, if direct control just isn't the way, the tactics system is still there. It's watered down though which is a shame, but it at least is usable. And for what it's worth, playing through the game on Merciless has still brought a surprising amount of challenge for me despite having direct control on all my party members.

With the possible exception of P3 Portable, this is the best way to play this game. TL;DR I love this iteration of the game. The voice acting is great, the remixes are banging, and the additional story elements are well-done. This quality without being a reboot is exactly what I wanted--and didn't get--from the Final Fantasy VII remake. Pleased to report that they didn't overhaul my all-time favorite game for a new audience.

If you've played Persona 5/Royal, P3R isn't as polished a game. Social links are more diverse, but most are not as memorable or nuanced as they are in later games. But considering the original P3, in 2004, was the first iteration of Social Links, the calendar time-management, and All-Out Attacks? Respect where it's due.

Never Played a Persona before:

- Half the game is dungeon crawling with turn-based combat. Half is a social sim/time manager.

- You better like reading, although the new voice acting means less of it.

- Punchy turn-based combat is kinda adjacent to Pokemon (in that it has a colorful character doing elemental status effects on your behalf,) but you can mix your minions together to get better minions. Very unlike Pokemon, you have party members that each fulfill an elemental role, and your fights are in groups.

- More forgiving game play than other Shin Megami Tensei main-line games, if you've come here from SMT 4 or 5. Also less parable and more slice-of-life plot than most of the other SMT games.

- Crank the soundtrack!

- This game is about death. You are going to have some feels.

Newer Persona Fans Should Know:

- There is one dungeon. Rather than that dungeon being about party members (Persona 4) or malicious adults inflicting their will on party members (Persona 5), each character has different motivations to enter the dungeon. That dungeon is randomly generated and does not have the kind of puzzles you see in 5, nor the brightly-colored hallways of 4.

- There are a few social links that really make the game, and many are less memorable. Hermit, Hanged Man, and Sun are some of the best outside of your party members. Magician, Chariot, and some of the others are more boring, slice of life stuff. As this game reflects the original Persona 3, there are tragically no male party member social links. (This is where Persona 3 Portable shines.)

- More magical realism and off-the-wall designs. Your teachers are absolute characters, for example.  

- Just keep going for All Out Attacks. I promise.

- This game is about death. You are going to have some feels.

Persona 3 Fan:

- No Femc

- No male party social links

- Removed the first hours of slogging through a town you weren't allowed to interact with

- Significantly easier combat for several reasons, from button economy to status effects to vastly improved navigation.

- I have never seen in-game characters resemble the original design and marketing work this well, and it is glorious


In conclusion:

Not everyone is going to appreciate a slower, plot-heavy anime game about death. But this is probably the best slower, plot-heavy anime game about death ever made.
fuckin epic

The original Persona 3 was very much a diamond in the rough. An excellent story and a really fun game bogged down by the limitations of a system far too limited to show the intended beauty of the environments, a sparsity of content and a couple really bizarre design choices here and there.

This fixes everything, which is really on par for ATLUS remakes. There is a lot more character interaction that you might be used to from P4/5, with proper social links (if not arcana-based) for the entire crew and then some. The main story had some extra stuff added to fill in some gaps, and being able to interact with Strega is a huge deal as well.

Tartarus is still... [i]there[/i], and it's still the same randomly-generated predictable mess that it was before. But now it looks gorgeous, and the different blocks actually feel different from each other. A few additions to its formula such as the extremely challenging optional boss fights and the extra rewards help spice it up just enough to feel at least on par with P4's dungeons, which is a big improvement.

Both the combat and the social systems are at the deepest they've ever been in this series. The ability for some social links to unlock others, or the ability to reverse social links, has been completely removed from P4 onwards -- but this game brings those back, which is excellent. The addition of Theurgy gives each character a distinct role that they're encouraged to play, but it's in no way forced on you so you can still play your way.

It also goes without saying that the new talented voice cast does a phenomenal job of helping the game's story move along. If you're one of the people who play in English, then you're no longer stuck with the robotic and emotionless voice of the original game.

My only remaining complaint is the somewhat slow pacing at the start of the game, it takes forever to fully introduce its systems and to allow you to interact with its main cast properly. However, it's a shorter timespan than in the original, and there's a lot to do in the meantime.

I'd like to address a few additional concerns that I see some people bring up: [list]
[*] This does not have FES content. This one is... simply not true. All of the extras FES added to the main game are here. What is currently not included is Episode Aegis/The Answer, which is allegedly coming as DLC eventually. The Answer was [i]always[/i] a DLC (well, an append disc) in Japan, so this isn't too surprising.
[*] The soundtrack/artbook are locked behind custom executables. This is true, and was probably done by ATLUS so that they could also release them on consoles (as they don't have support for proper file management). If you want the actual files, they are trivially extracted from this Steam version, so it's still worth a purchase (if you care to have these things).
[*] No Kotone/FeMC. This is true. However, her presence is largely made redundant by introduction of social interactions for the male crew members, which was the main selling point for her other than just her being a girl. Her storyline also introduced a few flaws into the story of P3, breaking some of its themes and making a lot of the characters come off as much worse than intended, so that's not a playthrough I'd recommend to a new player. If you care about her simply because a female character is easier for you to identify with, I'm sorry, there's not much there can be done other than waiting for someone to mod her in or playing Portable. However, if you care about her because of the story improvements in her route, you'll find a lot of the same things done in Reload, and done better.
[/list]

I have played Persona's 2-5 Royal, and I felt that this game is a disappointment for $70 thus far. I know that a lot of people in this fandom are going to rage just because I gave a negative review, but I feel that my justifications are valid.

TLDR; This game feels like it is struggling to maintain what made P3 great, while also trying to cater to the new design philosophies present in P5. It just doesn't work super great in my opinion, and it makes this game feel inferior to a modded FES version.

*Yukari's VA performance feels like a major shift from the way she was originally portrayed in P3
*Redone music is subpar in my opinion
*Premium editions are locked behind a laucher, so you don't even own the music.
*While the combat has vastly improved, the cutscenes and environments are lacking major updates.

This game honestly feels like they gave it to a "second-string" team to develop while they make P6 a masterpiece.  I hope this is not the standard going forward for the games.
Gud

I was afraid they would mess up this remake but Atlus delivered, especially to those who will experience P3 for the first time with this game. I still prefer the looks of the original, but this is a great experience even after a decade of playing the original.
Pretty much everything was kept that should've been and no bloat was added.
The OST has some interesting takes, hit or miss between the originals and the remixes, but it's still an enjoyable bundle of tracks.
Visually you get what you would expect from a Persona entry after the success of 5. They kept most of the defining factors of the original and gave a lot of life and personality to Tartarus. My only gripe with graphics is the limited amount of settings, mainly looking at motion blur. Hopefully some future patches will add more options to graphics.
Gameplay wise the core is what you would expect from P3-4-5. For newcomers it's a treat and it wasn't much of a pain to get used to the changes either. The new battle skills are fun and add some more depth to the fights, but because of it the difficulty feels rather flat; Currently only finished the game on hard, but it was a breeze. Tartarus also feels easier somehow, the amount of resources you find in this version feels a bit extensive.
New story scenes and events were cool and engaging, the few "rewritten" parts don't really do much and are barely noticeable.
A lot of QoL was added to the game which is a question of taste whether you like it or not, it makes the game more casual in many senses, but overall, I can't be mad at any of them. Maybe the Elizabeth request markers hold your hand too much, but that's the worst I can think of.

Overall, it's a great addition to the franchise and worth the price.

I primarily wanted to do this review just to address the quality of the PC port, which is barebones but functional (it also runs pretty well on the Steam Deck as well), but I'll touch on some specifics about the game afterwards. The game has very little in the way of adjustable settings but seems to run well enough! There's only two slight issues I've seen so far centered around the menu. The menu seems to be capped at 60fps (while the actual game can go up to 120), so when leaving the menu it actually takes 3-4 seconds for the game to ramp back up to 120 in gameplay. Obviously not a dealbreaker but it is noticeable and slightly annoying. The other issue is that while the game's rendering resolution can be increased to 200%, this does not seem to apply to the menus either. Running around in-game is fairly crisp with the resolution scaler set to 200%, but when you enter any menus you immediately notice that it's lower res and you'll see some pixelation due to the lower resolution. Again, nothing even close to a dealbreaker, but these are small issues that I feel we shouldn't be seeing in games in 2024. 

As far as the game itself, I feel like we all understand the gist of Persona now, so I won't get into the specifics of the game. This is my first time playing Persona 3, and I'm a big fan of the franchise and was interested to see what Atlus would do with a remake. You can tell that they definitely tried to stay as faithful to the original as possible, as in terms of gameplay it's much closer to Persona 4 than Persona 5. It's more dungeon crawl-y with less narrative bloat (and actually has some of the same systems as 4, like the card system for your rewards when defeating shadows) - personally I like how narrative/story heavy that 5 is and I miss that here, but I wouldn't say either way of doing it is better than the other, they're just different approaches to designing games. If you really liked the more dungeon crawling focus of 4 and hated the Palaces in 5, then you'll definitely like 3 (with the opposite also being true. If you really liked the palaces you'll probably be disappointed here, as 3 has one dungeon called Tartarus, and it's essentially the same idea as Mementos in Persona 5). 

I'm not far enough in the story and haven't spent enough time with the characters to comment on those aspects, but in general I do think the game looks good. It's not anything cutting edge, but you can tell that it's still an improvement over Persona 5 (particularly with shadows/lighting, I'm noticing a lot more shading and secondary shadows in the environment than I would see in Persona 5). The menus/UI are all very stylish as well, but it's more of a 'clean' type of aesthetic - sort of sleek and modern looking. 

Overall, the most important thing to know with this game is that Atlus was intent on keeping it as faithful to the original as possible - while they redid all of the voice work and redid all of the visuals, they still followed the beats and story from the original as closely as they could. That means that there's definitely some outdated mechanics and game design on display. But I feel like they've added enough quality of life improvements to at least make it decent in today's landscape, rather than letting it stay painful to play through a modern lens. And at the end of the day, it's a Persona game, so I feel like by this point you know all that entails and what you're getting into. I'm a big fan so I already knew I'd have a good time, and if you're a brand new fan then you might be better off starting with 5 as it's the most modern. But at the very least, this is an interesting semi time capsule into the past with a sparkling coat of paint on top

Spoiler free review.
Alright, long time persona 3 fan here. I grew up with this game. I literally picked up P3 FES blindly years ago and got very much surprised, satisfied. The game contained so many raw and strong emotions, it wasn't only about the gameplay but also about the overall depicted world.

And i think that everyone who knows the game might agree with me in that, while the new graphics and flashy art is cool and all, it just doesn't convey the atmosphere and tone of the original persona 3. Gloomy, gruesome, macabre scenes and dark allusions. They all got ""subtly censored"" in a way. It got way too soft. Just look at the prelude of the two versions, for comparison.

And i mean, the game literally contains suicide allusions, at this point why are you not going all out like the original? You guys are basically showcasing a censored story now.
How do i put this; it's like narrating the tale of Little Red Riding Hood without using the words kill, eat, death, blood. You know what i'm saying?

So yeah, thumbs up for the improved "dungeons", new dialogues, and the overall faster/nicer GUI and combat system, but still. 
Sometimes, flashy and fresh stuff isn't always the best option to tell a story, you know? Sometimes it's better to keep it simple, let your imagination fill in the blanks. If the game does everything for you, imagination-wise, what's the point?

If you're going to ask for full game price for a remake, I expect quality and effort. So far, I've been disappointed. I'm fine with some things not being animated cutscenes that were in the original, but in key moments, like Orpheus awakening, not having the hand drawn animated cutscene feels awful. Sure, they had a rendered cutscene, but it just isn't the same. The remixed songs have mostly been not great, which is a shame because I really enjoyed the original's soundtrack. I'm mostly fine with the art direction, however, not drawing the protagonist's clothes feels lazy. There's just a shadow over the clothes. Also, there still isn't a definitive way to play this game, which a remake should have fixed. There's no female protagonist option, no The Answer, and no Desert of Doors. Junpei doesn't sound as good or as young as he did in the original game. I'm going to continue to play the game because the frustrating thing about FES and the original was not being able to control your party members and this game gives you that, but so does Portable. Maybe they'll add the content in DLC, but considering what feels like a lack of effort and an insane asking price for the base game, even if they did, I might not buy it

Every facet of the game has been polished to a mirror finish, easily meeting and surpassing the high bar set by Persona 5. Got exactly what I paid for, Persona 3 given Persona 5‚Äôs budget and tech. Gorgeous to look at and engaging to play. I‚Äôd recommend this to newcomers and people who haven‚Äôt played the original, with the caveat that this doesn‚Äôt emulate the experience of the original game, this is Persona 5 telling Persona 3‚Äôs story, this is not a remaster of Persona 3. For some people that makes the game better, for some worse; I‚Äôm neutral.

For new additions, theurgies are stylish and brutal "ultimate" attacks that kind of break combat for me. I‚Äôm really not sure if combat was designed around them or not, but I always felt like I was cheating when I used them. Especially by the end, completing your compendium grants an attack that basically one-shot everything with the exception of [i]that[/i] infamous secret boss.

The Japanese voices sound just as I remembered them, the soundtrack does not. I like the new tracks, (‚ÄúIt‚Äôs going down now‚Äù might be my new favourite battle theme), but tracks that were ‚Äúremastered‚Äù sounded significantly weaker than the originals. I don‚Äôt think the new singer is bad, I think she‚Äôs got a higher pitch voice than the songs were intended for. Mass Destruction and the credits theme especially were upsettingly poor, and those are two of the most famous songs from the original.

While I found the new additions a little weak, I still loved my time with Reload and if it weren‚Äôt for the surprisingly high spec requirements, I‚Äôd recommend it as the definitive version of the game. (I do not care for the answer or femc).

Persona 3 has a slow start but highlights some of the best writing in the franchise. Reload is a strict remake of the original, it changes very little but enough to spice it up for older fans and bring it in line with the newer Megaten titles to ease new players into it.

Ultimately, I find Reload to be a mixed bag when it comes to quality. There are weird inconsistencies with the graphics - almost feels like there are lines filtered onto the screen, and some UI/cutscene elements are painfully low FPS in relation to the game. A few of the anime cutscenes were awkwardly animated. Some of the English VA's are poorly chosen, Yukari is basically a different character with a completely different inflection and feels inconsistent to me, she also doesn't sound much like her original game counterpart - the same can't be said for some of the other VA's like Junpei or Mitsuru. It completely took me out of the game hearing some lines by characters which sound entirely like a grown adult pretending to sound like a teenager. The Protagonist has completely different animations and VA. A FeMC route or 'The Answer' are nowhere to be found. Day one DLC are lackluster at best. I actually thought the soundtrack was one of the best parts of this game, but I have heard complaints about the new singer, which I can see although I do not agree.

There are many imperfections and weird inconsistencies with this remake, but I am glad it was made. Persona 3 (outside of the newly "remastered" Portable) has been an experience nearly unobtainable outside of emulating, and is notorious for driving people away with its dated mechanics. Reload updates many of the older games mechanics and graphics while still keeping the essence of the game alive. It really does feel like a true remake, and for that I have to recommend it to those seasoned in Megaten games wanting more. I still think first-time Persona fans should stick with Persona 5 Royal first.

Comparing this to other Persona games, it's no wonder this is the favorite among the hardcore Persona fans, at least when considering the other modern entries. The writing is way less cringe than Persona 5, the characters are much more likable (in my opinion), the atmosphere is wonderfully executed, the music is on point, the combat is great, etc. 

I honestly don't have much negative to say, it's Persona 3 at it's best simply put. You have the content from Portable FemC route added in (albeit in a not gay way which is kind of an L. Also L for not including FemC herself in the game). 

If you're still reading this, this is well worth the dive into Persona 3 for fans of FES, Portable, or Persona 5/4, or if you just like JRPGs.

Great game, probably should have played the originals first, but whatever! If you like RPGs, JRPGs in particular. You will love this game. If you've played Persona 5 and enjoyed it, what are you doing not playing this game? It's been updated to give it the P5 visual makeover. I will say Junpei is the Ryuji of P3, annoying with his quips. Haven't met the Robot, dog, or the 'delinquent' character yet, but when I do. I'm sure I'm gonna love them, especially the pup. 
Do yourself a favor and play this game, even if you aren't a fan of RPGs. I'm sure you will vibe with something/someone in this game.

Reload is an amazing experience! Persona 3 with Persona 5 graphics (and some references to Persona 2)! Some great quality of life changes/improvements and new events. Great voice acting from a new cast and the redone OST has a fresh but nostalgic sound to it. Some great DLC coming later including the Aigis story... Only thing missing is the fan-favorite Femc route but it doesn't downgrade the experience at all. I think this is one of the best remakes i've played in the last few years!

The true definitive experience of Persona 3. Yes the FES material has not been added to the game. However, with the graphics, character updates, new dialogue, better combat options, and enhanced story experience this is the way the game should have been developed in 2009. I am surprised with kingdom hearts and other JRPGs of the time, ATLUS did not think to create the game the way it was developed in RELOAD. But I am glad that I get to enjoy the full experience now the way it should have been played when I was a kid 15 years ago. 10/10 would recommend to all dungeon crawler JRPG fans, and generally anyone interested in Anime-like video games looking for a fresh experience.

In a way, it's the Yakuza Kiwami of Persona. Gameplay wise, it's very much a refined p5, with some obvious changes to make it feel more like p3. However it follows the story of the original persona 3. 
Both of these are great! As I never enjoyed playing persona 3. No party control and awful dungeon generation made it a chore. But now it's like getting the interesting story of persona 3, inside an actually fun video game! Highly recommend to anyone who enjoys modern persona games. 

It is a better game than the ps2 original, in my opinion, for the changes to combat and tartarus alone.

(The remake itself is very good in quality, it uses the P5R engine to rebuild the original game from scratch and it looks and feels amazing, there's jank here and there with the monotonous and outdated dungeon crawling, the 70 bucks price point for a remake made in an engine that already existed and the lack of some content that already existed for previous iterations of the game; But if you already know the original story and want to replay it in a modern suit, or if you just crave pointless tragedy that just eats man hours then this product is worthy of a thumbs up .... however

Semi?-Spoilers ->

Being a massive fan of Persona 5 Royal and Persona 4 Golden and since I've never experienced Persona 3 before I decided to purchase this game 7 days before it came out. After around 25h of playtime with nothing but build-up (which would have been fine if not great) and considering my diminishing free time in the near future, these games massive lengths to 100% complete and the fact that despite loving P5R, I absolutely hated the shit out of its ending (especially compared to the original P5 ending), I've made the probably ill-advised decision to watch the very last 60s of this game's "true" ending just to see if it was building towards something satisfying and was worth the 100-120h grind.

And I'm glad I did, because despite it's adequacy for the major theme of the story itself and the overall overwhelming praise that it gets from sad weirdos online that are so desensitized they can no longer feel anything if it's not at it's most extreme level of brutality and depravity, this game's ending is so garbage, so utterly trash and destructive to the over-all gameplay element of building your character and your relationship with the other characters around you over an immense period of real-life hours, that I now regret ever buying the game in the first place. 

It's such a massive downer that is just dropped on the player after they've likely spent at the very least 80h progressing though the story, that it just completely killed my enthusiasm and willingness to even complete the game.

TLDR: Only for hardcore masochists that can only get hard by cutting off their dicks after 48h of edging,

I've played all versions of Persona 3. I've cried while playing all versions of Persona 3. I really love Persona 3. Imo it's the best story, the best characters, and a smashing soundtrack. Now, it's also beautiful. Yes the new VAs take a little getting used to, and yes most definitely does Captain Kurasawa being voiced by Liam o'Brien throw me off every time. But eventually it changes nothing. It's still the best story, it's still the best characters, it's still a smashing soundtrack and now it's also looking crisp and neat and gorgeous. Best upgrade is the possibility to actually hang out with your male team members. Quality time with Akihiko is my favourite time (because Akihiko is just my favourite, period). Second best upgrade is being able to pet Koromaru. Third best is being able to cry again at this dang game.

I've also seen some complaints around about it now being good on deck but in my experience it's fine. I've been streaming it to the TV just so I can show my dog better that there's dogs out there who work for their stay instead of lounge around and fart. Still excellent gameplay with the occasional WiFi problems

Props for Atlus keeping the three physical types, I put money on them dumbing it down.  

There was a lot of opportunity lost here, ultimately a low effort remake from everyone but the artists and animators.

Just swap TSR for FXAA if you can render at 200% SSAA and turn motion blur off. Add the following to engine.ini located in C:\Users\username\AppData\Local\P3R\Saved\Config\WindowsNoEditor:

[SystemSettings]
r.SceneColorFringeQuality=0
r.MotionBlur.Amount=0
r.MotionBlurQuality=0

[/Script/Engine.RendererSettings]
r.DefaultFeature.AntiAliasing=1
r.TemporalAA.Upsampling=0
r.PostProcessAAQuality=6
r.AntialiasingMethod=1
foliage.DitheredLOD=0
r.FXAA.Quality=5
r.Tonemapper.Sharpen=0

Make sure to play in exclusive fullscreen or else the game will render at half res.

TLDR: Like Persona? Play it. Never played Persona but like RPGs and collecting funky looking creatures? Play it. BONUS: DOG.

Bonus++: DLC with the female protag and appropriate storylines would be cool, but it's not a deal breaker to not have it. As a female gamer, kinda used to games not having a female protag and it doesn't make a difference to me at this point - the game is still stellar.

My introduction to the Persona series was with Persona 4, and then I played 5. They were all both enjoyable experiences that I might attempt to reexperience at some point in time, more so after starting my playthrough of P3 Reload.

Right off the bat, the opening music is an absolute BANGER and I never use that word. The UI is not only smooth, but pleasing to look at as well. I know there are some people who played the previous iterations of P3 and would prefer the old UI, animations, etc, but as a newcomer? Oh, I love this.

$70 is a bit steep for a game, but it doesn't bother me too much as at some point most $60 games will be boosted to $70 to adjust for inflation and what not. I think a rule of thumb is if you can at least get 30 min to an hour of gameplay for every $ spent, it's worth it if you're having a good time. Bonus if you get more hours of gameplay from it.

I read that the previous iterations had a female protag and it does suck to miss out on that, but it can't be helped. The battles are smooth with features to speed through under leveled enemies and everything looks like it's been paintedf with that  Persona 5 coat. I'm enjoying the voice acting from the cast of characters, even with Akihiko deeper voice.

I definitely recommend playing the game for that good ol' Persona playstyle. But god, I wish the school questions weren't so ODD, this game makes college exams look like vocabulary quizzes.

I have played Persona 3 FES in my youth and that game shaped me in multiple ways.
Not too long ago I have started playing it again, noticing some flaws of the PS2 version.
But still, it was quite enjoyable and had a big nostalgic factor.

I have not expected P3R to be released, but when I saw it, I simply had to purchase it straight away.
This new iteration blows my mind. It works up the issues of the older PS2 version and really elevated the beauty of the main game.
I so love that they kept all these twisted nuances like the shot to the head to summon a temporary ally to fight for you.
And the models, the style, the UI, the music. Despite the big update of those elements, they all carry the actual soul and body of the original.
This is one of the best remakes I have ever seen. It is on par with the Resident Evil 4 remake.

Persona!

I'll be honest, as someone that kinda dislikes Persona 4, and is mostly lukewarm on Persona 5, I didn't think modern Atlus would be able to remake Persona 3 in a way that wouldn't ultimately play and feel radically different from the gameplay experience of the original releases of Persona 3. I was pretty pessimistic to say the least.

I was definitely wrong, Reload brings the polish and refinements of the latter two games to the combat system with a few new additions, but aside from the quality of life features, modern graphics, and rearranged soundtrack, Persona 3 Reload is a very faithful remake to the original game.

The script is (thankfully) largely identical to the original release, with much of the dialogue lifted straight from the original translation we received almost 20 years ago. Atlus wisely avoided adding any new major story additions like new characters or plot points, which have had mixed levels of success with their re-releases over the years.

Of the three major pillars of Persona 3's gameplay loop, the dungeon crawling was always the weakest. Atlus has made several changes to Tartarus to make climbing the tower more engaging. I'll list several I've noticed in the first handful of hours with the game.

-Rooms and hallways are bigger, allowing you to more easily maneuver around and avoid, or ambush, enemies compared to the original.
-Shadows wander around more, and most importantly don't take forever to change the direction they're facing. This cuts out a huge amount of the downtime present in the original games and further aids gaining player advantage in battles.
-You can no longer split the party up, but the addition of a dash button makes finding the exit on each floor quicker and further aids in avoiding or engaging enemies.
-Rare chests now appear and can be opened with a new currency you can find in Tartarus, as well as outside the the tower.
-The environments and layouts of each block are more distinct and varied.
-You can now teleport to the staircase of each floor whenever you want provided you've found them on the current floor you're on. This allows you to still continue to search for treasure before moving on and eliminates backtracking. This teleport persists for the rest of that night, even if you return to the Tartarus ground floor. This makes grinding and runbacks to the guardian bosses less time consuming.

All pretty good changes, While still staying true to the original feel of the P3's dungeon crawling. Some people might have preferred more changes, but I appreciate Atlus improving what was already there, rather than trying to change P3's dungeon experience into something it never was.

With all that said, I'm pretty happy with how Reload turned out. It's pretty clear the dev's understood what made Persona 3 stand out from its successors, and I'm grateful they elected to polish up the Persona 3 experience we are familiar with, rather than completely redefining it to be more like Persona 5, or something else entirely. 

Here's to hoping they do something with P1 and the P2 duology in the future.

Honestly? I don't understand the hype. Maybe it's because I was spoiled by Persona 5, but Persona 3 Reload is largely underwhelming so far.
Pros: The art direction seems to be improved upon the original Persona 3, and the soundtrack is immaculate. I have nothing bad to say about the soundtrack. Also, the voice actors add so much charm to their characters, even if the characters themselves are otherwise 2 dimensional. The world space is interesting enough, and the premise of the story sounds fun and enticing in theory.

Cons: I'm roughly 4 hours in, and so far my experience hasn't been very engaging. The pacing feels rushed, the writing is mediocre, and the way the characters are introduced provides no emotional weight to the player. Instead of getting to know them, the game basically drops them in your lap and says "these are your friends now". And without building up any real reputation, everyone automatically acknowledges you as a competent and trustworthy person despite having done next to nothing to deserve such treatment. As such, the social links feel shallow and contrived, and I felt no personal connection with ANY of the characters I am meant to interact with. As for the combat, it's... mediocre. The shadows have a decent enough design, but... There isn't enough variety for the early stages to make combat interesting, and Tartarus itself is even less interesting. There is no sense of urgency for the player to pursue the mysteries of the Dark Hour, there haven't been any antagonists to drive the story forward save for the few shadows you engaged very early in the game on the rooftop, and I'm largely bored with the main cast so far. They don't feel like characters. Just one dimensional plot devices that tell you where and what to do. Maybe I shot myself in the foot expecting them to provide more than just exposition after introducing myself to the franchise through Persona 5, but so far they are the greatest disappointment I've experienced in a long time. I REALLY want to give this game a chance, but I am SO. BORED. Maybe I'll give it another hour or two of gameplay to see if the story shifts from Exposition to Rising Action, or for the "characters" to get more interesting, but if it doesn't, I'm going to have to decline recommending this game. The premise is there, but the execution falls flat for me so far.

My Favorite game of all time got an incredible remake. Thank you Atlus.

So I've played P3R for 10 hours straight as of writing this; That should tell you enough. For those that do need a further explanation, here are my thoughts.

Wow. Great game 9/10, too much water.

But for real, this game is amazing. I played P3P to this point too I believe, just before the first boss if I'm not mistaken so that would be a little earlier than I am now. And MAN, am I glad I picked this game up anyways. The QOL features are really great, and everything screams "worth it".

First off, the usual. The music is great, shocker I know. I kind of expected to not like the music because of how great the original tracks are and how used I've gotten to them, but they just blew my expectations straight out of the water. Every damn second in this game feels so good because of the music, particularly walking around at night. No clue what this new song is called but DAMN this has to be the best song in the Persona franchise for walking around. The new battle theme is also top-notch. I like how its chorus is on a little quicker than Mass Destruction's, because it feels more natural with the flow of combat. The music does change kind of abruptly in my opinion, both in and out of combat. And how could I forget, the opening is of course incredible, as always.

Secondly, the overal atmosphere and UI. To get the obvious out of the way: this game's presentation is not on the same level as Persona 5's. That's completely fine but just something that you should know, so you don't go in expecting something ridiculous like that. Instead, P3R absolutely perfects the existing UI. Of course they do take cues from P5's UI, where the MC is the background of the menus, but it's a lot more lowkey and aesthetically pleasing. P5 tried to be (and was, don't get me wrong) really cool, but P3R just feels better in my opinion. The sound design is largely back to how it was in P3/P4, which is amazing as I got into Persona by playing P4. 

As a smaller sub-point of the last, the graphics are awesome. The map feels both new and exciting and nostalgic because of the lighting and just how faithful they remade it. The animations in combat too are great, and crits/weakness hits feel really impactful. It also goes without saying that all the models I've seen so far are great, but it takes one look at the pictures on this store page to see that.

Then thirdly, the actual gameplay. The game doesn't feel too hard, but not too easy either. I feel like they've made it more lenient maybe? I am playing on merciless difficulty so that might be the reason it's still somewhat of a challenge but overall, the combat isn't exactly a cakewalk. The first boss actually killed me twice, in fact, and not to brag but I am pretty experienced with JRPGs so that is quite an accomplishment for the first boss. Slight gameplay spoilers that get explained like 2 hours in: [spoiler] The clock that heals your party now costs the equivalent of lockpicks. 7 of them, in fact. Opening a chest with them can cost 1-3 and you can find them all over the world. Fun system but it is slightly less fun than just having free heals in the lobby. I'm the kind of guy that wants to do the entirety of the unlocked Tartarus in one go because it feels inefficient to not do that. [/spoiler] 
Anyhow, money is actually pretty tight on some days. The equipment is plentiful and expensive, so don't expect to have any savings in the earlygame. Your characters need shoes, clothes, a weapon and optionally an accessory. You can just use the default but that might not cut it on the harder difficulties. I have, for the first time in a persona game ever, actually done a side job purely for the money. Not for stats, not for unlocking a social link, just the money. 
Speaking about stats: P3R only has 3 of them, just like the original. Charm, Courage and Academics. There do seem to be more tiers to them, but I might be wrong. I've currently leveled them all up to the second level. They would be higher, if the questions during the lessons weren't such nonsense. The player is just asked a question, without any explanation or context. I know I can just use the network, but it feels like cheating. On the other hand though, if the game is, why shouldn't I?
Lastly for the gameplay section, the social links. These are back to how they were in P3/4, so there's no perks attached to the tiers, which is kind of a shame but it wasn't my favourite mechanic to begin with. The writing in these has been great so far (both the translation and actual writing), so I don't really have much to say on this topic. 

So that's pretty much it. I'll probably update this review as I play more so yeah, don't stay tuned because no-one is going to actually care about a review for this game

Persona 3 was my first Persona I played back on the PS2, it's what first introduced me to the series. I've been wanting a remake like this for years and have been hoping for it ever since.

I'm happy that I get to experience my favorite game again remade and improved. If you haven't played a Persona game or have started with Persona 5 and want to experience the old stories retold with better graphics I highly encourage you to give it a try. Even if you don't like it I appreciate anyone giving this game/series a chance.

[h3]Burn Your Dread[/h3]
Did you play the original P3 and want to know if the remaster is good?
[list]
[*]Subtle, but sharp update of the art that still maintains the original aesthetics and vibe - even the overall layouts of the locations. Stylized main menus a la P5.
[*]An absolute ton of QoL improvements - sprinting, quick travel enhancements, direct command of party members, fusion previews for your entire roster at once and the ability to manually pick inherited skills (thank you, ATLUS!), rewind, one button to enter save menu, and the list goes on.
[*]Great new music tracks.
[*]Even more voice acting.
[*]Buttery smooth, frame limit up to 120 FPS, good controls with either KB+M, or PS or Xbox controllers.
[/list]
It's just a FeMC away from rendering all the other versions wildly obsolete. (The Answer was terrible to play, better to just watch the cutscenes online after finishing this, if you're interested in it)

Persona 3 Reload is a fantastic game and if you have even a passing liking for JRPGs, you should pick it up (And portable, and 4, and 5)

One major caveat is if you're buying it to play on your Steam Deck; there are some pretty large performance issues. Nothing game breaking, but certain levels of Tartarus, The Velvet Room, and random areas on Tatsumi Port Island have dips going to sub 20fps at Medium shadows and RTX reflections off. Plus, as of 2/4/2024, system settings for some reason carry over between platform, so I have to adjust setting every time when I stop playing on my 3080 rig and start on my Steam Deck and vice versa.

Even then it's still an amazing game and I would play it even if I got 15 frames per second because Aigis is in it.

This is gonna be more of a first impressions review than a full review.
As a fan of Persona, it's hard not to compare this game to the original Persona 3 and to Persona 5, as this game tries to be a remaster of 3 with added elements of 5

Is it a good game? Yeah, definitely. Is it worth 70 dollars? Absolutely not. I recommend this game but with hesitation as I really feel like more could've been done to make this better. A lot of the positive reviews are ignoring the flaws with this game because of nostalgia, I wanted to make a more honest review.

This game is marketed as a remake, but in reality it just plays like a remaster. And no remaster in my eyes is worth the price of a full game, ESPECIALLY not 70 dollars (or in my case 100). Even if this particular remaster is well made. At the end of the day, you are still playing a nicer looking PS2 game for 70 dollars. That's just ridiculous.

---------------------------------------------

This game still has the same limitations and problems from the PS2. The areas are fairly small, the battles are fairly limited and are missing a lot of the improvements that P4 or Persona 5 had, it's still very linear. The only difference is now it has crowds of people that look nice, or fancy lighting/graphics. Tartarus looks WAY better now, but it's still very linear and the shadows are annoying just the same way they were in the original, little improvements were made (at least for how far I've gotten into the game).

They also remade the soundtrack, and in my opinion, it is a good remake, but it shouldn't have replaced the original. I would've preferred it was an option to switch between the new and old, or add the new ones to the existing soundtrack. The new songs have a slightly more polished and upbeat feel to them, and to me it feels out of place compared to the feel of the original, they would feel much more at home in Persona 5 than in Persona 3. This part is of course completely subjective.

The game also runs poorly on the Steam Deck compared to Persona 5. I'm sure it'll get fixed, but again, this is basically just a graphically updated PSP/PS2 game, the fact that it struggles to run on the Steam Deck is not ideal.

---------------------------------------------

This game is what the Persona 3 Portable port should've been to PC, for 30 dollars. Not a game marketed as something brand new for 70. It's disappointing. But if you haven't played Persona 3 before, this is absolutely the best way to experience it.

This game is the pinnacle racing experience combining both the adrenaline rush of motorsports with the spirit of a soviet army offensive move during the siege of Stalingrad. I have felt both tremendous joy and unwavering depression at the hands of the garfverse. This rollercoaster of emotions provided by this prime example of a cart racer peaks above the greatest works of media since man first touched pen to paper.

However these most recent update has been nothing but Mondays. Garfield does not like Mondays and neither do I. I do not question my skill. Gliding past pie and spring taking home first place like lasagna to a cat. However as of late there has been nothing but pain. AI that have unlimited perfume, physics that were designed by a eastern european space program. I no longer can cart with the top cats.

But fear not, I will not waiver. This setback was nothing more than microwaving day old lasagna. There is always the chance to bake a fresh batch. So I hold faith that with the UI updates I will soon rediscover my inner cat and claim my place back in the garfverse. Also robot wolf boobs 10/10

Amazing game, and a faithful remake the original with a slick sheen of polish. I'm actually digging the new voice actors, and its just as challenging (but fair...mostly!) as I remember.

You may want to wait a bit for it to be performance patched. playing on my steam deck and needs a bit of finessing

to those who want decently smooth experience

75% rendering quality
no reflections
high shadows
1280x800

turn off unified refresh rate in dev tools on your steam deck

download the 70hz mod (on github)

set hz to 35-37 I noticed it couldnt hit 38fps smoothly but 37 is very smooth.

I hope this helps someone

*edit: the difference between 37-40 is very small while the difference between 35-37 is very noticable. Do with this information as you please.

*edit: In velvet room it drops to 20-28 fps which is an issue, fixed if bumped down to 50% scaling but jeez the flashing lights kills the gpu. Steam deck is definitely under the solid 30fps cap.

If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

The original Persona 3 was my very first Persona game, so I had a soft spot for it. But when Portable came out for Steam not that long ago, I found myself getting bored with the game very quickly. Hence, when Reload came out, I was quick to jump on it, despite the hefty price tag. And I didn't regret it one bit!

Not only is it a big difference being able to explore everywhere in full HD, there were new combat systems and events being added to the game now. The only pity is that there is no option for the female protagonist for this game, which as I recall, is the only route where you can save Shinjiro and Chidori. 

As of this writing, I just finished saving Fuuka, and was able to see the SEES team all decked out in their new combat gear like some kind of shounen justice fighting group. But nice to see those scenes tho. :P

If you loved the original Persona 3 (or FES), you will love this game. Everything from the original game is here with a fresh coat of paint and massive updates that bring the game to modern standards (such as not being required to romance every girl in the game to complete their Social Links, or fully controllable party members). While I am not holding my breath that we will get a DLC for The Answer (and we definitely won't get a FeMC DLC), I think this game still worth it for anyone who has and hasn't played Persona 3.  

I would only suggest buying the Standard Edition, as I don't think the additional digital content in the other versions really adds anything to the game.

It's the game I know and love, but with a fresh coat of paint. The visuals, the audio, QOL improvements and gameplay DNA of Persona 4 and 5 are weaved perfectly into this one. Whether you're new to Persona, or a long time fan who's waiting to replay P3, this is a good time to do so.

I still have the original Persona 3 on disc for PS2 (and the PS2 to play it on).  The Reload version keeps the characters we know and love, as well as the plot and the dialogue of the original game (although the dialogue has been tweaked a bit - just smoothing rough edges more than a major rework), but it adds in greatly updated graphics with a stronger 3D feel, as well as adding a lot of new content.  The battle system is still recognisably the same one from the original game, but it's been tweaked with what Atlus has learned we liked from the newer games as well - the major differences I'm spotting so far are: there's a lot more treasure drops from Shadows; there's a lot more objects to gather; and they've added in a version of the Baton Pass system from P5 (called "Shifting") to increase the ease of dealing with difficult shadows.  Other little tweaks include definitely confirming the voice you hear in your head announcing your bonds is your attendant.   I'm looking forward to finding all the other little tweaks they've made to the game as I keep going through it, but so far, this Reload is definitely a positive experience.

(Dear Atlus: could you maybe Reload the original Persona and both bits of Persona 2 for those of us who are real lore junkies?  Please?)

It's not 2023 PC port disaster
Stable 60 fps on high settings - intel i-5 10400F, GTX Super 1660, 16 GB RAM
with occasional shader compilation stutter.
So far it's faithful remake to original P3, faithfulnes comes with a cost of welcomed features from later entires. 

It adds completly new ideas and at the same time regressing few steps back in terms of features introduced in later games. One of new features is:
Theurgy, powerful skill specific to character with character specifc conditions to use it,while removing much welcome features like benched party members earning exp or switch party members mid combat
Features like skill inheritance or ability to see fusion forecast are present tho

[b]I'll update this review with complete verdict once I finish the game.[/b]


Game has some issues noticeable in the beginning hour.
There's a word some ppl crashed on sneak attack tutorial but I'm still before 1st combat atm of this review.
Update #1: I didn't crash, more details below

There're some changes in beginning 1h:
- free roam sections in place of/before cutscenes in original e.g you can free roam a bit before entering the dorm (and chosing a name) for first time,
- ingame cutscences like P5,
- dialog changes,
- new intro alongside with it's theme song,
- certain tracks are rearranged e.g Iwatodai Dorm theme
Personaly I think it's on par if not [i]a little[/i] better than original

Worth noting that certain scences or events have been changed e.g "that" beach scene. 
There are rainbows in certain places in case you're bothered by it - pins on students bags or painted on monorails.

Update #1: Just reached combat section in Tartarus
There has been certrain very drastic framrate drops in certain places:
- first combat on the roof game stutters slightly when enemies get hit
this doesn't happen later on, only in this place so far,
- upon entering Paulownia Mall for first time framerate drops very drasticly to ~20fps or below 15 fps even to almost unplayable degree
[b]the fix seems to be turning off the reflections[/b],
- Entrance section of Tartarus (the place when you choose part members before going into dungeon crawling etc.) drops to ~30 fps,
-lack subtitles in some places - idle chatter during cutscenes and flashbacks aren't subbed
flashback lack subs due to dialog format (no dialog bubbles like in P5),
- attacking enemies (notably performing sneak attack) during dungeon crawling casues multiple light stutters as game transitions to combat. This might be the cause of crashes for some ppl

Despite those performance drops game is stable for ~90% of the time I would say. 
Your mileage may vary depending on your tolerance for stutters and occasional framerate drops.
Positive review still stands

Update #2: After playing for a while with [b]reflections turned off[/b] many performance issues like stutters disappeared. Even areas with fps drops like entrance area of Tartarus started keeping stable 60 fps.

Persona 3's biggest drawback has always been its age, but the remake brings it up to modern standards. The writing has been preserved where it was good and improved where it was lacking. The combat has brought in innovations from P5 while even adding its own brand new features. Tartarus is actually tolerable now; I have no idea how they pulled that off. The new English VA's fit the characters so well that you might not even notice they're new if you haven't played the original in a while.

If I had to choose between P5 and the original P3, I would have a hard time. With P3R, it's not even a contest.

14hrs may not seem like a lot of time with this game to give a review but from what i've played so far i felt it was a reasonable amount of time to put in for those who may take interest in the game and want to give it a try. First and foremost, i put 350 hours into Persona 5 Royal when it released, and i had already played the base Persona 5. So that means i essentially bought what could be the same game with an expansion attached . It was worth every penny. I love Persona 5 with a goddamn passion. Which is why it disappoints me to say, I think Persona 3 Reload is just a lesser persona 5 in almost every way. i was told the story is darker, its not. Its themes maybe darker but PS5 definitely has a darker story overall. Tartarus is just Mementos with rouge-lite elements. And thats not bad but thats literally the only combat. What was good about Persona 5 was the combat was integrated into more than just mementos. In fact mementos was an after thought until the later half of the game which made it bearable cause the real prize were the main story dungeons that werent randomly generated. I have almost no care about getting the social links because all they do is help with exp for fusions. Which is good, but Persona 5 had passive bonuses for every social link which gave you a reason to want to max them all out, as those passives were substantial. I'll make another review once i've finished the game. Maybe im wrong and the story really picks up later and im just judging too early.  TBD

I would recommend the game to anyone willing to give the Persona series a chance through this game. 
Its worth a try at full price or even on a sale in the future.

So let me begin with the admission that I have played P3/P3FES and part of 'The Answer'

I booted up the game and understood that with a change in hardware and presentation, the graphics would be different especially with almost a decade between it's original design and the current make...

BUT WHAT THE HECK HAPPENED?!

I just watched the scene where The Main Character and Yukari encounter [spoiler]the first Full Moon Shadow[/spoiler] and the whole sceene feels... Soft? Floaty? Underwhelming? Heck, they also [spoiler]render Yukari useless by bashing her aside before she can use the Evoker, in P3/FES she managed to use it twice before being removed from combat. THAT WAS SUPPOSED TO BE THE DEMONSTRATION THE MAIN CHARACTER NEEDED TO KNOW HE HAD TO USE IT![/spoiler]

This was supposed to be the big 'HOLY COW FECAL MATTER!' moment that makes you understand that the item is not JUST a gun and sh!t just got real, instead it's more like watching an admittedly beautifully executed ballet and the next motion it about to start.

I will still play this game and I may change my review later, but I would caution anyone who loved the visuals of the Original game to maybe wait until this goes on a sale...

the bar was set low for this game. its not too good the cut seen's are a mess and are an insult when they are not in the same style. some are using base charterer models and look bad compared to the original animated cuteness from the ps2 that they did not use for whatever the fuck reason. some of the cut seens are ripped from the show and some are actually fully rendered and look nice. the game has horrible frame rates that drop a lot any-wear that's not the dungeon and the background characters don't have faces so that's creepy as hell  and looks real lazy. the music is not very good they changed up the lyrics a lot and that was not needed sorry if you liked the original soundtrack that made the persona games iconic that's gone in this game. had a lot of clipping when walking into shops with charecter leg sticking out the door. or ill open a door and see the black area that was not filled in with texture when changing areas in the school. its very clear that this will have a lot of dlc bc you are told often if you play online what dlc is available. there is some new stuff like the social links are all voiced over now so thats nice but overall there is a lot missing from the game that was in the original game. combat looks kinda odd you dont get to see who has the next turn so its hard to stigmatize and its clear they did not want to add movement animations to this game. no enemy model has a walk animation they just show them attacking next to there target. overall this is a well disguised cash grab with very little polish. 2/10 on this one bc its clear there is a very small amount of work done but its clear it was rushed and not a 70$ game should not be having issues with clipping and frame rates at that price.
