GAME OF THE YEAR

[h2]PSA[/h2]
Buyers beware - Do not buy the Deluxe Edition - It's pointless. There's been mentions of being able to rip the soundtrack but it's not official. It's not a simple download or "click here to access", heck the app doesn't even have an official way to leave, you have to Alt + F4 to close the app. Consider either the Base or Premium Deluxe versions as these are the only ones worthwhile. Or do your research on how to rip before you walk in willingly. No idea on the Artbook though, I only cared about the OST.

[h2] Review [/h2]
Now that I got over the mess that was my launch day experience, mostly my fault but a save file being locked off because of missing pre-order DLC I couldn't restore after refunding my game to get a cheaper copy was just icing on the crap cake at the time... Now that I've had time to sit down and take my time, I'm updating my review from Negative to Positive. Huzzah!

Persona 3 Reload is the latest main-line entry to come out of Atlus following the glowing standard that is Persona 5 Royal. Alot of people are going to hold this game to P5R in terms of gameplay and features.

[h3]Tartarus is NOT like Palaces.[/h3] 
Perhaps the biggest thing - If you know anything about the previous Persona games (speaking mostly of 3 and 4, I don't have experience with 1/2) you'll know the dungeons are randomly generated. This lends to what could be considered a rather boring and uninspired design. And when you compare it to P5R's well laid out Palaces, yeah, Tartarus is pretty plain and barren. But P3R is recapturing a game originally out on the PS2 so naturally there's limits and creative liberties when overhauling a classic amongst fans and ultimately the game that set in stone the Persona design people have come to enjoy for almost 2 decades. 

As a result, making Tartarus like palaces just isn't feasible and shouldn't be taken as a negative - The whole nature of Tartarus is that its ever-changing, 1 night will never be the same as the last in regards to story so randomly generated remains relevant beyond "Ew dated game design". Does that defend said game design? Perhaps it does but in an age where we've seen tactics and mechanics get overly complicated or generic like your average open-world action adventure, returning to something like this isn't necessarily a bad thing. I may go as far to say, it's refreshing even... Why? Travelling a labyrinth with limited resources with no way out but pushing forward hoping to find a teleport point as you're running out of SP/supplies can be a thrill, games play it too safely these days and having a randomised design, the threat is ever high. Upto you if you're on board with that.

I'm only about 6hrs in so I've yet to see the first key story moment following the basics but I think that was probably the biggest intrigue of how Tartarus compares to Palaces - Simply, it doesn't. It's not supposed to.

[h3]A Darker Game[/h3]
P3 in general is known for being a darker game in tone, aesthetics and subject matter.
P4 is all about solving a murder mystery by becoming friends, believing in them to overcome adversity and discovering yourself!
P5 is about sticking it to the adults, changing their hearts to better the world and by extension, the lives they touch. Adolescence rules!
P3? People are becoming husks because shadows consume their minds in the inexplicable 25th hour of the day and you mean to put a stop to it by shooting your own headmeat to summon mythical creatures to fight. Just a little batsh*t nuts. Only a little.

P3R retains that sense of gloom amongst the stars even if the formula is about as you expect if you've played a modern Persona game; 
Living a glorified highschool life by day (seriously, the Highschool is on a damn island ffs) to headmeat blaster by night.

There's strong imagery for Death that when booting the game up, you're greeted by warnings for the kind of game you're in for. P3 tone and story is something that wouldn't come out today as objectively, it hasn't aged well with the heavier emphasis on mental health today - whilst a good thing make no mistake, the human psyche is still an intriguing plot device as we can all relate. Today people are snowflakes getting upset or offended over the slightest thing - case and point, the community page for this game. I'd like to believe Persona fans are better than this and it's just a general influx of interest from Tom, Dick and Harry but if you ever find yourself on a break and you want to be amused, give it a nose. So many people whinging... No idea what's wrong with 'em.

[h3]Style and Music[/h3]
Persona games are completely anime based if you happen to have never seen a trailer. Persona has even been touted as the ultimate anime game. I'm pretty positive an outlet gave Persona 5 that exact tagline when it originally came out and I agree that Persona is perhaps the cream of the crop when it comes to anime inspired titles. I.e. there's a lot of junk out there. 

When it comes to style, it's subjective. Atlus tends to have alot of it but it's an opinion if you're on board or not. For me, I think Persona 3 Reload looks fantastic and fits the tone of the journey - The world has something terrible happening underneath with evil lurking in the shadows being pretty heavy on shadow detail and its blues and greens. I'm a huge anime fan to boot so naturally, I'm all about this.

Music in the original game is fantastic and it's great here too - I've stopped to jam out and jiggle in my chair several times to the remixes introduced, the night time theme just walking around is perhaps my favourite but I knew that coming away from the trailers on their ending sting. It's just so damn GOOD!

‚ô´ Another wander in the niiiiight, let me paint the view... ‚ô´

Persona games are known for fantastic music and it's no different here - Again subjective as I've seen people pleading for the OG music for mods which is fine but alot of the soundtrack is already in the game so... Eh. Change isn't for everyone, power to you, opinions afterall - I hope it happens so we can all enjoy the game.

[h3]Sub vs Dub[/h3]
English dub is fine but that's coming from someone who never got into P3 originally so I have no well founded pre-established connections with these characters to compare and dispute - In the defence of those upset, if they ever do Persona 4 Reshaded and change the English cast, I'd probably have pitchforks at the ready too... so I sympathise with you all. 

I'd argue the Japanese VO is superior and to my understanding, it's also the OG cast so go figure I guess. Pity the subtitles are specifically for the English dub word for word and there's no toggle or automatic change when selecting Japanese audio. Whilst the general story gets across, listening to the JP VO, the expressions just aren't captured well in the subs. I by no means speak Japanese but I've seen plenty of anime to know some basic terms to where I can hear some basic discrepancies that misconvey what a character is actually saying. For me, this is a little jarring. I'd like to see an update for this or a mod but I doubt it's a big enough problem. Maybe I'm cuckoo but that was my observation. Play whatever works for you.  

[h2]Overall[/h2]
If you've played P5R and are jumping in, you already know what to expect gameplay wise and may even find P3R a bit drawn back by the lack of variety in mechanics but the story and tone will take you for a ride and afterall, it's more Persona - What's not to like? Enjoy visiting the game that established the foundations!

If it's your first time, welcome! P3R is a nice place to start albeit it being the darker of the esteemed trilogy most people look at when it comes to this franchise. You will more than likely join the crowd that claim P3 as their favourite as similar to Final Fantasy, more often than not, your first is your favourite!

If you didn't like Persona 5, worry not because this game not only has easily the best story in the series, but also possesses NONE of the traits that made Persona 5 widely dislike by fans of the older games and mainline SMT. Persona 3 Reload has:
-Minimal hand holding, unlike P5 which was handholdy and tutorial spamming to the extreme. Reload has more hand holding that Persona 3 Portable but not by a lot.
-Actually decent balance. Around the same difficulty as Persona 4 Golden instead of being unbalanced and piss easy like Persona 5 Royal.
-No annoying, tedious, zelda-like dungeons like in P5 filled with obnoxious puzzles and tons of mini-cutscenes every 5 steps interrupting the game's flow.
-No broken and unfair negotiation system, just the tried and true shuffle time.

This game has an amazing story and extremely fun game play. Only one flaw has been made apparent in my playthrough so far and that's the performance in certain areas. I am playing on a Steam Deck (v1 $400 release model) and two areas in particular, palowana mall and the entrance to tartarus, the game's main dungeon, lag the game TREMENDOUSLY to a sub-10 FPS level. Turning off "reflections" in the settings helped the lag somewhat going from literally unplayable 1 FPS to barely tolerable 10 FPS, but the ONLY way to fix the game on Steam Deck is to go into the UE4 code and fully disable ray tracing, which is what causes the lag issue on proton. Sadly the game offers no in-game option to turn off ray tracing, which would be highly appreciated in this game as an patch or update. Though the lag doesn't matter too much since this is a turn based RPG and the areas it effects have no enemies or danger whatsoever. So while I would rate the game positively, the ray tracing issue on proton needs to be seriously fixed and that should be the top priority for Atlus rather than starting pumping out DLC.

In my opinion the best Persona game by far in terms of story, setting, cast and ideas overall. All of the DNA of modern Persona games come from this game and this game was the only one so far which did it right. The way the calendar works, social links and so on are all carefully intertwined and all the additions from Reload makes the experience even better.

It's also the first Persona re-release with a decent difficulty curve. Yes the new content makes you stronger than in the original game but there's also new difficulty settings to account for it and they are pretty challenging from my 15+ hours experience.

It might be the best remake I've ever played (maybe tied with Xenoblade Chronicle's).

A must-buy to anyone not allergic to dialogs and human emotions.

The Persona series is one of the greatest series gaming because of its simple but engaging combat, it's interesting use of relationship mechanics, it's great storytelling, and its overall handling of mature topics. Persona 3 Reload is a great example of what a remake SHOULD be, much like other top-to-bottom remakes like Final Fantasy 7 Remake, and the Spyro Trilogy Remake, etc. Even at the increased price of 70 dollars, it is vastly worth it. You will more than likely get 70 hours out of it, and the storytelling is great in its own right to warrant the price. I will also always recommend Persona 4 Golden and Persona 5 Royal.

I don't know how to feel about this. I played it all last night and Yukari hit most of her attacks and Junpei didn't swing and fall on his butt every 3rd attack attempt. What even is this?

On a serious note, It's a remake of a PS2 banger without the PS2 jank. I would have been happy with just that, but this game feels fresh and holy cow does it look GOOD. Looking out of Tartarus at a sea of blood through the window, the moving clocks and eerie lighting, full blossoms swaying in the wind out of the school windows. I'm not normally the sort of person to mention graphics at all, so the fact that it impressed me that much says a lot.

The mechanics removed a lot of the punishing aspects like fatigue and bringing the 1 More / Follow Up system more in line with the later Persona games, as well as Direct Commands for party members. It's a great way to experience this game if you haven't already, and honestly worth it even if you have.

This is the perspective of someone who started with P5/P5R, played P4G after, and has never played P3. 

As someone who really struggled with the age P4G was showing (even though I loved the game, mostly for the story and characters), P3R is a massive improvement. The combat system has been improved to feel much more fresh, cohesive, and smooth than it did in P4G. In addition to the combat system, some of the systems and mechanics I sorely missed moving from P5 to P4G have been implemented into P3R which makes the game feel updated and modern. Unfortunately, much of the dungeon exploration doesn't seem to have been improved on so there are times when the dungeons feel incredibly lifeless and empty. 

There are many instances when P3R shows it's age, but I think in these moments the game does so in a good way. Even though a lot has been updated, the game succeeds in delivering the comforting, nostalgic feeling that older games should provide. 

Overall I would say that P3R delivers the "old school" feeling that P4G gave, but without the frustrating and outdated mechanics. Another way to put it would be P5/P5R felt like a brand new car; sleek, modern, and easy to drive. P4G felt like a vintage car; classy, nostalgic, but difficult to drive and maintain. P3R walks both lines almost perfectly (looking at you exploration system :/) and feels sleek and modern without sacrificing being classy and nostalgic. 

Highly recommended :)

I wanted to trash this game.
I first played this on the PS2 with the extra FES disc and all. I couldn't get very far, not because the game is hard or too complex, but because the gameplay loop was boring and the tartarus was akin to watching paint dry. I can't count the number of time I fell asleep and the reaper caught me. The music wasn't all bad, but the dungeon music was the worst offender.
This was somewhat fixed on the PSP version, which I loved. Allowing you to change the BGM at will. The POV was also a little bit better in the dungeon. Cool additions but also less-than-fun rebalance. it wasn't made harder, it was made easier. An already easy-ish game made easier. I cleared it on merciless about as many time as the reaper caught me in the original.

Now this Reload version. Like I said, I wanted to trash on it, to call it useless, worthless and all that. Well...

The visuals are astonishing. Not realistic or Call-of-duty-shoot-a-man stuff, but they are far better than even persona 5 (any version) and has better fluidity than I thought possible on my potato computer. The style fits so well I was honestly surprised. Sure, the texture could be better, especially the school, but it's not that big of an issue at this point.
The sounds and ambiance are just as good. While I don't fully agree to the changes made to the music, I can still see the charm and I must admit it fits. I won't take back my word though, the opening is utter trash IMO. I hate that genre. I miss the real "burn my dread" opening. Or even the PSP alternative opening. I'm not sure why they didn't keep it, especially when the MP3 player the MC has in the opening clearly shows "burn my dead.mp3" should be playing. Call me a nostalgic nerd, I'll accept it. You can also call me a hip-hop or rap hater, it's really not among the genre I can tolerate, 
Now... the big questions.
Is the story good? Well... the main story hasn't changed a bit. other than more pushy localization and more hardcore censoring to allow the gun-to-the-head to fly by more easily... The main story, so far, shows no sign of deviation. if anything, it's even more "in your face" than ever... or maybe it's just because I finished the game 100% so many time?
The confidant/social link have been slightly reworked. kinda easier to increase.
the social stats (courage, charm, academics) have been made easier than ever. without even trying I had level 2 in all 3 before the first story boss. It's disappointing. It used to take twice as much to increase each one and now you can increase it without trying. Like... yeah sure I did go to the cafe and studied but... even while focusing on those stats in both the PS2 and PSP version, I could never get ALL three of them to level 2 before the first boss. It's not gamebreaking, and it does make it easier to focus on more important stuff early like some of the social link. So I'm a bit divided on how to feel about this change.
lastly... the gameplay loop.
Streamlined, better tutorial, great additions and all that. Harder to level up somewhat but easier to progress through the tartarus. Floors have been shrunk a LOT, especially the first section. Combats aren't too hard to avoid nor too long to finish. The "tired" system is gone so you can do whatever at anytime (Maybe that's part of why they made stats easier to get, it used to be necessary to get a cold from not resting while tired after a dungeon dive just so you could get twice as much stats experience.) Nobody seems to be unavailable other than Mitsuru while they originally often had other stuff to do. Like Yukari used to be unavailable once per week or so and Junpei maybe once per two week. This just means you can probably go into the tartarus when you want to and not when the game allows you to. The classroom questions are the same as before, the average day is spent almost the same as before... The gameplay loop is kinda boring, to be honest with you. it's not bad, just not as thriling as other persona games. 

Final review comment: the addition of light (bless, holy) and dark damage type other than the insta-kill spells with low accuracy from the original and PSP version are probably the best in term of rebalance. 

I hope optionnal bosses can still be found and challenged (from the PSP version).

Is it worth the hefty price? I don't think so. 
Is it worth playing? Yes, absolutely.
Suggestion: Buy at any 20% or more discount. IMO, DLC are not worth it but that's on you to decide.

Replaying Persona 3 and 4 just keeps instilling that Persona 5 is an overrated 'dating sim' with RPG elements rather than a RPG with visual novel elements.

As far as steam deck compatibility, the FPS will dip a bit inside of Tartarus, and I have had to one crash that got my deck stuck in a boot loop. I'd set the graphical rendering to 75% if you prefer a higher refresh rate, though. 

Besides that, the UI feels great and I didn't have to make any adjustments to not get frustrated. The game feels fresh and modern, but brings back so much nostalgia from the times I played the original title. The interface looks really slick, and the music has been done beautifully (and hilariously at some points). 

I really recommend any fans of the series, or for new players looking for a social/life sim+ turn based JRPG. I'm very happy with it so far!

To start off I want to say I've played P5 twice but haven't really touched the others until now. Most reviews I saw for this were all jokes so I wanted to chime in.

Personally I would say this game is worth purchasing on sale but not for full price. 

Honestly so far my main complaints are the Visuals. The UI design is gorgeous as always but in a lot of places the graphics themselves feel lazy, Some flooring is super hi-res and shiny and the wall next to it will be a texture with no depth I would expect to see in a 2010 era game. For some reason a single animation on the pause menu plays at 15 fps despite the others being at 60. Hell there is a club location and they couldn't bother to have the background/filler characters move at all. they are perfectly motionless, as if they were supposed to dance but just left frozen because it wasn't worth it.

Edit: Just saw some people also pointing out the dorm lighting is messed up which would explain why the dorm felt off to me as well

Decent game but hard to justify for someone new to the series as P5R will be a more interesting experience for 10 dollars less

Persona 3 is one of my favourite games of all time and my favourite Persona by a wide margin.  The game is challenging and antiquated by today's standards but is fair and fun. The music is the best in the series. The story is much more grim and characters are down to earth and less "anime" than 4 and especially 5. The themes of dealing with death and apathy are hard hitting while being respectful and the ending is absolutely beautiful. 

It's a shame the game has aged like milk in some areas that makes it hard to recommend to people without patience and tolerance for older game design. Like the boring dungeons and previous mentioned "antiquated" combat. Other versions never quite brought it up to snuff with the polish of 4 and 5. FES only gave us an expansion called "The Answer" to the story that went largely unbeaten due to an inconstant story and a MASSIVE jump in difficulty to an already tough game. Portable introduced plenty of new content in a Female MC and gave us direct control of party members, however it massively stripped back the scope, design and some of the story in order to work on the PSP.

Now Persona 3 Reload is out. The game I've always wanted, not only as a chance for newer less patient players to enjoy the story and characters, but also for Persona 3 to finally have a definitive version with all the style and quality of life of the later games. The menus, art design and animation are top notch. Dungeons have more things in them, more variety overall and you can dash to get through them quicker. The OST has been reworked and re-recorded with some nice new music tracks that fit incredibly well and are bangers. The new features of "shifts" that copy the "baton pass" of 5 is a nice little addition too.

What has really impressed me however is how you can customise your experience. If you want to play it like the OG with limited party control and a high difficulty that's an option. if you want an easier experience and direct control over party members you can do it. If you want a mix of both? Go right ahead.

Anything wrong with this remake? So far all i have are nit picks. Like missing the original animated cut scenes style (personal preference), some music while still fantastic has been changed in an odd way ( Mass Destruction's funky "Babe-AY" yell is now a flat "Baby"), and some animated cut scenes have been replaced with just in game models acting out the scene which while still looking great is kinda lame in comparison. Also "The Answer" and the Female MC are not included in this as it is a remake of the original release.

Do i care about any of this? Not at all. Especially in regards to the "missing content" as i never cared for "the Answer" outside of some nice story points. In regards to the Female MC that is a large amount of content gone but Portable recently got a port if you really wanted it. Also FemMC wasn't canon anyway and had some very QUESTIONABLE romance options even for a Persona game so i felt it was necessary to enjoy the game.

I feel like Persona 3 Reload is for 3 types of people: People who never played a Persona game and just want an easy way to jump into the series, people who only played 5 (the weak links) who refuse to play any of the previous ones because "muh jank" and "ps2 graphics", then there's people like me... People who loved the original for what it is on it's own with nothing else tacked on but would like an update to pretty things up and smooth things out. Persona 3 Reload checks all the boxes for me.

I will update the review once more is played if more is to be said or if things fall apart later on. At the moment however i'm falling in love with one of my favourite JRPGs all over again. If you want a big turn based JRPG with social elements and a fantastic story to sink your teeth into Persona 3 was always a great pick.

Now it's the best it's been since OG release. Now it's one of the best picks you have available. Get on it.

The game is a really nice re-imagining of SMT: Persona 3, and FES, coming from a massive Persona fan (As someone who managed to play through every mainline game, including the spinoffs.) After sinking in 14.5 hours into this game, I can say that it's definitely a great game. It's too early to say if it's the definitive version, but I can say is that it's definitely keeping true to 3 and FES. Even enjoying some of the new additions like 'Shift', and additional SoL events like studying with your teammates. Tartarus feels smoother now, and it isn't such a grind, it's also more captivating since every block now has their personalities, even down to the layout per chunk. The graphics are beautiful and the lighting makes this game feel like it's in '09. Even if FeMC isn't here (and frankly I think it's too much copium people have,) it's still solid. 

My only gripes/peeves about the game is that occlusion view/camera is pretty bad, I don't mind it but you can definitely tell they focused on UE4 than their own engine 'P-Studio'. While battling, it slowly feels like it'll be easier than 3, as much as I enjoy 'Shift', it allows easier techniques to be pulled off. While feeling like some enemies got a nerf, or a huge unnecessary nerf. The only time I actually had trouble was the 'Magician.' Only due to the times it sped up the time. Another gripe I have is that, and this is very minor, so take it with a grain of salt, and a hot take, but I think Kaggy for Akihiko, kinda overdid it, I like the guy but I think he put too much effort lol

Beyond that, the game is really good, it's definitely faithful while also keeping FES content, if anything I feel like they undersold it saying they added minor FES contents. I recommend it to anyone starting the Persona series.

My favorite persona game hands down. This game touches on subjects that are hard to deal with for many people, but from a grounded, hopeful and compassionate perspective. They added a trigger warning for the moment you load the game up in this edition. This was very warranted, and I am glad that it is there for those who do not know what they are getting into. Combat updates give the game's combat system a lot more personality (the combat back in FES was uhh.. controversial to say the least since you couldn't control your party haha). I will say that, for those who want more of a challenge than normal, merciless may be worth doing instead of hard. I haven't gone below merciless, but it still feels easy at times (albeit i am only at floor 42 in tartarus).

Lines have been changed and voices have been changed. Some characters have a different feel to them and even the music is a bit different. Even so you gotta admit Persona 3 is one of the best video games ever made. This being a remake, it has to be pretty beeping good, right?

Giving this a not recommended temporarily IF you want to play this on Steam Deck. Hopefully Atlus will patch soon, but the fact that this is listed as "Deck Verified" is a joke. Default settings have areas chugging in 15-20 fps range. You can boost this by disabling reflections, but I've heard other areas of the game, such as Tartarus, still chug between 20-30 fps or so with this disabled. The MC's dorm room also drops to around 40 fps with reflections off. Is it playable? Yes, but the stutters and fps drops make for a rough experience so far.

I would personally wait until they fix the performance issues. If you want to play on a desktop, I'm sure you'll be fine.

A really good remake, but the soundtrack bonus edition one has the problem of you can only interact with the bonus content in window. If you alt tab it stops playing music. Id highly recommend waiting on a phys release cd if you want the music, Im intending to buy phys release cd. Otherwise I think the artbook looks great and the bonus persona and costumes in the dlc are a nice touch! 

A notable difference from this version of persona 3 versus the originals are that this one does more of its scenes as 3d animations versus 2d like the original does; but it works really well! Its almost a little more immersive for it! That said there are some noticeable differences between this and the source material so if you want a 1-1 this isnt it, but the changes and iterations made are honestly all positive thus far. 

Most importantly I think in the line of features and changes is that there is now incentive to explore the areas available to you each day before going to do your tasks and progressing time which I feel like it lacked before.

Persona 3 Reload holds a special place in my heart as a devoted fan of the original Persona 3, a piece of media that profoundly impacted the trajectory of my life. The anticipation for this remake has been a journey I've eagerly embarked upon, fueled by dreams and nostalgia that have lingered for a long time.
:
‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê‚≠ê

Persona 3 Reload successfully captures the essence of the original, revitalizing the cherished narrative that resonated with fans like myself. The visual enhancements breathe new life into the familiar landscapes, and the bits of additional content adds depth to an already compelling storyline.

The gameplay improvements and quality-of-life updates make the overall experience more enjoyable, offering a fresh perspective while maintaining the essence of what made Persona 3 unforgettable. The inclusion of new features seamlessly integrates with the classic elements, creating a harmonious balance that keeps both old and new fans engaged.

However, if there's one aspect that left me yearning for more, it's the option to use the original game's soundtrack and voice acting. While the remake's rendition is commendable, the nostalgic pull of the original audio would have added an extra layer of emotional resonance. A toggle option for enthusiasts to choose their preferred soundtrack and voice acting could have been a welcomed addition.

In conclusion, Persona 3 Reload is a stellar remake that pays homage to its predecessor, providing a fulfilling experience for both longtime fans and newcomers. Despite a minor desire for the original audio, the game's overall quality, depth, and nostalgic value make it a worthy addition to the Persona series.

Disclaimer: I have never played another Persona game before, including the original Persona 3. The vibes of this game are immaculate. The music, the visuals, the interactivity with all the different areas and characters, it all really makes for a super immersive game. I'm anticipating sinking way too many hours into it. My only complaints are the PC controls on mouse and keyboard can be a little jank. I understand that this is a remake of a PS2 game and meant for controller, but at least don't have the mouse cursor pop up whenever I move it. Also, I had a bug where my game chugged the absolute crap outta my PC and I had to try and get top a spot where I could save at about 1 frame/10 seconds. This has only happened once, and honestly I am just happy it didn't crash and have me lose all of my progress. Overall, my initial impressions are super positive!

This version of Persona 3 does not replace Persona 3: Portable, yet if one wishes for a more "modern" way to play Persona 3, this is indeed the title to acquire!

One doesn't need the DLC to be having fun, as the base game should be more than sufficient to have a good time, even if you've played through previous Persona 3 versions, including Persona 3: Portable.  The "Shift" party skill is designed so that it can create stylish ways to take down the Shadow enemies, and often is not required in early battles.  The music is great, but fans of the old versions of songs may have to get used to the new vocals and different lyrics in existing music.

If you love previous versions of Persona 3, then most likely you will find at least one aspect of Persona 3 Reload that you will admit is to your liking.

New to Persona games?  Definitely give this a try!  It will at least amuse you as you enter the Persona Japanese Role-Playing Game series.

With the limited amount of time I have played the game thus far, I already have a lot to say. I had the privilege to play one of the original versions of this game Persona 3 FES at the very young age of 9 years old back in 2013. To this day the original version of this game remains very near and dear to my heart. I love all of the characters, the narrative, and especially the world building. The things I admit have not aged the best in this game are the dungeon crawling, and the rather bland visual design. Even compared to other entries in the JRPG scene during this time it tends to look somewhat washed and lifeless in points. The art direction for the original version of this game I personally consider to be very good, but the remake honestly takes it to another level for me. It does definitely boarder more into that Persona 5 territory of art direction which some may not like, but I am personally fine with it. I will update this review with more in depth thoughts once I finish the game, but for now; I would say I recommend this game. It plays well and is a great re imagining of the 2000s era JRPG Persona 3. I never thought this remake would exist, let alone this series grow so popular, but I am so glad it did and that it has reached the hearts of so many people.

Minus some stuttering, it is possibly the most polished game on release by a major studio in months. Which is great because Atlus famously sucks at patching their games post-release. Still, they deserve some praise for not treating their customers like free beta testers in today's late-stage-gaming industry.

The music is fantastic. I played Persona 5 and 4, which also have great music, and it looks so far like 3 has some bangers as well.

Never played the original so I won't know what I'm missing from the post-game. I also don't know what the original pacing or atmosphere was, which is great because I have nothing to nitpick compared to the first release (though some reviews say the original had a more "spooky" vibe).

[h1]The Arcana is the means by which all is revealed...[/h1]

Persona 3 has always had an amazing place in my heart. It's one of the most influential games in my life, and I can link it to my own creative process, writing, and tastes. It's one of the most beautiful stories and tales about friendship, death, and strength in any media.

RELOAD is a fresh repackaging of the original experience. That's not bad, it's actually very good! It twists expectations of experienced veterans like myself, while making the daunting task of Persona 3 welcoming to newcomers. All the visuals, audio, voice acting, and combat is a visceral, and surreal as ever before. The characters feel more alive and real, with their struggles just as vivid.

If you've never played a Persona title, here's where to start. This is the height of the entire franchise, and a should be a staple in "Greatest Games of All Time". It will always be in my top 5 games, and is why everyone should attempt to play it, anime fan or not.

After playing it for a bit, this game is honestly the best I've seen from Atlus. With all the menus being fluid (pun intended), the game controls are smooth. The animations and the cinematics are gorgeous and the game still feels fresh even for a remake (I've played p3 and p3fes). The camera controls are better than P5 and feel really nice, with the combat also making the game feel somehow more fun. I'd say it's worth the 70 dollar base price if you're into Persona, but if you aren't a person who would pay 70 bucks for hundreds of hours of content and story (who wouldn't) then go ahead and wait for a sale which is probably gonna only lower the price by a max of 15%.

Is this a great enhancement of Persona 3? Yes, absolutely. If you're an Atlus fan you should definitely play it. The enhancements and influences from Persona 5 put a huge smile on my face. However steam is stretching the truth. Can it play on a deck? Yes, but great......no. In fact anytime you enter an area outside of the main dungeon that has alot of npcs it struggles to render...hard. Like the fps dips to borderline unplayable. i got stuck in a conversation loop because it lagged so much. (when i kept hitting a it would just keep the conversation going even when i meant to walk away) steam needs an honest optimization level disclaimer, that green check mark is plain evil. Atlus needs to do an update to address this too.

[h3] Steam Deck Performance [/h3]
I played through the first few hours on the [b]Steam Deck[/b]. The frame rate will often drop below 20 FPS on the default high settings. [b]Reflections are the biggest culprit of frame drops in my limited testing[/b]. The other settings didn't seem to have any real impact on performance. After turning off reflections, I have yet to see the frame rate drop below 40. I did my testing with the Watts limited between 7-12. I didn't notice any real difference giving the system extra Watts.

EDIT:
Upon playing further (at a 7 Watt TDP with reflections off) the frame rate seems to often sit around the mid-30s when exploring the dungeon and in some over world locations at night. In these situations it will occasionally drop to 28 but usually sits in the 32-45 range. Exploring the over world is usually around 40 fps. During stationary situations such as dialogue the fps is usually around 60fps.
This game taught me how to burn my bread - Shooting myself in the head/10 experience

This is the (closest to) definitive way to play Persona 3. Yes, it is missing FemC and FES The Answer (for now on this one), but the QoL improvements more than make up for it. World feels much more alive in this version, exploring Tartarus is actually fun, the reworked voice acting is great (special about out to Zeno Robinson for knocking out Junpei) and the reworked OST just slaps. Lotus Juice cooked in this version for sure!

A beautiful and faithful remake of many weebs entry point into Persona and SMT overall. I cant imagine any P3 fans who haven't already picked this up but if its a money issue, its well worth it. 

People who came in with P5 will also enjoy it and are in for a fast opening ride when you compare the two. P3 gets into the school life/dungeon crawling segment way faster then P5 or even P4.

On the port side, its runs very well. Graphical options are the minimal for most japanese games but it has support/button layouts for the big 3 and keyboard support.

I'm unironically one of the biggest fans of the franchise, I started with P3, and seeing this being remade is what truly gives me a boner, I wish girls were real.

It's a great port, although there are some issues I have with it. For the positives, the voice acting is amazing and the new art and UI are stunning. I can look at this for hours. The gameplay is great too, and they made the whole 'running into a shadow and hitting them in the back' system a lot more fun and intuitive. As for the negatives, it's mainly just performance issues. In some areas, like Paulowmia and more crowded places in town, on a 3060, my frames drop considerably with 150% rendering, but the game working fun in all other areas.

All in All, this is a great reboot with the things I loved about Persona 3 in some fresh new paint and with tweaks that make the game feel more modern
